number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												Played it for almost 100h on different accounts now. The game is quite simple actually, but you can get a lot out of that simplicity. ** Basics- Three different characters (Ranger, Dwarf, Elf) - Direct movement (WASD/Left Stick), direct aiming (Mouse/Right Stick)- Always all three characters in play. Coop or NPCs. (Many people have technical probs with coop. You might want to check that out.)- Different levels with multiple Zones (Mirkwood part1/2 ...)You enter at one point, exit at another one and destroy everything that moves on your way. - Grab the loot! Obviously!- Enter different towns between the zones. Sell/Buy/Repair/Get Quests. - Unlimited free travel to replay visited locations. (However the many boss mobs are not thereif you revisit a location.)** Visuals- Not high level for current gen, but it looks decent. - Sets and Landscapes are very well designed. Some areas felt like walking through the cover of a classic fantasy book. ** RPG- No real character based roleplaying. You can choose between a few conversation alternatives. But you cannot change the NPCs or your characters or the story in any meaningful way. It is about as linear as Diablo.- Very small number of town based quest. Almost all quest are about gathering loot during the fights.  ** Fighting- Hack&Slash + Ranged Shooting. You will be using both and it is quite fun. - Dwarf and Ranger use crossbows and bows, Elf uses magic bolts. - Some meele weapons are also class character exclusive. - Basic combo slashing "AAA", get a note for a critical attack, "B", knockdown/kill. - You fight smaller groups along the way and bigger mobs/bosses in arena type areas. ** Skills- Specific skill tree for all three characters. Kind of similar but the trees help to enhancedifferent playstiles or at least different feel. - Each skill matters but might be less usefull depending on your build. - Respec token available, so don't worry. ** Leveling- Level 40 is max. - Level 20 is roughly what you get after a first playthrough. - Unlimited playthroughs. Difficulty raises up to 'legendary'.- Attribute points are more important for equipment requirements than stat changes. ** Some Notes- Don't go for that one ultimate item set. At least not until you approach legendary. You will grow out of items a lot. Use that to have fun and replace them many times. Use your elfstones, try different weapons. In the next playthrough you will laugh about the stats of the former one. - Helpful item boni change over time. In the beginning you want more armor, more health, more coints etc to not die. In the end you want damage multipliers and cooldown reduction to get through those puny orks fast. - A single item with x5 coins can remove all your money worries. - Rare items are rare! You need quite a few playthroughs to get the 'perfect' equipment.You will be finishing the game with eyes closed by that time. - Your item inventory is large. Keep alterantive weapons for different situations. - Use mirrors to customize your appearance. Made the characters a lot more likeable to me. - Switch between characters if you cannot finish some area (should not be the case) or maybe a quest requires a certain character. *wink*- Don't stress yourself over lost items/opportunities etc. You can replay as many times as you like. Just carry on. - Special boni carry over from weapons to special moves. A good reason to go for dual wielding. ** Suggestions- Dwarf is considered the most powerful character. He has a broken overpowered ranged attackthat takes the whole challenge out of the game. Spare the dwarf for later, if you are interested in the other characters too. Its hard to fight big mobs and strong bosses with an axe, if you can one-shot them anyway. - Ranger is the most 'dull' (and kinda dumb looking) character. But if you want to play a sword and bow fighter, you can have a lot of fun with that guy. Ranger is a good start for a first playthrough and does not suffer from game ending op attacks. - Elf is primarily written as healer/supporter for the other two. You become the nanny for them when you play the elf. Makes the fights different and more rewarding. ** Elf tips- You are the NPC healer. But as a player you have to look after the other guys. That can be very frustrating when you play with two NPCs for dwarf and ranger. Make it your challenge to keep those little dummies alive. - When one NPC dies, the other one instantly tries to revive them. Even if they run into a mob and get killed instantly. After that you are the only target left and have the mob all to yourself. And not time to revive your buddies. Annyoing, but also challenging and a great reason to curse those stupid NPCs!!- Yes you DO need dexterity for your magic missiles damage. But all characters get high ranged damage without dexterity anyway. Attributes don't effect damage output that much. Focus on meeting item requirements. - A very rewarding build is to go for the Elfs AoE attack. A nova/splash attack that can later take out entire mobs of the strongest enemies. No Dex needed. Not much power (mana) upgrade needed.- Ranged attacks have a high mana cost and don't profit from casting cost reduction. - Elemental attacks and other modifiers take over from melee weapons to AoE attack. - Collect the ingredients for potions and USE them. Your inventory will be full with that stuff, so at least drink it.  - You can build an AoE based Elf that kills almost any enemy with a single splash attack and does rarely need a potion for health/mana at all. VERY rewarding after all the babysitting. - There is one boss towards the end that your gf might find very disgusting. ;)"She" drops a staff sometimes. Take a good look at that one and think about dual wielding and some quest rewards you might have collected...

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												I bought this game because of the co-op and because there aren't many RPG-Action Co-Ops out there. It seemed like a great opportunity to play my favourite game genre with my friend. And it might be a decent experience, if you get around the bugs, some of which might force you into restart.My rating without the bugs is 7/10. My rating with bugs is 4/10. I would not recommend this game for its full price, but with discount and some friends to play with, you might give it a try.PROS:Apart from being a co-op game there really isn't any other positive outstanding feature in this game, because as an Action-RPG game it provides only a mediocre gameplay experience and boring dialogues.CONS:-Pour graphics even for 2011. Compared to Witcher 2, which was released in the same year, LoR: War in the North is something from Stone Age.-Simple battle system: just fast attack and strong attack, blocking and few skills. There are no combos and, if you are patient enough, you can just hold block and attack simultaneously, without taking any damage (apart from ranged attacks)-Confusing crafting system, unless you learn the names of all the plants and components, it's hard to understand what will be the result of your crafting.- There is no push-to-talk, you are forced to listen to all the background noise from your gaming buddy's microphone.-If you finish a quest, you can return to complete it again. I can't understand whether it's meant to be like that or it's a bug. Either way it doesn't help you to understand what to do next.- No mini-map. It's a big problem in Burrow-downs cave system and Forest for apparent reasons.- Bad camera work – does not always follow the character.- BUGS!!!1. Some quests get stuck. No solution. Restart the game or change the host (if co-op).2. Completed quests revert back "in progress", if you return to the same area.3. Some enemies (bosses), which should spawn, do no appear.4. Sometimes it's not possible to revive your allies. Normally it's possible.5. I started to play this game with my friend. But on our second co-op session this game told me that he has progressed further than me and that I will not be able to get achievements and to save my progress. However none of us had played the game in single-player mode after the previous session, so we were on the same line.6. Graphical glitches.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												Overall, it's your standard beat 'em up hack and slash, but it's got a great amount of LOTR flavor thrown into it.  You can chose between three rolls, a human ranger, a elven mage, or a dwarf warrior, giving you a fair bit of variance between how exactly you kill Orcs and Uruk-hai (and a lot more.)  The maps are quite a great sight seeing experience with a large bit of map interactivity, rarely leaving the feeling of playing the same thing.The setting itself is just so perfect for a video game, leaving you to follow your own unique LOTR story while maintaining everything which has already been made.  It truly casts you into the line of your favorite story hero, even during the co-op experience.  Which leads to the games greatest feature - Co-Op.War in the North is AMAZING in co-op.  The game was seemingly made for it from the ground up.  If you're looking for a hack and slash co-op game, this might just be the one for you.Similar games:  Warhammer 40k: Space Marine, Fable 3, Batman series, Darksiders series, Brutal Legend, Witcher 2.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												8.7/10 LOTR: War in the North sheds a whole different light on the story.This game has got to be my favorite LOTR game (Haven't played Shadow of Mordor, thats next :p). What is really cool about this game is it doesn't just retell the story of the fellowship but rather a group of three with a quest equally as important. You do get to see all the characters from the movies at one point but the main focus is on your group. One thing that is rather strange is that everyone you meet is always saying how this story should be written down, but I guess that was to stress the importance of your mission. The combat in this game felt kinda dull, while you had a range of abilities you run into enemies that are just copies of each other but with different skins and greater stats. So once you master how to defeat a troll you shouldn't have a problem again. When you play singleplayer your two companions aren't really helpful for anything but reviving you. They will keep guys occupied but have no finishing capabilites. You find at the end of the mission you did 3/4 of all the damage dealt. Overall this game was a lot of fun. The side quests aren't too interesting but the main questline is where everything comes alive. If you have yet to, pick up this game and give it a shot.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												For the most part, War in the North delivers a satisfying romp through Middle Earth. It looks good, sounds good, and you get to explore a few really interesting places and meet some fun characters in search of random loot. In a rare stroke of ambition for a Lord of the Rings game, you're also presented with an original story rather than going on the adventures of Frodo & Co. for the umpteenth time. Some parts get more than a little fanfiction-y, and combat isn't as fluid as it needs to be, but even in areas where the game has glaring flaws, you manage to have just enough fun to overlook those shortcomings.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												Dear fellow gamerAfter just 17 hours me and my friend finished a single playthrough of the game in co-op. We discovered something: this game is a must in co-op! We had loads of fun and we were frustrated more than once when we couldn’t kill a boss or troll. But in the end we got through and concluded that this game is more than awesome!! On the other hand we were let down by the final battle, which was simply tooooooo easy, since we had more difficulty defeating the first boss in the game. THE STORY: We were pleasantly surprised by the fact that the story is interwoven with the actual storyline of LOTR. You even come across characters as Aragorn, Gandalf, Lord Elrond, Legolas and Gloin (known from the Hobbit-trilogy) and even Frodo and Bilbo Baggins. You follow three companions (Eradan, Andriel and Farin) on their quest to defeat a minion of the dark lord Sauron. On their way they make several friends and stops in the north of Middle Earth.GRAPHICS: Not bad at all for a game that is already 4 years old. We saw a fair amount of detail on armours, buildings and the like and didn’t realise we were playing such an old game.INTERFACE: Convenient use of hotkeys and a useful minimap! The inventory was a little off, since you had very limited space and images for additional and trivial objects in the world of Middle Earth.GAMEPLAY: We found it very useful that you could see the name of your friends on screen even if they were in an entirely different place/room. A very useful feature of the game is that you have the option to exchange items with other players that are only suitable for that particular race. Conveniently enough there were several sell/buy/return to civilisation-points.- For the Ranger: Very smooth movement of the character during a fight and one of the current reviewers enjoyed the swordplay a little too much at times. We liked the convenient switch between two-handed, one-handed, dual wielding and bow very useful. And, contrary to some other RPG’s,  the realism of being attacked whilst you are looting or switching weapons was very satisfactory to us! We loved the critical, brutal, legendary, etc. strikes with the swords and headshots with the bow too. They lead to some pretty funny ways of dying! We would’ve loved an alternative attack with hotkey ‘2’ while using a two-handed sort, but that could just be because we didn’t unlock every skill in the skill tree. Conclusion; Eradan was a great ranger.- For the Lore-master: Andriel has some great abilities to use in combat, as a supportive mage. For example, she can conjure a magical shield that can protect you against arrows and magical blasts. She also can use her staff as a melee weapon, that is actually quite strong. Because of her Elven ancestry, Andriel can use herbs to fabricate potions to support herself or her companions. This can be decisive at some points in the game.- For the Champion: Not applicable (yet), but Farin is awesome!! He got us out of trouble more than once…more like a thousand times…LOL. ALSO FUN;	- You can use your Eagle friend to do all the heavy work for you.	- You meet a dragon; Which seems to be very popular amongst gamers.	- Turrets!Overall conclusion: 'The Lord of the Rings - War in the North' is a must have if you are a fan of the LOTR, RPG and/or co-op gaming, with a bit of hack & slash in it. We had hours and hours of fun (and yet more to come) and we didn't get bored with the storyline once, even though all those trolls were a pain. Me and my friend decided that we definitely are going to play this game a few times each year... *Totally not addicted*Enjoy the game!

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
												This game is definitely one of my favourites that I own. It isn't exactly amazing, but it isn't bad at all. The story is pretty good, nothing too exciting however. You don't really get any sort of connection with the characters. You're kinda just an elf, dwarf and a human who are tossed together, it feels. Throughout the game you get to visit places such as Fornost, the Barrow-downs, Rivendell and even Carn Dum, the capitol of the old Angmar empire. As far as pros go, the story is alright, and you can tell the devs did put a bit of research into things. There's a few nice name drops here and there as well. The soundtrack is pretty good, and none of the levels are exactly impossible, though in some cases it can get that way pretty easily. Combat is alright, consists mainly of LMB for light attacks and RMB for heavier attacks, or a critical attack when the enemy has a yellow arrow over their head. You also have 3 abilities for melee and 3 for ranged, used with the 1, 2 and 3 buttons. You also have a handy eagle to call with the fourth. Combat isn't exactly amazing however, I'll admit, though it's pretty simple to get the hang of. Isn't slippery or hard to adapt to whatsoever. You and your companions are, in a way, tied in with that of the Fellowship, and several things that occur in the movies happen because of things you did, which is pretty neat.Now to the cons. This game is pretty well known to have a LOT of bugs. There's a few quests in particular that are very buggy, and you can easily screw yourself over with them. If you're focusing on whether this is canon, I've seen mostly people saying that it is not canon. The achievements aren't very bad at all, either, though the "strength of our alliance" achievement is extremely tedious to get in my experience, and is very buggy as well. There is a lot of issues when it comes to balance. As Farin, the dwarf, unlocking the explosive bolt can do up to 150k damage from what I've seen personally. Which can instant-kill trolls and usually 2-3 shot a boss. Took around 8 shots or so to kill the final boss with it. Now, what I said earlier about the levels sometimes being crazy hard comes down to you. If you run out of health potions, you do NOT have the option to save manually. So, if you go into a level, run out of potions and can't leave (example being a later stage of Nordinbad) you're pretty much ♥♥♥♥ed, and you have to do it on your own. Ended up doing this myself and trying to do it with no health potions, which isn't too easy. To 100% complete the game there's a minimum of 3 playthroughs to get the achievement for beating the Legendary mode. This is a little bit of a con as well, in that there isn't really any sense of a challenge. Mobs do a little more damage and take some more as well, but it never really is an issue.Now, be warned, two levels in particular, the Barrow-downs and Carn Dum are very well known for crashing computers. I run the game flawlessly on ultra settings, but I crash constantly in these spots. I read that it has something to do with AMD drivers or something along the lines, but I don't know much about that. Just be warned that it does have some crashing issues.In the end, the game is pretty good, has a good bit of replayability, it isn't boring or stretched thin, and it's pretty well rounded. It does have a lot of bugs and isn't the greatest with balance in the second and third playthroughs, (being in your favour as opposed to being in the enemy's favour) but there isn't really any game breaking issues. The community isn't too lively, though if you really want the one online achievement, you only need to post in the forums of the game that you want help and people flock to it. I believe the game has a built in system that causes open mics constantly, which is EXTREMELY annoying when you're an English speaking man, but get stuck with a very angry spanish child being scolded by his father while a Russian laughs and calls him a ♥♥♥♥♥ for it. It isn't amazing, but it isn't bad at all. I personally really like the game, it has a great feeling to it, and it's nice to be able to have a good lotr game. Be warned that the voices of the few fellowship members you meet are not the same as the movies, so don't get too hype thinking they'll make a cameo. I'd definitely recommend this game. I'd give it an 8/10, only lacking the two points for the crashing issues, lack of a challenge in the later levels, and balance issues that break whatever challenge would have been from the Heroic and Legendary difficulties. (Probably worth mentioning you have NO interaction with Mordor, Sauron, Isenguard or anything of the such. You have your own quest that you and your companions are going on dealing with the North. Don't go in expecting to see the black gates.)

												It's an alright game for $5.This game plays alright, it's a typical hack and slash game you can play with up to 3 people online co op.+Multiplayer Co-Op online with private/public matches for campaign mode+Easy to learn and play+Has built in voice chat with no need to press/trigger a speech key+Decent graphics for a game that is what... 5 years old?+Basic skill trees with stat growth you can pick from+Basic alchemy for Elf character+Loot system for Common to Rare gear-If you have a specific type of graphics card (Radeon series) you have to download certain drivers to stop game from crashing randomly-Can be annoying to host a game and have friends join as a new character since characters passed a specific point in game will have auto save/save features disabled completely-Built in game voice chat sucks. content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
LORD OF THE RINGS: WAR IN THE NORTHREVIEWYes, this is yet another adaptation from Tolkien's The Lord of the Rings novel trilogy, one of the best fantasy book series of all time. It also uses characters-model from the movies...but...it's a totally different story. Kind of. In the south, war breaks between the Dark Lord Sauron and the free people of Middle Earth, as shown in the movies/books. But the game shows a "hidden" story: a fellowship composed of Eradan, a Dunedáin (man), Farin, a dwarf and Andriel, a she-elf. They too, embark in a journey to fight for the north of Middle Earth, at the same time of the LOTR trilogy battles in the south. It's an interesting idea and the plot develops really well. With the presence of beloved characters that will make a LOTR fan smile, a decent villain and some good character development for Beleram, an Eagle that helps in the journey, i liked the story. The ending is also epic and amazing with a challenging boss fight. Talking about boss fights, the game have a lot of them and they're all pretty good. The game is challenging even in the lowest difficult (normal) because of tough enemeis in high quantities. Sometimes is frustrating because of your companions AI when you die in combat, but it's pretty rewarding, as this game is about loot and there is a lot of it. You can choose one of the three characters to play, and all of them have unique skills to upgrade and purchase, that's real nice. Also they have unique abilities and usable weapons, making the variation of playing with each one of them unique. You can even play online, whick makes the game a lot more enjoyable. But while playing offline, the companions AI is pretty bad, and sometimes you die just because they messed up while trying to ressurect you. It's frustrating. The graphics are outdated, and the facial animations are bad, but the scenarios are really awesome. The combat is very cool with all aplicable skills and upgrades, use of potions and weapons, inclding ranged weapons. But it gets too repetitive. The whole game is a bit repetitive, there is no puzzles, just go and kill a thousand enemies, proceed, then do it again. It may have RPG elements, but it's pretty linear besides the fact you can travel to some places, and challenge maps in scenarios from LOTR trilogy. There is dialog system too, which have zero impact on the story and only serves to know more about events/begin side quests. There is some side quests and some of them are decent, but there is only a few. The soundtrack, as expected, is awesome and have some beautiful melodies and epic combat tracks. You can call for Beleram support, which is awesome and helps a lot. The game length is good for an action game and you can replay in higher levels of difficult with the same weapons and equipment (there is armor and other stuff in good quantity). Kind of new game+, adding replay value because you can use other characters. You can swap characters during the campaign by only going back to menu or at certain points, and giving them items mean nothing, they don't use them and you should switch at least one time to up their skills and equip the loot they found because those dumbasses don't do anything alone. The game have some bugs too, as usual.+Replayability+Boss Battles+Epic ending+Decent plot+Beautiful scenarios+Lots of weapons, armors, skills, upgrades+Secrets and loot +Good characters+Absolutely epic ending sequence and boss fight+A few sidequests+LOTR Trilogy characters! +Lots of enemies types+Challenging and cool combat+Epic soundtrack+Unique characters skills, weapons +Challenge maps +Co-op+Eagle support-Some bugs-Stupid and bad AI-Outdated graphics and poor facial animations -Very repetitive-Horrid UI-Dialog does not impact nothing in the story-Very linear-Sometimes frustrating -Boring sometimesA decent Middle-Earth tale with some good inspiration on it, but nothing impressive. 7,5/10

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												It’s sadly just a very generic game. Every aspect of the game screams mediocrity from the story and characters to its unbelievably basic hack and slash gameplay. The dialogue and voice acting is very poor, I ended up skipping most of the conversations it was too boring to sit through. The writing in this game is absolutely awful, it comes a across like someone who is still learning English wrote it. They had the opportunity to tell an original story in the Tolkien world and they completely wasted it by making the plot very by the numbers and bland. It’s the gameplay that kills this game for me, I couldn’t stand how basic and repetitive the whole experience was. I had to eventually mute the game and listen to youtube videos in the background just to get through the game. The game also has this low budget feel to it, like all the animations all feel very stiff for example. The lack of variety in the level design and the environments also make the game a massive chore to play through. The very basic rpg mechanics save it from being awful but it’s not enough to save it from being a bad game.3/10 (Bad)

content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												An absolutely wonderful game. Then why the negative review? Let's see:Pros: -great story ( the action happens in the same time with the fellowship of the ring)-you can co-op through the campaign with 2 other friends-you have multiple builds for your character with various spells, armours, enchantments etc.-a handful of sidequests-quite easy to get 100% of the achievements.-when you finish a difficulty, you can advance to the next one with all of your gear, coins, and your current level ( Diablo stuff)Cons:-well, if you are an AMD graphic card user, good luck playing the game! Since the release of the game (2011) it's almost impossible for you to play the game. I have an HD 8850M which is more than enough for this, but it's so poorly optimised, that you will get stuttering every 2 minutes and the game will crash every 10 minutes. Fortunatelly I have a 4th generation i7 and I was able to play the game on the integrated graphic card which struggled a little on medium settings, but the game was playable.-this game has the most  ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ voice chat I've ever seen since I play multiplayer video games. If you join a lobby with your friends or any random person, the game will activate your microphone all the freaking time! It's almost impossible to stop it. How is it possible for someone to release in 2011 a game in which you can't deactivate the voice chat?After many tries, I finally managed to get rid of it.All-in-all this is a great game, I would say it is very underrated and it is perfect if you don't have much time to spend on, as the campaign can be finished in 8-10 hours, but unfortunatelly, the voice chat and the AMD graphic cards problem have a huge impact on it and I'm really sorry but I can't recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												I originally gave this game a negative review. However, after putting some more time into it, I feel that if you get this game on a heafty discout (as I did), you will definitely feel satisfied after the experience. However, I highly recommend you only buy this game if you either a) plan to play with friends, or b) have a high tolerance for frustrating games (see below).Here are a few things I think you should be aware of before you purcahse this game:- The UI is terrible. It is cleary optimized for console/controller use. Even then, it's full of nonsense. Also, be aware of the fact that unless you're using a Microsoft Xbox360 controller, you'll run into problems (I have a Steelseries 3GC, a PDP Afterglow Xbox360 controller, and a MS Xbox360 controller).- The AI is stupid. Your AI teammates are of little help, and tend to get in your way. If you play as the Loremaster, you'll spend a fair amount of time trying to heal them. If you play as one of the other two classes, you'll find you're doing most of the work yourself and reviving your AI teammates often.- The interface is terrible. The Keymapping makes little sense, is not customizable and is frustrating when dealing with 'Skill 4' and summoning Eagles (they're mapped to the same key and I have not found a way to change that).- The inventory system is a nightmare. Your inventory is only accessable on your current character, meaning you cannot equip your AI teammates. The AI is left to auto equip whatever inventory you're not currently using and thus makes managing it quite difficult. In multiplayer, some traded items would just disappear.- You cannot switch characters in game. This makes it a chore to keep your teammates up-to-date with stats. Often you'll find yourself three levels ahead of your teammates in terms of equipped skills before you get the chance to sort them out.- The save system is out dated. It's based off of a checkpoint system which is poorly thought out.- Finally, this game is poorly optimized. It is filled with bugs that may not be game breaking, but are certaintly frustrating and annoying. Including a particular graphic bug which causes a transparent white flashing throughout and entire level. I could not find a solution for this problem, and after searching the internet, I can confirm it is not my graphics card as many are plagued with the problem.In the end, if you can get this game on a great sale and have a craving to play a Lord of the Rings themed video game - and you're willing to tolerate some frustration - this is worth it. I would also suggest Lego: Lord of the Rings. The voice acting and music comes straight from the three movies; it's very well done.As a fan of J.R.R. Tolkien's works, I think it is worth it to mention that this follows Peter Jackson's movie version, sadly. Although, it is to be expected from a WB published game.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												This is a really underrated co-op hack and slash RPG for up to 3 players. I know not everyone is into Lord of the Rings or that sort of thing, maybe you feel this is only for those who are fans? Well, as a fan I can say they made the world 100% accessable to those who maybe never read the books or saw the films. You can just appreciate it for a fantasy game, but at the same time the game offers options through dialouge trees (a bit like Mass Effect) to ask more if you're interested, and it explains everything, even the most basic plot if you truly know NOTHING about the story.The gameplay itself is very fun, just basic hack and slash but I was never bored. You get random loot drops that can be sold, traded with party members or equipped. The storyline takes place during the events of LOTR, and it uses the look and feel of the movies, but they explore places the movies never covered, which for a fan is a real treat, and I think they did a good job. Again, you can just enjoy it for what it is, and enjoy the game just fine. The enviroments are nicely varied from ancient ruins, to forests, to snowy peaks and inside mountains, and more giving the game a nice feeling of progression and variety without feeling stale. Being an RPG, you of course gain XP points through combat and questing, and you can level up your character using character trees that fans of Borderlands or Dead Island, and any such games, will understand easily. You can pick betwee 3 characters - A Dwarf, A Man (Ranger), and an Elven Mage (which doesn't make a lot of sense with the lore, but it's a nitpick). Each character has a special ability that can be tweaked per the player's liking, and you can play your own way. The game can be enjoyed in single player, as the AI takes over any non player characters, but the game really shines with having 3 players in a game each with their own strengths and abilities. It's a fun little game, took me about 12 hours to play through, and after you're done, you can do more playthroughs where the enemies and loot are better to go along with your leveled up characters. So, if you love LOTR or Middle-Earth stories, check it out, and even if you know nothing about those things, but like RPGs, co-op, action packed gameplay, you'll enjoy it, and maybe even become interested in the world.

I could not find a solution for this problem, and after searching the internet, I can confirm it is not my graphics card as many are plagued with the problem.In the end, if you can get this game on a great sale and have a craving to play a Lord of the Rings themed video game - and you're willing to tolerate some frustration - this is worth it. I would also suggest Lego: Lord of the Rings. The voice acting and music comes straight from the three movies; it's very well done.As a fan of J.R.R. Tolkien's works, I think it is worth it to mention that this follows Peter Jackson's movie version, sadly. Although, it is to be expected from a WB published game.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2013
												Pretty fun game. Only played a couple levels in Co-op and it's much better than doing it single player, but it's still lots of fun.It fills in some lore around the war of the ring, mostly taken from Christopher Tolkien's "history of the war of the ring", which is pretty cool. There are several interactions with members of the fellowship of the ring. Character models based on the movies, and they got voice actors that sound kind of like the hollywood actors, but they're far enough off that it feels a bit cheesy.Otherwise the game is super generic, but has strong action controls and is pretty fun. It's basically a LOTR beat-em up. Graphics look like early XBox 360. The port is pretty lazy, so you can't tweak too much. Everything's pretty nice looking and artistically great, but it really looks like a console game.A single playthrough takes about 9-10 hours and there are 7-8 varied environments and plenty of different enemy types.RPG elemements are minimal. The skill tree is pretty cool and there's plenty of loot to be had, but companion gear management is awful and it's pretty unclear about how they level up.Note that keyboard controls are awkward. This game was designed for consoles and the port is a lazy one, so best to use a 360 controller.All in all, a fun game that gets way better if you have some friends to do co-op with. Definitely worth picking up for around $5 which will get you a nice 10 hour playthrough. The are 2 New Game + modes that make the enemies a lot harder and the loot better, but unless you're playing with friends I can't see anybody actually wanting to do this.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												I had fun with this title and would recommend it to action rpg fans in general and anyone interested in Lord of the Rings. I got it for a decent price around $8 and it provided me with around 12 hours of gameplay so I think I got my monies worth :)You pick one of three characters and journey to stop one of Sauron's generals who plans to start war in the northern realms. You can pick a ranger who can dual wield, a lore master (healer mage) or a tanky dwarf. They generally all play the same with a few unique skills attached to each class. Combat consists of mashing the normal attack and hitting the strong attack once enemies are weak to cause critical damage or finish them off. Levels consist of areas where you have to defeat waves of enemies before the next area is unlocked and you pick up gear for your characters and level up.I played this game solo but I can see the real fun is with playing with friends which I haven't tried, not even sure if it works or not considering this is an older game. Your AI companions can be pretty dumb often getting preoccupied fighting one weak goon while you get swarmed by enemies. You can only switch between the characters at checkpoints which is a shame and only your main characters look will be affected by what they are wearing.The music and the voice acting are great although some of the dialogue is cliche. You do have some dialogue choices during the story but it doesn't really matter what you pick. The story itself is weak and predictable and when you finally defeat the last boss you instantly find out that the original Fellowship completed their epic journey making your efforts seem kind of pointless.Overall great game and still playable in 2016. I only wish you can freely swap between characters in battle and setup all your characters with loot and equipment that you find in the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												Well after about 2 hours of setting up it finally worked. For us, there was a specific order in which we had to set everything up, one of us had to switch to a different computer, the other one had to be the host and every one of us had to make some funny sound settings to disable the ingame voice.But after all that I really did enjoy venturing out with my friends. The combats were somewhat interesting, though we only finished on normal mode were everything is a little bit too easy, and the abilities matched the characters. We played the default MMO setup with healer (my role), tank and damage dealer, which worked great.Some abilities seem to be a little overpowered. There is, for example, this big shield (we called it "the bubble"), which deflects every projectile anybody shoots at you and heals you. This includes bosses. Therefore you sit in it waiting and shouting in order to get the bosses in melee range.All in all, the dialogs are linear but believable and well made, the story feels good and the atmosphere is deep, even though it can get a little monotone after too long periods. The graphics are not the best I've seen even for the time the game was released, but they are still not too bad to look at. The textures of your armor and characters are somewhat well made even though some animations may be a little set off. Sometimes the voice isn't fully synced.We finished the game in about 10 hours in 3 sessions.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2013
												This game is REALLY average. The combat consists of LEFT CLICKING and Spacebar. Oh, and right click when you see an orange triangle. The combat is extremely boring, and unengaging. It's also really annoying when enemies constantly stun-lock you. Enemies with 2 weapons are the worst, you'll constantly be hit and stun locked unless you block them, but if you are constantly being hit in the first place, you won't be able to block because you are already being stunned. The game throws tons of enemies at you, mostly to hide the fact that the game has a shallow combat system. You can press space to roll, which clips you through enemies, and is extremely effective. There's not even a penalty to spamming the roll! Meh. The enemy types in the game are also usually very meh as well.   Your AI teammates are the dumbest people out there, if the last one is alive, they will constantly try to revive you, NO MATTER WHAT. Even if there's only 1 hit left to finish the boss. Or they won't even try to evade the enemy, they'll just take it in order to revive someone. Regarding certain enemies, there are big ones who smash you, and toss you and make you ragdoll around. These are easy to beat, but when there are multiple enemies, it's a chore, because you'll be forced to hit them 1 or 2 times, roll away, come back and hit them again. You'll be able to use abilities here and there, but those aren't very effective and they cost 'power'. The game also has an RPG element that is very basic. You get XP from killing stuff, then you level up. After you level up, you put points into attributes and you pick abilities, either passive, or activated.  There are very few abilities, and they aren't very interesting, save for the Ranger's Stealth, the Lore-Masters bubble shield thingy, and the Dwarfs War Cry that supposedly does something useful. The game also has really bad AI management. You tell them to attack or defend. That's it. AND even when you tell them to defend, they will often times, leave you to kill an enemy. When you give them gear, they will throw it away most of the time and use one that sucks, because you can't manage their inventory. They will usually throw it away once it breaks or reaches low durability from what I can tell. This is also very annoying, because they will toss away high tier gear in order to replace it with ANYTHING that isn't about to break. You can't even tell if it's about to break, you just stare at your teammates and check if what they are wearing looks cool. If it doesn't you probably need to add new gear to them. The story in this game is incredibly bland. SURE, it's staying true to the book, but that doesn't mean you can't add anything that makes it interesting. The main characters are also just people you don't really care about, you don't even get to know their real backstory, and you get no emotional ties with them at all whatsoever, unless you get hard looking at the elf. Regardless, the story is also only about 10 hours long, longer if you do it alone, and shorter with friends.That's including the side-quests. There are about 20 ( or less ) side quests in the game. I'm not even kidding. And the rewards are usually rendered useless by 2-3 levels anyways. The game's matchmaking found me with no players, so I assume no one plays this anymore. You can trade items to other players, but that only matters if you can actually find someone to play CO-OP with.Overall, the game is really bland. It doesn't have any variety, and it's KEY selling points are average. I thought the game would be better, but I am disappointed with what I saw. It could have used a better combat system, better AI, better enemy variety, and better RPG mechanics. If it had all of those, I'd give it an 8/10 if I were to score it. But if I were to give it a score right now, I'd say 6/10, and that's being generous, as I do know the series, and I appreciate the amount of time they put into the lore. ( not pointing out the bug where the dwarf calls a ranger 'KINSMAN'  )

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17
												If you are looking for something LOTR related and do not have anyone to play with or wish to play alone, you could grab this. When it is on SALE that is.As to if you want to play it with your friends? In that case you will encounter two things that will devastate your enjoyment of this title. Those two things being disconnection issues that completely wipe ALL your progress in the level that you are playing with your friends, along with ALWAYS ON VOICE-CHAT. Now there are ways to go around that Always on voice-chat, but it is NOT worth the hassle.As to the disconnection issues: You lose all your loot, all your levels and all your skillpoints you gained in that level / session. The loot in your inventory / what was equipped on your character does not get saved. The moment you rejoin, those things are gone. Period.As to the always on voice-chat: Extremely crappy audio quality, no way to change mic levels or audio levels of other players, and no way to turn it off or mute others. Workarounds include using another microphone and setting it as the primary audio device and then muting it but let us be frank here. How many of us actually have another microphone, and do we really want to connect another microphone / headset JUST for a single game? I dare wager only few of us are willing and able to even try that.In other words, an okay single-player LOTR game for 5 bucks of less. For 20 bucks (19,99€) though? No. Absolutely not worth it. Especially if you are looking for something fun to play with your friends. In that case, the sale price is not worth it either.Graphics are also from the early 2010 era so it is not a pretty game either. It was not a pretty game when it came out either if the graphics are to be judged.

												I played this game about 5 years ago and came back to it recently in the hopes that it's many issues at the time would be fixed. I really enjoyed the game and co-op was a ton of fun, but I experienced the very same bugs and technical issues that made the game unplayable for me since day one of release. Certain areas in the game cause crashes and disconnects and when you're not crashing to desktop you often have to restart the game completely due to some bug or another. It has great gameplay and potential for fun with friends, but it's not worth the dozens of crashes and hours wasted on them replaying areas just to crash over and over again in an attempt to get through a single playthrough. Sadly it's just another sloppy and unpolished game that developers make and never give it another glance after it's release, the kind of game you really want to enjoy but it just won't let you. If you want to give the game a try on sale and you've got a lot of patience, go for it. But I wouldn't drag your friends into it with you if you want to keep them :p

												I liked the old lotr hack n slash games and this is close to that.The RPG elements could be better but I shouldn't matter much if you treat this like the old hack n slash games.There is however a game breaking graphics problem with some AMD cards.The game crashes often at certain parts of the game and makes it almost impossible to pass.I have tried multiple times to pass these sections and what it comes down to is a big waste of time for me.I managed to pass one such section by doing something ridiculous like zooming at the floor the whole time while your graphics settings are at it's lowest.But in the next playthrough where there seem to be more enemies some parts seem to be unpassable.Have tried the numerous reported fixes ( lowering all graphics settings, rolling back to old graphcis drivers ) but none of them work for me.Not sure if this is something AMD or the game devs should fix but as it stands nobody is fixing it.So I would recommend this game if you do not have a AMD 7xxx card ( Which I have ). content:
Posted: May 29, 2013
												This is really an excellent game. I have no idea why it scored so low in the reviews. A good story, excellent voice acting, nice graphics with tons of options for the PC version, and it never crashed on me once. it's a pretty long game (expect about 15-20 hours your first time through on Normal), lots of secrets to find, three different characters to play (each with their own play styles and each of them fun), and it has an absolute metric ton of loot to find, all of which alters the look of your characters, to go along with some good customization options.The combat is simple but takes awhile to master, and it does get more involved on Heroic and Legendary difficulties, both of which are excellently balanced (though there are a few huge difficulty spikes in certain quests.)All in all, this is an awesome game, well worth 20 bucks. This is the game Diablo 3 should have been.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												This game is based in the lord of the rings universe, and the story takes place, at the same time as the first lord of the rings movie.If you know something about lord of the rings, you would properly like this games story to some extend. The game builds on the lord of the rings universe, and you have to visit locations, that are kind of new to the averige lord of the ring knower.The game still focuses on main charecters such as the fellowship of the ring, and many more main charecters. Your journy in the game has nothing to do with the fellowship, but focuses on killing Saruns right hand (sorry if I spell some names wrong, but they are not so commen)Your journy starts at an inn, and then you move on througout the lord of the rings universe. This brings you far around the country, and you get to visit many interesting locations. There is a forrest with spiders, an underground cave with undead, A fortres with orcs just to name a few of the locations.You can take controle of one of three charecters. Each charecer, has his or hers own thing to do for the team. We have a dwarf, who functions as tank for the team, which mean he will be the first to attack, and the one to take the most damage, but still have enough life to surviev. This character uses heavy weapons and crossbows mostely, but can also use small weapons to channge things up.The secound charecter is a human, who mainly focuses on range attacks, but can also go into combat with duelweld, or a sword, and a sheild. Since this charecter is mainly focusing on damaging, he is the one to damage enemys, while the tank, takes the beating from all the enemyes. Of couse the dwarf can fight by themselves, and thats why the game is great, becouse you can basicly do whatever you want, when it comes to classes.The last charecter is an elven mage, who focuses on healing. She uses magicel attacks to attack enemyes, but is the weakest of the three and therefore needs the most protection.The gameplay is a bit different for each of the three charecters, and therefore you can have a different experince with each charecter. But the goal is the same with all three, kill all the enemyes as a team.The game is best to play with you friends, and since there is only three classes, you don`t have to hold the big gamer party, in order to have fun with this game. I completed the game with two of my friends and we really enjoyed the game, all the way through. We can say though, the story felt a bid lacky at the end, but I will of couse not spoil it. But if you know your lord of the rings movies, you will know what happens at the end of the first movie, and therefore the ending will not be a huge surprise for you. The loot and trade system between charecters is a bid odd, but besides that, you can clearly see when your charecter evolves on he`s or her`s equipment througout the game, this gives a really satesfing feeling, which you will know for neally all RPG`s.Now I want to talk about the ending, that is not about the plot, but more like the events at the ending. In the end of the game you get all kinds of awesome items, and you get all new and great talents. But then you fight an easy end boss, and all that awesome stuff you just got, can`t be used, I know you can play your charecter on another person playthrough, but still, the game is far to short to do all the stuff you want to do.A note to end on, the AI in this game is good, but only for your enemyes, if you play the game alone, you will see your allies are really bad, and don`t really contebute with anything. This is a problem if the charecter you need is the healer, since the healer won`t. Well, heal at times.This game is really good, and I highly recommend to play it with you friends to get the full experince of the game. But you can of couse play it by youself, and still have a good time with it. This game get`s a thumps up. 6 out of 10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												A decent game, if you know what you're going to getI really did enjoy this game. I love the Tolkein universe and I think the idea of the story running parallel to the story from the Lord of the Rings Trilogy worked well here. Do not expect an RPG experience, this is much more of a hack and slash, and there are many moments that break the 'immersion' of an RPG game (randomly buying items, mid level, from a floating pool of light, etc.). Story/Presentation: 6/10Agandaur, a high ranking commander of Sauron's forces is marching to destroy the north, and you must stop him. That is the meat of the story. Whilst this is nothing original, and there are no plot twists and things to keep you guessing, it serves its job well enough. The story is fleshed out with characters from the Original LOTR story (Gandalf, Aragorn etc.) and it works well to keep to the original lore (from what I know). There are side quests, but they are sparse and sometimes hard to give a crap about. I finished many of them without even realising (found an item from killing an orc, turns out a dwarf wanted it for a quest).I say 6/10 because as stories go, it is hard to go wrong when Tolkein has done the bulk of the work! The thing that brings this score down to me is how bland the playable characters are. There are many characters in this game that have quite interesting personas, the playable characters are not among them.Gameplay: 5.5/10Nothing inventive here. I played the ranger all the way through, and although the abilities that you learn (from a talent tree similar to world of warcraft), I found that most of the time you'll be mashing the attack button from start to finish. There are some AI problems, if your allies (who were clearly designed to be played by friends) see a ranged unit, they will walk slowly towards them, shooting at them, whilst melee heroes hack them to pieces. Other than that the AI is actually quite fine. I will also note here that you can 'switch character', but you lose all items from your first character unless you switch back again, so I really don't see the point. It seems like a big design flaw to me, but I had no need to change my character anyway. 5.5/10 because it serves its purpose fine, and there's a lot of gore and fun to be had, but at the end of the day its too repetitive.Visuals: 8/10Whilst the graphics are nothing to rave about, they are really quite good. The linearity of the game means that the surrounding environments look quite beautiful, and there has been quite a lot of effort clearly put in to the design of the scenes. I am also going to mention the gore as well, it is nice to see a bit of blood and severred limbs that is startlingly absent in almost all Lord of the Rings games. The hack and slash gameplay IS quite repetitive, but lopping heads and arms off never really gets old.Replayability 6/10Whilst I doubt I will play through the game again, there is the option to do so with a higher difficulty, and naturally with another player character. I think this is a nice idea, but personally I would have rather put the difficulty higher on my first playthrough, than be forced to wait until I've completed the game once. That being said, it's a nice option, and I think many will enjoy playing through again with a second character.Conclusion: 6/10A fun game, nothing special, but worth a play through. I don't think this game is worth a full price purchase, but if you see it on offer definitely give it a go. I got this game from the humble bundle, and I thought I'd end up brushing over if but I'm glad that I didn't. Take that for what it's worth!

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												6.5/10War in the North is the tale of a dwarf, elf and ranger wandering the wastes and plains of Middle Earth away from the main events of J.R.R. Tolkien's book and films.It's a respectful hack and slash action rpg, with the major gripes being the lack of much ability progression and a lot of the same enemies appearing over and over again. A mildly coherent tale against a relatively unknown antagonist is only brought back from boredom due to the rich lore that has been previously established.Reminded me of the Two Towers on PS2 back in the day. Three characters playing on screen, Each one has their own unique moves, spells, and abilities and you fight against Sauron's minions in the North. One can get involved with alchemy, another with breaking down walls to find treasures, upgradeable weapons, gear armour etc. Other games do everything it offers better. There are a few short appearances from the major LOTR characters in Rivendell but their sudden appearance and disappearance only cements the insignifance of the playable characters. Campaigh is about 10-12 hours long, bit longer I would think on higher difficulties. Best fun is the 3 player co-op. Got this on a Humble Bundle nearly a year ago, but worth a look if you have it and are itching for an average Action RPG or a LOTR game til Shadow of Mordor arrives.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												TLDR? Go to bottom for list of pros, cons.Lord of the rings games to my opinion tend to be good just for having that vibe.But forget about lord of the rings for a moment, because what you have here, is the one and only game that pulls it off to actually FORCE people to play together without the feeling that you are "forced" to play together!!!!This game is all about the team. You have a ranger (DPS), a warrior(tank) and a loremaster(support) class. Each class as before mentioned having their own task. Loot is given to each individual, which negates fighting over loot. The loremaster will have crappy damage, but great supportive skills, the tank can take a lot of damage and aggro, while the ranger has low health but can deal massive damage. Besides this, areas can only be finished when everyone is together, but the action always leads you towards it. Besides this great job, is the story compelling and very similar in feeling to the movies.Pros:- Great story- Best co-opperative gameplay EVER!- Great combat mechanics (per class different)- Reasonable replayability (switching of classes)- Good leveling mechanics that keep you compelled.Cons:- Medium to short campaign.- Ranged attack is too spot on.When in doubt. Buy this game!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2013
												War in the North is an interesting mixture of action-RPG and cRPG.It has the fun third-person action and excellent itemization of a good action-RPG. But it also has the extensive dialogue and great worldbuilding of a good cRPG. Add in the Lord of the Rings setting and you have a recipe for a wonderful game.The game is set during the events of the LotR books and movies, but mostly covers events in the north that weren't depicted in the books and movies. Those who have played the Battle for Middle Earth games, or Lord of the Rings Online, will find some familiar elements. But this is very much a different story and it takes a little more leeway than most with LotR lore.That being said, the LotR setting is used to great effect. The game is very consistent and the extensive dialogue features a lot of attention to detail. Many iconic locations from the books are depicted beautifully, such as Bree and Rivendell. And the characters all look like the actors in the movie trilogy. That's where this game's most crucial flaw comes in: voice acting. The familiar characters from the movies (of which there are a fair few) do not share the same voice actors. As such there's a very real disconnect with most of them.As to how the game plays: you choose one of three characters. You then travel with this entire party, and can switch characters between chapters. You can even play the campaign in co-op with friends, but with the heavy dialogue and cRPG elements it lends itself better to singleplayer. The AI takes over the other characters in singleplayer and you can give them some of the loot you don't need to boost their effectiveness. And there's a lot of loot, and item sets, and all sorts of stuff!Both the story and environments are linear, with very few choices in either. The story would only have been even worse were it non-linear, as is it's passable and the dialogue carries it through. Likewise the environments are extremely linear, but very detailed and interesting. These may seem like flaws, but in my experience they didn't hinder my enjoyment of the game overly much.As such, I'd say LotR: War in the North is a surprisingly good RPG. It has strong cRPG and action-RPG elements and offers a very enjoyable experience. Reasonably lengthy too, without overstaying its welcome too much.Recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												I am a huge fan of the LOTR universe, so I got excited when they said that there will be a new game about it. to buy the game and. When I finally aquired the game, I dove into the world of Tolkien once more. And I was fairly happy with the results that I've found. First of all let me say that the world of LOTR "war in the north" is a delicous a mish mash from many of Tolkiens LOTR's resorces. Like the books, movies, cartoon animations as well as the endless Imagination of snowblind studio. Which makes a woundful effort in blending the game into character with the rest of the other stories without feeling stragnly out of place. The visuals are just amazing and the dialog is heroic and thoughtful. The events of  LOTR "war in the north" characters were invented, well crafted, and detailed by the grandfather of modern fantasy Tolkien. You play either one of three main characters: the female elf lore master Andriel " the sorceress ", the dwarf warrior Farin "the warrior tank", and a human Dúnedain ranger Eradan "the roge". In the beging the trio are seen walking into the Prancing Pony in  the city of bree, heading to a table were Aragorn is sitting. They inform him that the Shire Guard at San Ford was attacked and that the Rangers have suffered a great loss. After the raid a Ringwraith mets with a man of great malice and power called Agandaur. He tells the Ringwraith that he had done as Sauron commanded and he has started gathering the Orcs of the north at the old ruins of Fornost. Farin questions why the enemy would build up a force against the Shire and Aragorn replies that a hobbit with a great burden is on the move to Bree. He asks them to help him keep the Hobbit safe by thwarting the enemies preparations at Fornost. And so begins your adventure. The game play is a decent standard type of action RPG . Nothing ground braking INTERSTELLER MECHANICES THAT CHANGES THE GAMING WORLD!!! or anything like that. Nevertheless, still decent. All three characters have mele and range attacks when battlling the endless hordes of orcs, cave trolls and goblins. There is also a combo system which makes the game more responsive. When a yellow bar shows on an enemy's head you get a chance to do a critical strike chope some heads off and gaining more XP.  The pacing of the game is done well. However, there are too many mounted cressbows sequences that kinda feels repetitive to a point.  On the other hand the game has a good co-op game play of three players. Which changed the expreance of the game altogether. You and 2 more of your friends can jon forces and lead the attack on the eeevil orc meness. And saving the hobbits for certain dooooooooom. Overall, the game is a wonderful piece of art that shouldn't be overlooked.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2013
												A fairly good movie-based game dressed up as a Gears of War-feeling Diablo clone.The plot follows TLoTR from a group of heroes parallel to the main story of Frodo, adding a lot of backstory and "meanwhile..." kind of lore for diehard fans. There's a lot of good exposition and the custscenes are well done.While the game is firmly planted in the Action-RPG tropes of Diablo and Titan Quest, it plays a lot like Gears of Wars, minuse the cover mechanic. Sprinting feels like the "roadie run" and the rolls are almost the same. It's made using Epic's Unreal Engine 3, but its strking how much this game borrows gameplay mechanics from Gears of War with an ARPG shoehorned in and then told using the trimmings from TLoTR's plot.Visuals range from good to great and the sound is satisfying, but nothing amazing. Combat is fun and it's a delight to knock a big, ugly orc's head off and then fel his friend by slicing his leg off.In case you're wondering, yes there is a multiplayer mode that allows you to play through the game in co-op.Overall, a nice buy for anyone a fan of ARPGs and/or TLoTR with a farily decent amount of replayablity.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												This is your generic fantasy rpg game. I would not even bother with it if not for the setting...Middle Earth ! And damn it adds a lot to the game. You can play as 1 of 3 characters (elf healer/mage , dwarf warrior / crossbow guy  and the ranger / tank dunadain.(2-handed sword dunadain warrior op:) ). Anyway I picked it up with 2 other friends and I really had fun...until I started getting blue screens. I dnk why I encountered this problem since my computer never behaved like this with any other game and i meet the specs with ease. It was not from the graphics settings of the game (tried so many options) and it felt really random (would happen at random times in the game , not even twice in the same place). Just wanted to lay that out before I continue. The action / Rpg elements are solid with different talent trees (and the leveling is at a good pace) , a lot of loot (that also changes how your character looks) and the coombat feels good and smooth , fluid. The graphics are decent , but an RPG is not about the graphics and since the gameplay is good i am willing to overlook that. The story is your pretty tipical fantasy story with a middle earth setting , but I admit I enjoy that (although it is predictable). The voice acting though , it's kinda on the low side. Also playing with friends increases the value of the game so much so keep that in mind.In conclusion I would say that you should buy this game at full price if you are aware that you might encounter bugs and blue screens and are ok with it and if you have friends to play with.Otherwise wait for a sale if you want to buy it as playing alone will soon become boring and start to feel like a chore.

												With some of the glitches i've experienced playing this game in co-op mode, i'd considered giving this game a thumbs down.  But even with the glitches I can't really walk away from this game.  For any fan of Middle Earth, this is just stunning.  The graphics are beautiful and incredible and the lore is pretty spot on.  You play as a small group that fights in the north to buy time for the fellowship of the ring.  You get to encounter six of the members of the fellowship, along with other notable characters.  And they really bring a sense of familiarity, the character models were designed to resemble the cast from the films.  All in all, I really, really love this game.  Glitches be damned.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												A decent game, if you know what you're going to getI really did enjoy this game. I love the Tolkein universe and I think the idea of the story running parallel to the story from the Lord of the Rings Trilogy worked well here. Do not expect an RPG experience, this is much more of a hack and slash, and there are many moments that break the 'immersion' of an RPG game (randomly buying items, mid level, from a floating pool of light, etc.). Story/Presentation: 6/10Agandaur, a high ranking commander of Sauron's forces is marching to destroy the north, and you must stop him. That is the meat of the story. Whilst this is nothing original, and there are no plot twists and things to keep you guessing, it serves its job well enough. The story is fleshed out with characters from the Original LOTR story (Gandalf, Aragorn etc.) and it works well to keep to the original lore (from what I know). There are side quests, but they are sparse and sometimes hard to give a crap about. I finished many of them without even realising (found an item from killing an orc, turns out a dwarf wanted it for a quest).I say 6/10 because as stories go, it is hard to go wrong when Tolkein has done the bulk of the work! The thing that brings this score down to me is how bland the playable characters are. There are many characters in this game that have quite interesting personas, the playable characters are not among them.Gameplay: 5.5/10Nothing inventive here. I played the ranger all the way through, and although the abilities that you learn (from a talent tree similar to world of warcraft), I found that most of the time you'll be mashing the attack button from start to finish. There are some AI problems, if your allies (who were clearly designed to be played by friends) see a ranged unit, they will walk slowly towards them, shooting at them, whilst melee heroes hack them to pieces. Other than that the AI is actually quite fine. I will also note here that you can 'switch character', but you lose all items from your first character unless you switch back again, so I really don't see the point. It seems like a big design flaw to me, but I had no need to change my character anyway. 5.5/10 because it serves its purpose fine, and there's a lot of gore and fun to be had, but at the end of the day its too repetitive.Visuals: 8/10Whilst the graphics are nothing to rave about, they are really quite good. The linearity of the game means that the surrounding environments look quite beautiful, and there has been quite a lot of effort clearly put in to the design of the scenes. I am also going to mention the gore as well, it is nice to see a bit of blood and severred limbs that is startlingly absent in almost all Lord of the Rings games. The hack and slash gameplay IS quite repetitive, but lopping heads and arms off never really gets old.Replayability 6/10Whilst I doubt I will play through the game again, there is the option to do so with a higher difficulty, and naturally with another player character. I think this is a nice idea, but personally I would have rather put the difficulty higher on my first playthrough, than be forced to wait until I've completed the game once. That being said, it's a nice option, and I think many will enjoy playing through again with a second character.Conclusion: 6/10A fun game, nothing special, but worth a play through. I don't think this game is worth a full price purchase, but if you see it on offer definitely give it a go. I got this game from the humble bundle, and I thought I'd end up brushing over if but I'm glad that I didn't. Take that for what it's worth!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												I am a huge fan of the LOTR universe, so I got excited when they said that there will be a new game about it. to buy the game and. When I finally aquired the game, I dove into the world of Tolkien once more. And I was fairly happy with the results that I've found. First of all let me say that the world of LOTR "war in the north" is a delicous a mish mash from many of Tolkiens LOTR's resorces. Like the books, movies, cartoon animations as well as the endless Imagination of snowblind studio. Which makes a woundful effort in blending the game into character with the rest of the other stories without feeling stragnly out of place. The visuals are just amazing and the dialog is heroic and thoughtful. The events of  LOTR "war in the north" characters were invented, well crafted, and detailed by the grandfather of modern fantasy Tolkien. You play either one of three main characters: the female elf lore master Andriel " the sorceress ", the dwarf warrior Farin "the warrior tank", and a human Dúnedain ranger Eradan "the roge". In the beging the trio are seen walking into the Prancing Pony in  the city of bree, heading to a table were Aragorn is sitting. They inform him that the Shire Guard at San Ford was attacked and that the Rangers have suffered a great loss. After the raid a Ringwraith mets with a man of great malice and power called Agandaur. He tells the Ringwraith that he had done as Sauron commanded and he has started gathering the Orcs of the north at the old ruins of Fornost. Farin questions why the enemy would build up a force against the Shire and Aragorn replies that a hobbit with a great burden is on the move to Bree. He asks them to help him keep the Hobbit safe by thwarting the enemies preparations at Fornost. And so begins your adventure. The game play is a decent standard type of action RPG . Nothing ground braking INTERSTELLER MECHANICES THAT CHANGES THE GAMING WORLD!!! or anything like that. Nevertheless, still decent. All three characters have mele and range attacks when battlling the endless hordes of orcs, cave trolls and goblins. There is also a combo system which makes the game more responsive. When a yellow bar shows on an enemy's head you get a chance to do a critical strike chope some heads off and gaining more XP.  The pacing of the game is done well. However, there are too many mounted cressbows sequences that kinda feels repetitive to a point.  On the other hand the game has a good co-op game play of three players. Which changed the expreance of the game altogether. You and 2 more of your friends can jon forces and lead the attack on the eeevil orc meness. And saving the hobbits for certain dooooooooom. Overall, the game is a wonderful piece of art that shouldn't be overlooked.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2013
												It speaks to the lowest instincts of gamers: A ton of items to collect (even sets!), button smashing for hack'n'slay and looking more and more badass throughout the game. But besides that, the story is well researched and fits into the world of Tolkien. Especially when you talk to unimportant NPCs you can learn a great deal about Middle Earth and its inhabitants (I didn't know what's the story of Arwens mother, for example.) The whole design is more like in the movies, in contrast to the colorful and comic-like design of LotR Online. The levels are really tube-shaped, the story is very strict with few side quests (and they got nothing to do with the main story). I recommend playing it in coop! It's a shame there is only an online coop-mode and no local coop, made even worse by the horrible ingame voicechat (which has, I have to admit, nice ideas like echoing when you are in caves) that has a terrible quality. Overall, I do recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2013
												War in the North is an interesting mixture of action-RPG and cRPG.It has the fun third-person action and excellent itemization of a good action-RPG. But it also has the extensive dialogue and great worldbuilding of a good cRPG. Add in the Lord of the Rings setting and you have a recipe for a wonderful game.The game is set during the events of the LotR books and movies, but mostly covers events in the north that weren't depicted in the books and movies. Those who have played the Battle for Middle Earth games, or Lord of the Rings Online, will find some familiar elements. But this is very much a different story and it takes a little more leeway than most with LotR lore.That being said, the LotR setting is used to great effect. The game is very consistent and the extensive dialogue features a lot of attention to detail. Many iconic locations from the books are depicted beautifully, such as Bree and Rivendell. And the characters all look like the actors in the movie trilogy. That's where this game's most crucial flaw comes in: voice acting. The familiar characters from the movies (of which there are a fair few) do not share the same voice actors. As such there's a very real disconnect with most of them.As to how the game plays: you choose one of three characters. You then travel with this entire party, and can switch characters between chapters. You can even play the campaign in co-op with friends, but with the heavy dialogue and cRPG elements it lends itself better to singleplayer. The AI takes over the other characters in singleplayer and you can give them some of the loot you don't need to boost their effectiveness. And there's a lot of loot, and item sets, and all sorts of stuff!Both the story and environments are linear, with very few choices in either. The story would only have been even worse were it non-linear, as is it's passable and the dialogue carries it through. Likewise the environments are extremely linear, but very detailed and interesting. These may seem like flaws, but in my experience they didn't hinder my enjoyment of the game overly much.As such, I'd say LotR: War in the North is a surprisingly good RPG. It has strong cRPG and action-RPG elements and offers a very enjoyable experience. Reasonably lengthy too, without overstaying its welcome too much.Recommended.
