number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												There don't seem to be many detailed reviews, so I will try to write one for everyone. Though I feel it is going to get thumbs downed a lot because I am not a die-hard LOTR fan and I don't kiss the franchises♥♥♥♥♥The ReviewIts a good game, but I thought there would be a lot more to it. The ending and the entire story really feels irrelavent to the actual story.I was also expecting the story to be much much longer, seeing as how it would play in the timeline of the 3 movies, but instead the game didn't take long to beat at all, or at least not as long as I had expected.This game took me 11 hours to beat, and about 8 hours of that is gameplay, while the other 3 hours is storyline.Seeing as how you meet the fellowship before they depart, I thought you would be a group that played a part in the movie, but were more in the background, sort of like you had a part in the story that the books and the movie didn't show. The in-game map shows all of the locations of the LOTR, Helms Deep, Mordor, The Shire, etc.I thought we'd take part in the battle at Helms Deep, that maybe we would fight some Orcs/Goblins that had followed Frodo and Sam, without their knowledge, as they were about to destroy the ring. I thought we would be able to explore places like the Shire and some of the other major places in LOTR. But instead, you go everywhere EXCEPT those places.By the end, I feel like the War in the North and all of what is done in this game is irrelavent. Like it played no part in the main story, like it added nothing important to it. You have this "right hand" of Saruan, Leader, but I'd think that if he was that important, powerful, and in charge, he would've been mentioned in the movies or books, so adding this enemy seemed pointless.Overall Cons- The gameplay is quite annoying, feeling clunky and based on button mashing.- You can tell the game was built on the purpose of co-op. seeing as how everytime you switch characters, your previous characters gear is changed to a default kind of gear, so you cant set other characters gear unless you are playing as them.You also cannot switch characters as you please, you can only switch between chapters, so you may as well stick to 1 character throughout your entire solo playthrough.- The Orcs all feel the same, like a bunch of brutes, and all take 7-10 hits to kill, EACH. Which makes it frusterating and boring when you're fighting large groups of orcs.- There is no build with any of the characters or their friendship. They are simply 3 travelers who decide to fight the war in the north. There is no character build, no relationship built by the 3, and all of their personalities are the SAME.* Remember how Legolas and Gimili had that funny relationship where they would have a contest of who would kill more orcs in a battle?* Remember how Legolas and Arigorn had a brotherly kind of relationship?* Remember how Arigorn and Gimili had that semi funny moment where Gimili asked Arigorn to toss him over to the bridge at Helms Deep, then said "Don't tell the elf!"?* Remember when Gimili tried to jump across a bridge, that he thought he could make, while a demon was chasing them and when he jumped he almost fell, and Legolas grabbed him to save him and Gimili yelled "not the beard!"?The point is, there was relationships built within the fellowship. Here, there is NONE! No relationship, no friendship build at all! You will end the game not caring at all about ANY of the charaters, except maybe the birds.I was looking for the dwarf to have that battle-thristy personality, the elf to have the wise personality, and the human to have the smart and careful personality. But instead, they all have the same, bland, boring, personality.- Your AI teammates can be quite annoying when they are struggling to revive you or your companion, or when the elf wont heal you when you're 1 hit away from death, or sometimes they will not follow because of 1 single enemy so when you run into another group you'll be left struggling while they sit back with their thumbs up their♥♥♥♥♥trying to kill this 1 single orc archer that they cant hit or kill and once you are down they will take forever to actually reach you since they are now the prime targets of the group of orcs that just murdered you dead.Pros- Its semi-fun to play. I played it solo, so its probably better with co-op.- Its cool getting to meet most of the fellowship before they leave onto their quest.- The leveling up system is pretty nice, like any other RPG game.- Has NG+ so when you start a new playthrough, you don't lose all your gear or your level(s).OverallMaybe my expectations were too high, maybe my standards were too high, but I am very bummed out about how this game turned out and how it ended and the time it took for me to beat it.I recommend to get this game while it is on sale. Maybe its because i'm not a die hard fan of LOTR and I am not an♥♥♥♥♥kisser to the franchise, but to me, this game is a MAJOR disappointment, and not worth $20. I bought it on sale, and I think its a good game if its worth $5 - $10. But this game is NOT all that it is made out to be. Its good, and I reccomend buying it when its on sale. At full price? No.Rating: 4/10

												You can consider yourself lucky if your game hasn't crashed while in-game without a recent save.The game(play) itself is good, the combat is enjoyable and satisfying. But with the bugs and crashes, this game is a dislike from me.The crashes happen at random times, and it's annoying if you haven't recently saved the game, as you'll have to repeat again to the spot where you was when it crashed. When you go down, both AI try and help you, therefor drawing the attention of enemies to the reviver, and getting knocked down while being revived. Terrible AI, they cannot navigate very well.I'm on a low-end video card (Radeon R7 240 2GB) and I can run this on Max settings, including Motion Blur, etc at 1600x1200 with decent fps. The mouse movement is terrible, it's jaggy and I can't spin/turn fast without getting confused.It can get repetitive, but at times you forget it's getting repetitive and continue.Gameplay 7.2/10Stability (Bugs & Crashes) 3/10AI 4/10

												There are times you want to play dungeon crawlers and you look to the online where you will rack and stack yourself at end game with specific builds, items, and do your research and reading.  There are other times you want the simple joy of killing a lot of creatures in a nicely themed area, with a mild bit of challenge, gear and leveling that is easily managed, and played with a friend or two.  This is a wonderful dungeon crawler to unwind to, and the kills are quite visceral (that awesome level of physics and gore that'd you'd expect when a goblin meets an axe wielded by a dwarf in combat).

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2013
												Lord of The Rings War in the North is surprisingly a very competent game. It cannot compete with the AAA titles with hand to hand combat and fantasy element, but it is good enough to be worth at least one play through. From the start it is evident that the developers put great effort into the game to make the environment shine with detail and realism. I was surprised to see such quality of level detail, despite the levels and gameplay being linear. The character models and armor are very detailed as well. Every time you put newer more advanced pieces of armor it reflects on the model of your chosen character. Be it helmets, arm guards, leggings, body armor. All of it. It is also very accurate as far as movie content. Human, Elven, and Dwarven armor and items are what you'd have seen in the Lord of The Rings movies. It is not surprising since the publisher of the game is WB.Positives written above do not come without the negatives. Nearly every level, no matter how spectacular in appearance, has plenty of invisible walls. These invisible barriers can be incredibly frustrating because often you'd find yoruself checking whether you can go in a particular path only to find that it is simply blocked by an invisible wall. As is the case with even the best games on the market, the level design becomes less impressive, and often shows plain lazyness as the player reaches the 2nd half of the game, and eventually the ending. Some areas start looking less detailed and more rushed. Invisible walls become bigger, lighting less consistent, etc. War in The North also has issues with inventory organization. You may eventually gather enough weapons or armor to fill all the alloted slots in the inventory. Some items can be old, other items too high for current level, and there is no way to organize them. Neither manually nor automatically. You cannot select an item and move it in the inventory. Player just ha sto move the cursor over the items to see the stats of each. Another rather inconvenient drawback is in the design of the game for those who want to play single player as opposed to 3 player coop. You have the option to "give" your excess items or items meant for other two classes to your CPU controlled teammates. This is a very poor design gaffe because CPU does not  always equip the item gifted to them, nor compensate the party for the item value. Once it is given to a teammate controlled by the CPU the item is as good as gone. This is not an issue if you play coop with 2 or three players. The other player actually gets the item and can use it. Similarly, when you play coop you can actually exchange items with each other to acquire complete sets of items meant to be worn together. They may be strangely acquired by your CPU partners, and when you switch characters between levels you may see the items that could complete your set on the other player you have picked to play as, but you are not able to either put it in any "shared chest" nor give to another player. Wasted opportunity.Combat is very satisfying and as the character levels up you have a wide choice of upgrades and moves and magic spells to pick from. The upgrade tree is very similar to that of Borderlands games in which you have three columns of skills which you invest points in to unlock the most powerful ones on the bottom. Once again, when you play single player you control your own player's upgrades, but the CPU manages them automatically and utilizes them in hit and miss fashion. Sometimes you'll see the Lore Master (Elf lady) use some of her very helpful spells often, other times you won't. Thankfully you can switch to another character midgame to experience their gameplay style. Whatever you upgrade them with and equipment you give them will be present again if you select them in the future, but not when CPU controls them.The plot and the story is ok. It is not very impressive, but should be interesting to any fan of Tolkien universe or the Peter Jackson movies. The events take place at the same time as the Lord of The Rings three books. You encounter some characters mentioned in the books, get to visit iconic locations such as Lorien and get to talk to most of the main characters of LOTR. The cutscenes are very well animated, most of the time. Some cutscenes are just cheap fill ins where characters just stand there. Characters are voiced by quality voice acting, but unfortunately the same voice actors are recylced for many characters which feels very cheap. The main antagonist of the story does not impress too much because not much of their background or motivations are reveled to the player.Thankfully and to benefit of those who just want to kill some orcs, goblins, urukhai, and whatever there is a survival mode available and at least 3 maps to play it on. You basically fight many waves of enemies. Pretty fun. After the main campaign is complete you are able to replay the game on Hero mode. This is actually pretty good because you can save up the "Gifts" that big characters give you upon completing their side quests. If you save the Gift for the Hero mode you will not get under powered items but instead get to choose a gift from high level items which goes all the way to level 40 or 50. Also replaying is fun if you play as one of other two characters. Each of them is fun to play because of pretty unique abilities and moves.

												An hack & slash Action RPG set in Middle Earth that boasts a fun and visceral combat experience whilst also catering to loot collecting and gearing up that so many of us like. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												MOST UNFAIR REVIEW EVER!And the developper suffered from it. Sure there are "better" coop experience out there, but that's not a reason to give this game a mediocre review. >:( I hate that type of review approach. I played all the coop games, and I would have enjoy the hell out of this one if I hadn't trusted the reviews. My bad. But the game is great! It starts in a tavern! The combat system works so well you can really see and understand everything that is going on, hitting feels good and you don't want to get hit either so difficulty is well balanced. Bringing a Troll down is always satisfying. Characters looks good, graphics are veeeery polished (glittering snow and it just feels cold!) I found the cinematic storytelling much more polished and less awkward than Mass Effect and Skyrim combined. We were 3 friends playing in LAN and it was 8 hours straight, forget to eat style of gaming event. I wouldn't pay 59$ for it  but not it's a very high value product IMHO. Not astoundingly great but just so so good, hits the right points. The UI is fast and simple, you very rarely get overencumbered, interaction between players is a lot of fun, you can really support one another in the heat of the action. The backgrounds are often breath taking honnestly, we just sat there admiring the view while smoking a joint. There is a lot of meat on that bone so for us it became a coop classic. So the morale is having a tough competition doesn't necessarly make a game bad. Lesson learned.

With only few types of enemies, each one similar to nother, with bad pace, poorly hit points systems (you must hit an enemy like 5 times before you are able to do  critical hit, but he hits you and if you dodge - you loose streak, if you parry - you lose streak, if you get hit - you know). content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												  Where to start with this one? firstly it is worth mentioning I played through middle earth: shadow of mordor before playing this so I understood I would be taking a step back.    Turret sessions were somewhat fun with hordes of enemies charging you however there is a quite a few problems which would keep me from buying this game again.   First issue is the revive system, in theory its a pretty good system and the female elf wizard character does this very well when controlled by the pc however the dwarf is just useless, his only purpose is to be a damage sponge and even then he fails at that at constantly needing revived.  Trying to keep the rest revived is a pain and I would love to just let the dwarf die because his only function on some levels is to crouch and walk into a wall while I struggle to fight off enemies and revive the usefull member of the team.   Controls some time do not work in combat and even though a skill is ready to deploy it will not even though I'm mashing on the button for it.   The characters are all there but not the greatest representation of them and in combat the frusteration continues.   As in, why does a kick from an orc deal the same damage as a 9 foot tall boss bringing down his sword on you?   Combat usually is pethedic even compared to other hack and slash at the time and definitely of today.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												It has some issues with online connectivity, has an always on voice chat in multiplayer, is a bit buggy, has some issues with getting the proper resolution and over all it is a less than perfect port. However, if you can see past these issues it is a very enjoyable and easy to pick up action RPG that should satisfy fans of the Lord of the Rings and/or action games. It is somewhat reminiscient of the classic "Two Towers" and "Return of the King" LOTR movie tie-in games of the GameCube era, however it is significantly different in some respects (the player now has full control over the camera and there are now town areas like Bree in which players can buy and sell items and get repairs). The game is set up to work with an Xbox 360 controller with no configuration needed, so I recommend you use one for the optimal experience.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												Definitely worth a try.I think the expectations have doomed War in the North. Since it's Lord of the Rings title, players and Middle-Earth fans alike anticipated something grand, a game that will finally maximize the potential of LotR in a video game. It didn't happen to the extent everyone expected. Yet it doesn't mean War in the North is an inferior product. Far from it.  You play as one of three available characters - a Ranger, Dwarven fighter and Elven mage. Each have three main skills at their disposal and a handful of minor ones. Even though the trio is a bit bland, they are likeable. The story runs simultanously to the Frodo's quest, which is a nice touch - your actions feel relevant as your party contribute to the greater cause.The gameplay features a lot of hacking, slashing, shooting and looting. You face the horde of goblins, orcs and trolls under the command of one evil Agandaur, who is neatly tailored as a villan. War in the North offers an abundance of loot - here I would like to mention that the equipment in this game is superbly designed. The details on weapons and armor are fantastic, the overall feel of the equipment you find or buy fits the world perfectly, which is a nod to the coherent Tolkien universe and at the same time a welcome break from all the overdone, tasteless and improper design in most of the modern RPGs (a sexy female warrior with armor covering only her breast and groin area? Yes, practical indeed). On your travels you will visit locations and meet characters well-known from the books and movies (Ian McKellen voices Gandalf).The game's length is reasonable, around 10 hours for a playthrough, and the replay value is here. War in the North is best enjoyed while playing with your frineds in a co-op mode. It's essantially the same campaign as the single player, but obviously more challanging as the opponents grow in strength with each additional player. Recommended. I approached War in the North without any expectations and was pleasantly surprised by the overall quality - it's not one of the best games you will ever play, but it's certainly enjoyable.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												There are times you want to play dungeon crawlers and you look to the online where you will rack and stack yourself at end game with specific builds, items, and do your research and reading.  There are other times you want the simple joy of killing a lot of creatures in a nicely themed area, with a mild bit of challenge, gear and leveling that is easily managed, and played with a friend or two.  This is a wonderful dungeon crawler to unwind to, and the kills are quite visceral (that awesome level of physics and gore that'd you'd expect when a goblin meets an axe wielded by a dwarf in combat).

content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												MOST UNFAIR REVIEW EVER!And the developper suffered from it. Sure there are "better" coop experience out there, but that's not a reason to give this game a mediocre review. >:( I hate that type of review approach. I played all the coop games, and I would have enjoy the hell out of this one if I hadn't trusted the reviews. My bad. But the game is great! It starts in a tavern! The combat system works so well you can really see and understand everything that is going on, hitting feels good and you don't want to get hit either so difficulty is well balanced. Bringing a Troll down is always satisfying. Characters looks good, graphics are veeeery polished (glittering snow and it just feels cold!) I found the cinematic storytelling much more polished and less awkward than Mass Effect and Skyrim combined. We were 3 friends playing in LAN and it was 8 hours straight, forget to eat style of gaming event. I wouldn't pay 59$ for it  but not it's a very high value product IMHO. Not astoundingly great but just so so good, hits the right points. The UI is fast and simple, you very rarely get overencumbered, interaction between players is a lot of fun, you can really support one another in the heat of the action. The backgrounds are often breath taking honnestly, we just sat there admiring the view while smoking a joint. There is a lot of meat on that bone so for us it became a coop classic. So the morale is having a tough competition doesn't necessarly make a game bad. Lesson learned.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												Definitely worth a try.I think the expectations have doomed War in the North. Since it's Lord of the Rings title, players and Middle-Earth fans alike anticipated something grand, a game that will finally maximize the potential of LotR in a video game. It didn't happen to the extent everyone expected. Yet it doesn't mean War in the North is an inferior product. Far from it.  You play as one of three available characters - a Ranger, Dwarven fighter and Elven mage. Each have three main skills at their disposal and a handful of minor ones. Even though the trio is a bit bland, they are likeable. The story runs simultanously to the Frodo's quest, which is a nice touch - your actions feel relevant as your party contribute to the greater cause.The gameplay features a lot of hacking, slashing, shooting and looting. You face the horde of goblins, orcs and trolls under the command of one evil Agandaur, who is neatly tailored as a villan. War in the North offers an abundance of loot - here I would like to mention that the equipment in this game is superbly designed. The details on weapons and armor are fantastic, the overall feel of the equipment you find or buy fits the world perfectly, which is a nod to the coherent Tolkien universe and at the same time a welcome break from all the overdone, tasteless and improper design in most of the modern RPGs (a sexy female warrior with armor covering only her breast and groin area? Yes, practical indeed). On your travels you will visit locations and meet characters well-known from the books and movies (Ian McKellen voices Gandalf).The game's length is reasonable, around 10 hours for a playthrough, and the replay value is here. War in the North is best enjoyed while playing with your frineds in a co-op mode. It's essantially the same campaign as the single player, but obviously more challanging as the opponents grow in strength with each additional player. Recommended. I approached War in the North without any expectations and was pleasantly surprised by the overall quality - it's not one of the best games you will ever play, but it's certainly enjoyable.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												Experience has usually left me very cautious whenever I see a licensed videogame, particularly when it’s tied in to a film franchise. It seems that virtually every blockbuster in the past 20 years has had an awful accompanying game aimed at cashing in on the hype surrounding the name. I’ve usually felt differently about the Lord of the Rings games because they’ve been pretty good (the tie-ins on the original Xbox were actually pretty great) so I approached this one with rather less cynicism than I’d usually reserve.It’s immediately obvious that this isn’t a high quality, high budget title. The cast impersonators are the first clue and every member of the original cast that appears in the game has an actor that sounds not-quite like what we’re used to hearing. The crude visuals, basic soundtrack and the sense that they’ve hired one voice actor to cover every other NPC were a little disappointing, though not enough to be off-putting.So, yet another 3rd person hack ‘n’ slash, this one with the most basic of plots; “that guy is Sauron’s mate, let’s kill him”. Obviously, being a mate of Sauron he’s quite powerful and has many orcs between him and your party, so you’ve got to kill them off first. The plot is as simple as that. On the way you encounter some of the characters shown in the films, as well as some only mentioned in the books, (minor spoilers, though it’s not like the story here is that important!)  such as Gwaihir, Elladan and Elrohir, Radagast the Brown and Halbarad the Ranger.Levels are very simple, with three or four stages to each level and a peaceful base every few levels where you can return to repair, buy and sell items and turn in quests at occasional checkpoints. You won’t spend very long there though; the main part of the game is either chopping up orcs or running towards the next lot of orcs to chop up.Gameplay is very repetitive and, though the combat is very functional, it gets quite dull as you go from one stage to the next doing the same bloody thing over and over. Combat is quite a standard affair, with standard fast and heavy attacks melee attacks, a ranged attack and the options to block and dodge. The controls are functional and work well enough, but everything feels quite floaty and a little detached. Each character has unique abilities that can be unlocked and upgraded as the character levels up, most of which are pretty cool to execute. The problem is in how repetitive it becomes as you take on endless hordes of a very unvaried enemy. I often compare these types of games to God of War, but there’s a reason for that; in those games, there are dozens of various attack types and there’s a huge variety of enemy types, all of which require different tactics to combat. In this case, War in The North has 4 basic enemy types – a melee guy, a ranged guy, a sorcerer and a troll. Sure, there are technically more, with goblins, Uruk Hai and so on, but all they really are is the same thing with better stats – which doesn’t mean anything as they are only encountered later in the game when your own stats have also grown massively. This effectively means that you’re fighting the same group of things in a sequence of different rooms for the entire campaign, broken up by the occasional mediocre boss battle and combat is broken down to a sequence of dodge, attack, dodge, special attack for the entire campaign. Not exactly Ride to Hell, but hardly a prize winning game either.Visually the game plays it safe, using the same design aesthetic as in the films, although without any of the grand scenery or set pieces that I loved about the trilogy. The settings are familiar and just a little bland, but it does the job. It’s in the graphics that the game shows its limitations, especially in the resolution and framerate. This game looks like a last-gen console port and even running at 1080p it doesn’t look like it’s in HD. Framerate is similar, even though FRAPS showed it running at a solid 60fps it certainly didn’t look like anything approaching that, in fact it felt like 20. I don’t know why everything looked so poor, or why the framerate randomly dropped to 2fps for a few seconds at random, or why the last level is so glitched you have to reinstall 2 year old drivers for your GPU to run the sodding thing, but it’s very poor form and quite infuriating. That these issues haven’t been patched, despite the forums being flooded with various technical issues, is pretty disgraceful.War in the North is one of those licensed games that get a recommendation because it’s “good enough”. If, like me, you’re a fan of The Lord of the Rings, you’ll probably enjoy going toe-to-toe with a horde of orcs and just being in Middle Earth. The game almost loses my recommendation due to the technical issues and game breaking bugs and if you don’t want to♥♥♥♥♥♥about fixing it yourself then I’d advise you to steer well clear. If you’re fine with that, it’s a pretty decent distraction for a few hours.My score:6/10It’s a good enough game; quite repetitive, and pretty average combat, but it’s a good amount of fun carving through a mass of orcs.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												It has some issues with online connectivity, has an always on voice chat in multiplayer, is a bit buggy, has some issues with getting the proper resolution and over all it is a less than perfect port. However, if you can see past these issues it is a very enjoyable and easy to pick up action RPG that should satisfy fans of the Lord of the Rings and/or action games. It is somewhat reminiscient of the classic "Two Towers" and "Return of the King" LOTR movie tie-in games of the GameCube era, however it is significantly different in some respects (the player now has full control over the camera and there are now town areas like Bree in which players can buy and sell items and get repairs). The game is set up to work with an Xbox 360 controller with no configuration needed, so I recommend you use one for the optimal experience.

Posted: August 4, 2016
												   This is one of the CRASHIEST games I have ever played. The gameplay is not incredibly outstanding but its fun, until it CRASHES. The story is almost compleately unrelated to the movies or books (which I consider a good thing since most people have seen the movies or read the books) and is therefore mostly original yet still feels like lord of the rings, so its entertaining despite being brokeden up by regular CRASHES. The levels look like they might be fun to explore, at least once with each character, if I wasn't in a hurry to make it to the next save point before the inevitable CRASH. Its fun to walk around framiliar locations and talk to characters from the original story (books/movies) aften learning new things I didn't know before (that may or may not be canon), that is until... you guesed it: a CRASH.    Overall I am not dissapointed with my perchase, but I got it on sale for $4.99 or something and can not recomend it unless it is on sale (or they fix the crash issue).

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Players looking for a fun role-playing game should definitely consider this.The combat is very hack-and-slashy, but I often find myself utilizing features such as blocks and interrupts which I hardly ever touch in other games. Large enemies such as trolls require me to use the combat roll to get out of the way, and I actually have to ration my health potions. The game does have some combat abilities (such as power hits that are on a cooldown), but I personally don't use them very much.The companion AI is very well done. I've noticed one companion position herself so that her spells benefit both me and the other AI, instead of just spamming her abilities off in a corner somewhere. The armor system in the game is relatively interesting. I find myself actually comparing stats on armor and looking for gems to boost my armor's base stats. I also have to be careful with my funds so I can afford good armor upgrades when I find them on shopkeepers.The game IS linear. At times, I have felt an almost on-rails feeling, but other times it's surprisingly open. The game has a lot of hidden chests and caches that encourage exploring every corner of the map. The items from these caches are typically very useful.The game has many side-quests that are typically optional. You may revisit quest hubs in the world to complete these side quests at your leisure.I'm not a fan of the Lord of the Rings, but even I got into the story. The dialogue has a very nice RPG feel to it, and the voice acting is incredible.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												A seperate story that is connected to the events that take place in the Lord of the rings trilogy. You are able to play three different characters. A human ranger, a dwarf champion and a elven wizard. Archetypes from the realm of middle earth and as a party you and your companions embark on a quest to aid the fight against evil in the form of an avatar of Sauron. This is a very engaging story and gameplay that requires commitment to roleplay, your character and your companions. You will be able to play for yourself or with 1 or 2 friends, when finding your way through hordes of goblins, orcs and trolls.Three words would describe why this game is great. Story, atmosphere and gameplay. The only thing that really concerns me is the inability to disable ingame voice chat. There is a workaround for it, but it should be implemented as an on/off option in game settings.PRLU SCORE: 7/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												If you get past the fact that the coding for this game is utter♥♥♥♥♥♥ multiplayer is unstable (as well as the rest of the game) and the horrible attempt at a built in mic chat (that you can't turn off) it's pretty damn good. The textures in this game are really spectacular, the detail to everything from dust on your clothes, notched weapons, echo in the game chat while you're in a cave. The combat is simple but every kill feels rewarding. As you run through orcs and goblins drenched in their blood you can't help but to feel some adrenaline. The story, being set in Middle Earth, is just what you'd expect from the universe of Tolkien. The established locations like Bree and Imladris are nice to look at but the never before seen areas add to immense size of Middle Earth. If you get this game expect to be frustrated by the♥♥♥♥♥♥poor coding but know that you won't easily get bored.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												Well where to begin here. Big LOTR Fan here which is why i got this title at some point. However the lore comes pretty short. The voices of the three heroes are terrible and so is the dialogue. Your Ranger is not dark and mysterious but a crybaby, your elf is the typical nice healing priest of WoW and your dwarf is lacking the typical attitude you would expect from him. Now the place where this story takes place is quite interesting because it is happening at the same time of the movies but you didnt really hear from the northern front at all. But this is the only positive story aspect. Besides that you meet some famous characters like the fellowship and many more. But again: Terrible voices.The combat evolves around basic Hack'n'Slash completed by mostly useless active abilities. It still feels good for quite some time and the combos are somewhat rewarding. Yet it gets dull especially when you want to complete all the difficulties. Speaking about difficulties. There were no other players around for me to play with so i soloed the content and by increasing the difficulty it got more easy with "legendary" being the easiest AND fastest playthrough. Now whats the most positive thing about this game? By far the lootvariety! You get weapons, shields and armour from all the different nations of middle earth, good and evil. You just want to find all the stuff there is and you want to find an orc shield to your orc sword just to look cool etc. BUT killing animations again are a bumper. Axe, sword or mace it doesnt matter you will have the same animation which can look a bit weird at times. If you have one or better two buddies to tag along I imagine this game to be a lot of fun but alone it gets rather boring. Still some LOTR fans might get satisfied by all the familiar places you visit and people to talk to.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												Tolkien and Peter Jackson fans alike should enjoy this game.  The game characters bear a remarkable resemblance to Peter Jackson's film characters. My PC game however was prone to crashing and at one stage I lost my save game, although it was luckily early in the piece. I'll be ammending this review if it happens again as I'm now at L14.Crashes aside, I enjoyed the simple combat system - essentially mashing the mouse button(s) whilst maneuvering and choosing when to invoke special actions. It reminded me of the combat in the Batman game series. Plus you get to sit back and watch your avatar hack, slash and behead Orcs and Goblins in various interesting ways. I think there's an option to tone down the gore but seriously, hacking Orcs to bits is a major theme in the books and films. There were numerous cut-scenes which made it feel like the game was one big interactive movie. The background scenery and music was well done, as were the character voice-overs. Then there were the standard RPG features: quests, side quests, secret caches of weapons, equipment upgrades, buy/sell at vendors, NPC interactions, choices to make, skill trees and character builds etc. All the psychological stuff to keep one interested.I'm playing solo with 2 other AI characters and they do a pretty good job at staying alive, attacking enemies and at times reviving me. So hats off to the developers for not creating dumb AIs. These AIs handle their own skill tree and attribute upgrades plus they equip the best gear they find automatically.  Another special mention goes to the dialog with Gandalf (I think) where you ask the question all LoTR fans ponder: why not send in Frodo on the back of an eagle to begin with?  Play the game to find the answer :-)I've enjoyed this game so far, but it is with a certain fear that I will lose my save game.  Nevertheless for $10 AUD it has been well worth it. Until I lose my save, then I will be cursing.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												This game is a very generic-feeling beat 'em up. I played through the game with a friend quite some time ago and we found ourselves trudging through the game for completion's sake more than anything. We stopped after one play through, unable to muster the gumption needed to play through the campaign a second time on new game +.The few characters you have to choose from are all rather boring archetypes. You gain new class abilities over time that let you perform special moves, but nothing here seems particularly inspired.There was also pretty severe bug on a couple of the levels that was causing the to become exceptionally bright, almost to the point of the screen being a blinding white color. And sometimes it would rapidly blink in and out of this mode. I'm not sure if it was some intense bloom effect bug, or what it was, but it nearly made those levels unplayable.The game was bland and over all boring. It was certainly not for me, so I cannot recommend it to others, however if beat 'em ups are your thing then perhaps you will still find something here worthwhile.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												When I recieved this game I was hecka excited. I had finished this game on my friend's Xbox 360 only months before and enjoyed playing it with him in Co-op mode. After finshing this game on my PC I realised how boring and repetitive the game really was. The game is not a free-roaming or exploring type. It restricts you to the very bone with it's story levels, which are the only things that you can actually do in this game. Sure, myself being a huge Tolkien fan should enjoy this game a lot, but the lore is barely touched on. There are refrencing to the movies and books but no huge give away of what the game/story is actually about to all new-comers. If your looking for a Middle-Earth game with heaps of lore and factual basings on Tolkien's work, please, please buy Shadow of Mordor. I did so on my Xbox One, and have to say, it's probably one of my favourite games of all time.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2012
												Alright War in the North has been out for roughly 2.5 years. It isn't the greatest rpg you can get but if you are brand new it isn't a terrible place to start. The levels are linear, skill system fairly simple and loot tends to be on the order of straight upgrade. Enemies and overall plot are not engaging and outsided of some flashy kill moves combat isn't stellar. This isn't a bad game it is just very 'meh' in comparison to something like The Elder Scrolls. Pick this up on the cheap or just let it pass by.

												An average co-op experience that is haunted by technical problems, the major one being an always activated steam voice chat when playing with other people. This makes it unbearable to play if you're using skype or other voice chats in the background, because of the constant echo this creates. Apart from this, the game crashed reliably after an hour or so in each session.The gameplay itself is somewhat tedious, with damage-sponge bosses and abilities that don't differ much from your normal attacks.Unless you have no other co-op game at hand, I can't recommend this game.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												Love the LOTR world. Gameplay is pretty good. But I am writing this review to say, there are serious bugs with the Steam title...BEWARE.And before I go further, Steam won't refund the money spent to purchase this title, because I went (just) over the two hour refund period. Thankfully, it was purchased during the big summer sale. But it does give me concern making any more Steam purchases. The main issue is that the game crashes and returns to the Windows (7 64-bit) desktop if any of the Equipment or Skills keyboard shortcuts are pressed. So if I want to spend my skill points and press the K key (or whatever it is), the game crashes and goes away completeyly. The game restarts fine, but nothing seems to fix the crash. I have even reset my Steam cache with steam://flushconfig without any success.So fun game, but beware. Try the other action keys before your two hours are up.

												Story is re-tarded, dialogue is painful, nine tenths of the conversation is absolutely useless and wouldn't be in a game in any other setting.This is a game for passing fans of the Lord of the Rings movies who have no idea that there are books out there. If you've sene the movies more than once, nothing in this game will make any sense. If you've read the books more than once, you'll be shouting at Aragorn, Gandalf, Elrond, etc every every time they're on-screen because they make absolutely no attempt to make them anything like the characters in the book or the movie.This is a mediocre hack-and-slash that has the great fortune of being named "Lord of the Rings." Otherwise, it wouldn't have sold many copies.The fight mechanics are boring, the archery is clumsy, and the equipment treadmill is just tiring. Srsly? I'm going to go to Rivendell, and the elf at the smithy is going to charge me for repairs?Most of the loot you'll get in this game is arrows or money, both of which the game would have been much better off without. There is so much ammunition hidden in jars that it's just stupid to make me keep track of it at all. In the first three missions (probably four or five hours of game time), I've run out of arrows once.But really, there's not much point to ever firing an arrow. There's apparently a headshot mechanic, but in order to score a headshot, you still have to shoot a big orc in the head four or five times to reduce his HP.This game is a solid D. If it wasn't a Lord of the Rings game, it would be a D+. But it is, so it's absolutely bursting with references to lore and history that play absolutely no part in the story whatsoever. But you can't be certain what's going to be important or might trigger something later on, so you click through every single dialogue.What a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ Do not bother.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I got hold of this game in the one of the recent humblebundles. The game wasn't so bad in the beginning. Co-op is realy fun if you grab two friends and discover the world together. The item and skill/spell system is similar to many other RPGs nothing special  here.The quests are shallow and very easily completed (bring me A, find and rescue B, talk to C and tell her that i love her... bleh)Levels are tube-like and will not even alter in the slightest ways if you replay them.On easy/norm your two companions will almost everytime revive you from the "dead" if you fall,  making  it impossible to die ere. On heroic/legendary they will almost always die themselves, i'd recommend you to  play  with friends  here.Stil, the game seems technically unfinished for some reasons- You can't turn off the ingame voice manually, so when you're used  to play  with teamspeak, vent or skype you have to turn this  off instead of the ingame voice which btw has a  horrible delay- About half of the PC users experience heavy  graphic problems. Minor ones in level 2 and to a point unplayable ones in level 8. Either your game will shut down or sometimes you end up in blue screen. I only got past this level by drawing my bow, zooming in and look on the ground. This prevented me from seeing the graphic bugs all over  and  my game from shutting down every 15 seconds - this issue has been out there from the release of this game. It has not gotten  any updates so far and i doubt it will ever. That's a cruel statement of the developers. They don't even care.All in all i had a couple of great hours, but i was glad when i finally got my 46th achievement, closed the game, clicked on "delete local content" and will never play this  game again.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												The co-op element of this game cannot be emphasized enough:  this is inherently a co-op game.  I played single-player and so my comments are reflective of that experience.The game includes three characters:  a dwarven tank, and human ranger who can choose between melee and ranged DPS, and a support/ranged DPS mage.  The three characters have decidedly different roles in combat and the fundamentals of the combat system are good, but other design flaws quickly mask those positives.Gameplay is episodic, with small, linear maps broken up with portals back to town.  Each character has a small number of actions, making combat somewhat repetitive.  Town is a dull place with a few vendors, the interface for which is clumsy and inefficient.  Managing and building your character and gear is more tedious than rewarding.The main flaw in the game is that you are tighlty tied to a single character.  Rather than giving the player the power to smoothly transfer control between characters on-the-fly (which I would think would be a very easy, obvious feature they should have included), you must play as a specific character for the entirety of a level while the other two are controlled by AI.  You cannot even equip gear on a character other than the one you are currently controlling.I admit I did not spend a lot of time in this game, maybe it would have gotten better as the game progressed, but to be fair I quit playing the game because I did not enjoy it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												As a casual Lord of the Rings fan, I found this game to be rather on the nose.  I'm going to list the good and the bad that I've encountered so far in a list of bullet points and then expand on them later so that it doesn't get too TL;DR.GOOD:*  Fun action gameplay*  Interestingly well done facial models based off the actors from the movies - (though not mocapped or anything)*  Decent amount of gameplay hoursBAD:*  Terrible console port*  No way to differentiate LAN from internet multiplayer (it does work with LAN, just doesn't give any network information)*  Painful 'story' attempting to garner interest from the fanboys*  Ugly, ugly graphics*  Unimmersive sound*  No way to toggle off voice chatThis game hurts to play.  It's an unpolished and lazy attempt to cash in on the success of the movie releases.  You play one of a party of 3 characters that spend the entire game one or two steps away from the ringbearers. One of the first areas is Bree, where you meet up with Aragorn who's waiting on Gandalf and Frodo.  After you finish the quest, they've made their way through the town.  We all know how the storyline of the novels runs and the constant "Oh, you just missed the really cool characters but you helped them on their journey... I promise" gets boring quickly.It is a poor console port.  The engine has not aged well, and it shows.  Despite the beautiful lands in LotR, the brown filter that is more commonly seen in FPSs makes the graphics look even worse than they actually are.  I am not someone that expects Crysis-like graphics in every video game, but this is painfully dated.  There is no way to change any networking settings (not that I expected them to be there) and this is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥on a PC release.  You can't specify whether to use LAN or WAN though it does appear to function on both.  There is no way to turn off the voice chat, and it is SO laggy.  Playing with my partner over LAN in the next room had a good 3000~ms latency on the VoiP.I love RPGs, I love hack n slashers, and I quite enjoy the LotR story.  I can put up with bad writing if the gameplay is fun, and vice versa.  I've got countless hours wasted in these sorts of games.  Unfortunately, there isn't much substance to hold any interest in this game whatsoever, and completely unimmersive.TL;DR.  Crap LotR action RPG that I'm glad I got in a Humble Bundle instead of paying full price.  Not even whacky co-op shenanigans could make this fun.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Gameplay itself is actually quite fun in co-op and the story is interesting (if not a little cliched), especially if you're a Tolkien fan. That said, there's several annoying bugs to be wary of. The game forces you to use Steam Voice in co-op, which is counter-intuitive in the likely scenario that you're already using a better form of voice communication. The game crashes frequently in graphically intensive situations, and this is a commonly reported issue for AMD card owners with post-HD5k era GPUs. The aggregate score of 66 seems fitting, as those looking for this type of game should enjoy it if they're willing to tolerate its issues. Get it when it's on sale.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												Everything about this game screams mediocre.  I'll break each aspect of the game down below:Graphics - stuttering and muddy.  Everything is in dark earth tones for the most party and tends to becomes a black/brown blur.  Sound/music - For the most part this is the best part of the game, or at least the part that sucks the leastUI/Mechanics - The UI is horrible.  There's just no way to say it more clearly.  It is easily one of the worst parts of this game.  The levelling and talent trees are lackluster, the HUD during gameplay is incomprehensible, and the combat is sloppy.  Story - Yes, it's set in Middle-Earth, and they have gotten a lot of the names of people/places directly from the lore, but that doesn't make the story actually interesting.  Essentially, you are a small band of adventurers (a man, an elf and a dwarf, super original) that need to distract Sauron's forces from the ringbearer during the time of the LOTR trilogy.  Really, it's just a hack and slash-fest that is completely uninspired and boring.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Lord of the Rings: War in the North is a hack-and-slash game. That's... it.You control one of three characters with no personality or character development trying to chain as many finishers as possible, until you unlock Farin's Explosive Arrow and trivialize the game. Even the only vaguely challenging sections, which are the optional horde challenge maps. Along the way you will meet other fan-favorite characters such as the Fellowship, but then you will discover they have about as much relevance to you as this game does to Tolkein's legendarium. Sorry, Lord of the Rings fans.Your mission is to go kill the leader of Sauron's forces in the North, Agandaur. He is pathetically easy, but it's worth it (?) to see the CGI animation that probably ate up 70% of the budget for this game.The only way this game becomes decent is if you somehow game one, preferably two, friends into playing it with you. The time commitment shouldn't be that bad because the game is both easy and short. Playing with friends helps disguise some of the game's more egregious single-player faults, such as an incredibly limited inventory system, no ability to switch between characters on the fly (this requires you to completely reload the game), and the fact that some parts of the game are straight-up inaccessible without two or more players.Fortunately the game isn't super glitchy (there are some glitches but reloading usually fixes it) or unplayable, and you'll probably unlock 95% of the achievements without even trying.Sadly, War in the North failed to live up to any of its promise. It's not a HORRIBLE game by any means, but there are way better uses of your time.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												Performance of the game:This game is a buggy mess.  I powered through a very bad bug in chapter 2 of the game that would have it randomly crash, took about 3 hours to pass a single section that should of took about 20 minutes, twice crashing seconds before triggering the saving in the game.  Most of the times it crashes it doesn't crash to desktop it blue screens my computer most of the time not giving a reason just something failed and the memory address of all “0”s and an x or 5 thrown in.  I have made it through chapter 7 with it crashing about every half hour and now in chapter 8 of the game I found another section that will crash every few minutes similar to chapter 2 of the game.  Now I have to quit.  The actual review of the game (based on when it is not crashing)one of the first things you get is a bird friend and you hit the 4 button to call for his aid.  Well the Elf character has a power that has you block and hit 4 (holding CTRL then hit 4).  even though the 4 icon has changed from the bird logo to a different logo, BOTH powers are used; the bird and area heal.  I wasted a lot of bird power trying to keep the other 2 friends alive.  Defense missions are the worst part, it goes fine until the enemy brings in the giant troll and he walk past you not caring that you are attacking him and then kills the thing you are protecting in 15 seconds.  I personally am more of a dodger power and like to dodge and not much blocking, I would of liked a double dodge (I only played the elf so I do not know if the other characters have a double dodge).  After facing a double sword enemy who is stabbing you so much that you can not dodge, I have learned to block against them just be for they attack and then attack them back.  Dialog was interesting even had a few points that you could try to tell some one that we are just passing through this very remote area to get to grandma's house (not exactly G ma’s house, but you are lieing about what you are doing so I thought it appropriate) and the NPC has non of that, but a very interesting choice to tell them.  Also there is a lot of repeat dialog choices that are represented as new choices.  Example: someone tells you of a castle; new option of the castle in dialog choices, npc just repeats the thing that brought up the new choice.  Combat was fun and interesting, slowly adding in new enemies over the 6 chapter's I played.  I would of loved to see how the ending turned out and if they kept adding new enemies through the end, but sadly the bugs and crashing my computer is enough to make me stop.

I powered through a very bad bug in chapter 2 of the game that would have it randomly crash, took about 3 hours to pass a single section that should of took about 20 minutes, twice crashing seconds before triggering the saving in the game.  Most of the times it crashes it doesn't crash to desktop it blue screens my computer most of the time not giving a reason just something failed and the memory address of all “0”s and an x or 5 thrown in.  I have made it through chapter 7 with it crashing about every half hour and now in chapter 8 of the game I found another section that will crash every few minutes similar to chapter 2 of the game.  Now I have to quit.  The actual review of the game (based on when it is not crashing)one of the first things you get is a bird friend and you hit the 4 button to call for his aid.  Well the Elf character has a power that has you block and hit 4 (holding CTRL then hit 4).  even though the 4 icon has changed from the bird logo to a different logo, BOTH powers are used; the bird and area heal.  I wasted a lot of bird power trying to keep the other 2 friends alive.  Defense missions are the worst part, it goes fine until the enemy brings in the giant troll and he walk past you not caring that you are attacking him and then kills the thing you are protecting in 15 seconds.  I personally am more of a dodger power and like to dodge and not much blocking, I would of liked a double dodge (I only played the elf so I do not know if the other characters have a double dodge).  After facing a double sword enemy who is stabbing you so much that you can not dodge, I have learned to block against them just be for they attack and then attack them back.  Dialog was interesting even had a few points that you could try to tell some one that we are just passing through this very remote area to get to grandma's house (not exactly G ma’s house, but you are lieing about what you are doing so I thought it appropriate) and the NPC has non of that, but a very interesting choice to tell them.  Also there is a lot of repeat dialog choices that are represented as new choices.  Example: someone tells you of a castle; new option of the castle in dialog choices, npc just repeats the thing that brought up the new choice.  Combat was fun and interesting, slowly adding in new enemies over the 6 chapter's I played.  I would of loved to see how the ending turned out and if they kept adding new enemies through the end, but sadly the bugs and crashing my computer is enough to make me stop.

												Para todo el que esperaba un remake o continuación de los beat'em up de LOTR para PS2 de este juego, lamento decirles que lo único que va a hacer es decepcionarlos. Lo digo con certeza por que yo era uno de ellos ... Basicamente le agregarón mas features de un RPG, como loot, inventario, etc. O sea es mas como un Diablo en tercera persona, ambientado en tierra media, que un beat'em up viejo y querido digamos. Eso estaría genial si hubiera estado bien hecho, pero la verdad por mas que el juego en si es solido, no agrega nada al genero y la historia es generica en el mejor de los casos. Aparte, como no el juego no se decide por un genero, ninguna de las 2 partes esta bien hecha digamos. Como sera que por mas fanatico de LOTR que soy, no lo pude terminar del embole ...

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												This game has quite a few primordial building blocks of a great game, but it loses it on the details. First, the game looks fairly decent. Graphics could be tuned up a bit (mainly with some textures), but overall, they aren't bad. Gameplay is a mixed bag. The characters move well enough, but there are some annoying collisions that will hang up your heroes, including places that "heroes" should be able to travel through (like stepping up a set of stone stairs from the side instead of moving around to the first step and stepping up that way - or trying to step down off a rock ledge a mere two feet off the ground below). Music is reminiscent of the movie and the sounds and mannerisms of the creatures in the game ring true. The game would be a fun 3-person co-op game, but I only played solo.. which is where some of the problems (and big ones), began to rear their heads.Your character gains XP in the game which allows them to level. This allows you to spend some points in typical RPG stats as well as putting points in skill trees, which allow you access to better killing moves. This is all fine and dandy except for the fact that if you ever switch out to one of the other characters, it resets your skills to default, meaning that you can't play a guy, switch over to another character for the next chapter and expect all of your choices to remain constant. On that point, the same goes for loot. You can share loot with the NPC allies, which they'll use on the mission you're on, but they will strangely have lost some or all of it when you switch over to them. If you opt to not give them anything, they are stuck "helping" you with starter weapons.And enemies and NPC A.I. isn't all that bright. I cursed so many times seeing my healer (whom I didn't want to play), rush into battle swinging her staff at a cave troll and getting two-shotted (of course). Then she cried out, "I am dying!" Yeah, no♥♥♥♥♥♥ Don't get me started on the weirdly placed save spots either. Some are just so far apart that if you wipe, you have to repeat long and tedious chunks of the game.. which is a total buzzkill.I read up online that this game is huge too though, which is sad. Because the combat is pretty fun. There's enough hidden elements and fun gameplay that it kept me entertained. I just wish it was mechanically superior than what it is. I say no to this game. Perhaps a later incarnation will have these odd game mechanics worked out.

												I came here to write a happy review but it will be short and angerd.I realy enjoyed this game, decent hack&slash, decent story, decent graphics. A game great for looting with your best buddys. You can play 3 different classes and races for that. Ranger, Chapion and Lore-master, all having their own skill trees, their own weapons (just the bows and staf), their own special armoring. A little variaton of enemies but passable. Not even a shalow ARPG but fun no matter. Just don't buy it at full price, wait for it to be below normal summ.I would recommend War in the North if only it had not crashed on my 2nd run trough it, at the very last chapter and guess what, it left me with no save files. That's right, it completely deleted my save game files. Afterwards I cheekt forums for answers and the game supposedly does that. When you might ask, when ever it feels like, so my hours spent enyoing War where completely wiped.So, great time with the game, but specifically one little crash made me unlike this avareg but decent work. Because the rights has been sold from SnowblindStudios the game will not be patched and save files will be lost(mark my words). I do not recommend it, let it sit in the cold depths of forgoteness.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												If you read the top reviews for this game, you'll notice the good review, but there is a GOOD reason for the low metascore. The amazing reviews ons team are most likely because the only people who will buy this game are already avid LOTR fans. I however, was not a fan beforehand and will deliver a serious review.Here's a complied list, and at the end of the list I'll let you be the judge of whether or not you wish to dive into this gameIs the story any good?Absolutely, as any RPG you have the freedom to partake in the story or to skip it and get into the action. Talking to the villagers of every town will get you side quests in which you can earn some intense gear.Is the combat any good?Personally, the combat is pretty repetetive, but it does allow for some customizing, much like dragon age.Is there customization?The customization is limited but it IS there, which is better than no customization. Note: You may only customize AFTER starting the game.Diversity?Yes, you're able to pick one of the three heros and go along with it, there's also multiplayer functions so you can bring two friends and each have their own hero.All of these things are good, so why is this a downvote?There is only one bad quality, but you must realize the depth of the how terrible it is to understand why it's a thumbs down.What is wrong with it?The game crashes OFTEN. This game was released on Nov. 1, 2011 which wasn't too long ago. Yet, the game runs like it was made in 2002, with how the graphics are I originally thought this game was made in 2006.My computer is really new, and it is capable of running Bioshock infinite on max settings, yet it cannot run LOTR War in the North for over an hour without crashing. What's more, is that it does not simply crash the game/window/application. It crashes the ENTIRE DESKTOP. THIS IS WHY THE GAME RECIEVED A LOW METASCORE, IT IS INCREDIBLY UNSTABLE. It is borderline unplayable, because up until the undead level, you don't really have any problems with crashing. but the second you get to the undead mobs, the game cannot control it's own software and seeminglye xplodes upon itself. And, because the undead levels are canon, you MUST pass through them. I was lucky because my computer was new, so I had a long grace period before it killed itself, but any run of the mill computer may not be able to handle it at all.All in all, this was a great game, if it wasn't so cancerous to it's own programming, I as a person who is not a die-hard fan of LOTR can honestly say this would have recieved an 85-95 score for what it brings to the table. However, an amazing game CANNOT HAVE A FOUNDATION MADE SUITABLE ONLY FOR GAMES 5 YEARS BEHIND ITS TIME.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												If you get past the fact that the coding for this game is utter♥♥♥♥♥♥ multiplayer is unstable (as well as the rest of the game) and the horrible attempt at a built in mic chat (that you can't turn off) it's pretty damn good. The textures in this game are really spectacular, the detail to everything from dust on your clothes, notched weapons, echo in the game chat while you're in a cave. The combat is simple but every kill feels rewarding. As you run through orcs and goblins drenched in their blood you can't help but to feel some adrenaline. The story, being set in Middle Earth, is just what you'd expect from the universe of Tolkien. The established locations like Bree and Imladris are nice to look at but the never before seen areas add to immense size of Middle Earth. If you get this game expect to be frustrated by the♥♥♥♥♥♥poor coding but know that you won't easily get bored.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Players looking for a fun role-playing game should definitely consider this.The combat is very hack-and-slashy, but I often find myself utilizing features such as blocks and interrupts which I hardly ever touch in other games. Large enemies such as trolls require me to use the combat roll to get out of the way, and I actually have to ration my health potions. The game does have some combat abilities (such as power hits that are on a cooldown), but I personally don't use them very much.The companion AI is very well done. I've noticed one companion position herself so that her spells benefit both me and the other AI, instead of just spamming her abilities off in a corner somewhere. The armor system in the game is relatively interesting. I find myself actually comparing stats on armor and looking for gems to boost my armor's base stats. I also have to be careful with my funds so I can afford good armor upgrades when I find them on shopkeepers.The game IS linear. At times, I have felt an almost on-rails feeling, but other times it's surprisingly open. The game has a lot of hidden chests and caches that encourage exploring every corner of the map. The items from these caches are typically very useful.The game has many side-quests that are typically optional. You may revisit quest hubs in the world to complete these side quests at your leisure.I'm not a fan of the Lord of the Rings, but even I got into the story. The dialogue has a very nice RPG feel to it, and the voice acting is incredible.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												If you read the top reviews for this game, you'll notice the good review, but there is a GOOD reason for the low metascore. The amazing reviews ons team are most likely because the only people who will buy this game are already avid LOTR fans. I however, was not a fan beforehand and will deliver a serious review.Here's a complied list, and at the end of the list I'll let you be the judge of whether or not you wish to dive into this gameIs the story any good?Absolutely, as any RPG you have the freedom to partake in the story or to skip it and get into the action. Talking to the villagers of every town will get you side quests in which you can earn some intense gear.Is the combat any good?Personally, the combat is pretty repetetive, but it does allow for some customizing, much like dragon age.Is there customization?The customization is limited but it IS there, which is better than no customization. Note: You may only customize AFTER starting the game.Diversity?Yes, you're able to pick one of the three heros and go along with it, there's also multiplayer functions so you can bring two friends and each have their own hero.All of these things are good, so why is this a downvote?There is only one bad quality, but you must realize the depth of the how terrible it is to understand why it's a thumbs down.What is wrong with it?The game crashes OFTEN. This game was released on Nov. 1, 2011 which wasn't too long ago. Yet, the game runs like it was made in 2002, with how the graphics are I originally thought this game was made in 2006.My computer is really new, and it is capable of running Bioshock infinite on max settings, yet it cannot run LOTR War in the North for over an hour without crashing. What's more, is that it does not simply crash the game/window/application. It crashes the ENTIRE DESKTOP. THIS IS WHY THE GAME RECIEVED A LOW METASCORE, IT IS INCREDIBLY UNSTABLE. It is borderline unplayable, because up until the undead level, you don't really have any problems with crashing. but the second you get to the undead mobs, the game cannot control it's own software and seeminglye xplodes upon itself. And, because the undead levels are canon, you MUST pass through them. I was lucky because my computer was new, so I had a long grace period before it killed itself, but any run of the mill computer may not be able to handle it at all.All in all, this was a great game, if it wasn't so cancerous to it's own programming, I as a person who is not a die-hard fan of LOTR can honestly say this would have recieved an 85-95 score for what it brings to the table. However, an amazing game CANNOT HAVE A FOUNDATION MADE SUITABLE ONLY FOR GAMES 5 YEARS BEHIND ITS TIME.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17
												Bite Size Review - Lord of the Rings: War in the NorthThe Good:+ The dialoge and lore that characters have and speak to you about+ You can play as one of three unique classes + Story is interesting+ Graphics are on the old side, but still look ok+ Lots of loot+ You get to meet several characters from the film and they actually have a good amount to say and it is interesting+ Gameplay is simple but can still hold upThe Bad:- This is kind of a dealbreaker, I have a modern PC (runs New Doom 2016 on Highest settings etc) and this game slows down and crashes more times than is acceptableThe Verdict:So I just finished playing this game, and I have to say it was fun. You get to see some new places and some familar ones from the movies. You also get to meet and actually have meaningful conversations with characters from the movies and they actually talk a decent amount, it was really interesting to talk to them and learn more about the LotR universe. So I would classify this game as an average action role playing game, with great lore. All good stuff.Unfortunatly this is where I must tell you that this game crashed on me probably every 30 - 40 minutes and slowdowns in certain areas for no reason I could figure out. I just got a new computer recently, it runs the new doom at max settings 60 fps - now granted, I did switch to an AMD graphics card this time around (not Nvidia) so this may have something to do with it, or it may be windows 10, I am not sure. I tried to fix the usual ways I tend to fix these issues with other older games like using compatability modes etc. this but was unsucessful, forcing me to restart the game and just try to force my way through the crashy bits. But yeah, with the technical problems I ran into... even with the fun I had with the game, I can not recommend it. If it did not have these technical issues I could definitely recommend the game though for the lore, I really enjoyed that part of this game a lot. But with it's tachnical issues I will say "buyer beware" and leave it at that.

content:
Posted: February 15
												I've played this game together with a friend. It took us around 15 hours to finish the missions. The game was incredibly enjoyable for as long as it lasted, but 15 minutes of gameplay is not worth the price. The dialogues are a bit stale, as are the faces of the characters. At a certain moment, two brothers come and help you, whose sprites are litterally the same. They're like clones O_o. The hack and slash element of the game and the challenges of defeating strong foes are VERY enjoyable, however. It'd be great if there was a seperate 'open world' part of this game, so that the content would last more than 15 hours. (we were offered to do exactly the same missions on a harder game mode, but that's just meh). If you are looking for a fantasy game that you can play together with 1 or 2 mates, I'd recommend it. Otherwise, it's not worth the cash.

												I first bought this at Gamestop for my 360 to check it out and see if it was any good. I played previous SnowBlind games, but I'm not a Lord of the Rings fan at all. But what I played of the used copy convinced me to pay it forward so to speak. I went back to Gamestop and changed it in for a real copy and paid the exta money. And people will like that also. Not knowing what to do in a game is not fun.The difficulty seems fair. I'm not that great at video games, and found normal a fun, fair challenge.I will soon find out if the xbox 360 controller works for this game. The controller worked fine! Nice.So this is the 2nd time buying this game. Even though I played it twice on the 360. Warrior and Rouge class. Very fun.I played co op with my cousin on Xbox Live. I think we played through the whole game. But I can't remember for sure. Very fun game to play with a friend.It's fun co op or single player! I would give this game a try, It is not a masterpiece. The story pulled me in, even though I'm not a fan, and with the combination of great gameplay equals a great adventure!

												I am kicking myself for leaving this unplayed in the back catalog for so long. Not the best story ever written, but does a better job than "The Hobbit" movies of telling a story related to the events in Lord of the Rings that does not feel shoe horned in and is consequential in and of itself. The combat is easy to pick up but rewards practice and skill with fun executions and bonuses for long hit streaks and good teamwork (specifically, you get and extra bonus for helping a team-mate finish an enemy off). Short version, a must play for Tolkien fans and a decent fun game for everyone else.Quick edit - now I am on my 2nd Legendary playthrough. The difficulty ramps up nicely, and now I am planning how I am going to upgrade my gear over the next several playthroughs. Yes it is still awesome every time I finish an orc and get painted black :D

												THIS REVIEW IS FOR ANYONE HOPING TO PLAY THIS GAME WITH FRIENDS:Simply put: The multiplayer is broken so bad to a state which makes it unplayable.  Here is what I can say with absolute certainty:1: There is no local multiplayer like there was on console. But don't bother buying multiple copies because2: The LAN feature is completley useless. This literally wont work and3: Playing online is extremely extremely volitaleHeres the thing. This game is fun, and youll disconnect once and say "Hey thats ok lets just reconnect" then you wont be able to so youll switch hosts but then your save will be desyncs and youll say "ok well let me just play singleplayer to get our saves resynced then you can host" and your friend will have to wait while you play the same part you just played. Then when your saves are resynced maybe JUST MAYBE switching hosts will get you reconnected. Hurrah! but then 15minutes later you drop the connection again.  This cycle will repeat itself over and over again until you finally get so sickly frustrated that you quit altogether and youll feel like crap because you spent so much time trying to adjust your firewall and port forward, reinstall and modify game files etc. Here's the bottom line:TRY ANY FIX YOU WANT: THERE IS NO RHYME OR REASON TO THE CONNECTION INTEGRITY IN THIS GAMEDon't be fooled by any premonitions about this game. This game is NOT multiplayer, its single player. If you want to play it with friends, buy it on Online for Xbox 360If WB games responds to my support requests adequatley then I will change this review, but I doubt it because theyve got better things to do with my money than fix a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ port of an older game
