number of helpful: 13 of 28 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												The boring adventures of some random, soulless characters which somehow live at the same time as the Lord of the Rings storyline (which I enjoyed a lot). Useless gimmick: Somehow most of the cast of the main storyline know these guys already or at least meet them throughout the game even if there was no mentioning of it in any of the films (nor in the books I guess, but I never read them).It gets even better: The game is quite ugly for a game released in 2011 and has still quite a lot of performance problems in 2013 and if you follow the instructions of the brightness configuration wizard you end up with by far too dark settings. The characters' skill trees are pointless, the combat, especially the ranged, is unrewarding, the combo system is never explained at all, the world is one straight line with invisble walls every two meters from the track where you are supposed to walk and the inventory and shop handling is quite uncomfortable. Even if some of the conversations had an interesting core, they would have driven you to insane laughter before being able to notice, not only because you are constantly talking to giant, English-speaking eagles but because they are prolonged by endless amounts of pointless standard fantasy gibberish. Fun fact: The game even honors the player who servered the most limbs and broke the most destructible items - activities all too familiar to the heroes of Middleearth.The only reason I still played this mediocre game was the fact that I could play it with up to two friends in networked co-op (which is actually my favorite way to play games). After we took about an hour to disable the not-supposed-to-be-disabled, ultra-low-quality, always-on ingame voice chat through using Virtual Audio Cable, we had quite some problems getting into the game lobby at the same time. After trying all possible permutations of who is host and who connects when, we actually found a working setup. Only to notice that the net code is pretty weak and causes a lot of rubber banding and enemy lagging.The good part is, that we didn't pay a lot, because the game was only one of many parts of a Humble Bundle, that we had a lot to laugh about and were able to play in a mixed setup where some of us were playing with gamepads and one with keyboard and mouse.I would only seriously recommend this game to the console peasants for which it was obviously originally made. My recommendation for everyone else: Stay away from this.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2013
												Snowblind studios built it's name on console action RPG's. They haven't wandered from that path. They've left their mark on the gaming industry. Kudos to you Snowblind, this really is a nice gem. War in the North brings a 3 person co-op style of gameplay. The players have a choice between three different characters. Each with three skill trees and a multiple number of abilities. All three characters can either go melee or ranged during combat. Primarily there's two basic defensive moves, block and dodge. There's other abilities that can further defense. The games merits rely on the charming Tolkien lore which only enhances a unique and plausible storyline. Warner Brother's has really done a excellent job with expanding Tolkien's universe in various media outlets. Artwork is amazing, the plain fluid motion of the camera is flawless. Middle-Earth is painted with a darker brush, there's a gritty and grainy feel to the game. My only peeve with the game is that the two hardest difficulty settings aren't unlocked until completion of a play-through.Snowblind studios delivered easily a worthy pickup both on consoles and PC. 8/10

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14
												Snowblind are known for putting out some great arpg's-Baldur's Gate: Dark Alliance. Champions of Norrath: Realms of EverQuest, and Champions: Return to Arms are some of the best Diablo-style arpg's to have come out on any system. They helped made the PS2 one of the most memorable console's ever and copies of all three fetch anywhere from $20 to $150 on ebay. That's why it baffles me how they messed this one up. It's just not a good game. The main issue with it aside from the story not measuring up to the material that inspired it is the combat. If you're playing it single player prepare to face infuriating balance issues. You'll be yawning while button mashing as you overpower scores of enemies and then all of a sudden you'll have a cave troll or mini-boss constantly overwhelming your AI companions. When AI are able to reach you they'll be constantly knocked back by enemies. Added to the frustration will be gear. Good gear is rare and when you do get it nothing you get scales well. This isn't quite as bad early on but as the game progresses it ends up making it difficult to reach the end of the story by yourself. The story itself is weak. While some of the characters in this are in Tolkiens works and the films they're more like celebrity cameos in a bad 70's holiday special. The main characters in this lack any kind of personality or defining trait other than being generic representations of their assigned class. Dialogue is terrible with bad cliche's all throughout and cutscene's that act as filler to pad the games already short playtime. Performance and art-wise it performs just fine even on older systems. The art however while reminiscent of Lord of the Rings online's Middle Earth mixed with elements form the films feels looks just as generic as the characters personalities. The game is an on-rails grind fest through a series of uninteresting settings that evoke none of the ancient melancholy, ethereal beauty or ominous dread the novel and films do. To sum up this is a game from a company who once made some of the best arpg's around who seem to have forgotten how to do just that. I would not advise picking it up.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												It's weird when I don't like fantasy RPG's, because for the most part I really WANT to love them. And LOTR: WITN wants me to want to love it, but wanting only gets us so far now doesn't it?To start, I was immediately disappointed by the lack of local co-op. I had assumed that this version, despite being a port, kept the split screen co-op of the console version. I was, in fact, very wrong about this. So when I bought this and had a friend over that same day to play it together, instead I had to sit there awkwardly and submit to either playing solo while my friend sat around like a git or play LEGO Hobbit because it at least kept the basis of the game intact.And then there's the combat. As far as hacky slashy button mashy games go, it's not the worst around (lookin at you, Two Worlds). It's not good enough to be called good though. Most of the moves are quite slow and don't really feel like they connect all that well. It feels more like you're having a dramatic pool noodle fight with a bunch of people who aren't convinced you really hit them until you've bopped them on the head fifty more times, and even then the point is barely starting to sink in. I've heard of bullet sponges but most of the enemies here are steel sponges. I have the sneaking suspicion this is one of those games that only gets easier as you go, but after a few long and rather boring quests that I've had to solo I realized I had stopped giving a♥♥♥♥♥♥But the visuals. Dear Gimli the visuals. This felt much more like a Fallout game than a game set in a magical fantasy universe. Many of the characters you interact with stare at you crosseyed like they're trying their damndest to figure out whether the awkward jagged lines on your face are poor polygons or ♥♥♥♥♥♥ shadows. There are a couple hobbits naffing about in the various towns but at first glance I was a bit concerned that goblins were attacking. And the elves, supposedly the most fair race, look like they've been to Sylvester Stalone's house and got roped into re-enacting the fight scenes from "Rocky". It's all just a bit eerie to look at. In short, there are lots of collectibles, hidden goodies, etc. and I'm sure online multiplayer could be fun but sluggish combat and poor visuals lead to an ultimately dull experience. Time to go play some Dark Eye: Demonicon. 4/10

Posted: January 14, 2012
												I didn't expect to find a great or even good game here, but it's alright so far. The levels are straightforward, the graphics are ok, but lack personality, and the voice overs are also pretty good. The combat however is dull and boring. It isn't fluent and as a loremaster I get my♥♥♥♥♥kicked quite regularly. Most of the times my AI teammates are there in time to save me but other times we all just die because we were overwhelmed. There is an integrated RPG system where you can level up, collect gear and have multiple quests but it feels tacked on somehow. The skills aren't that powerful, there isn't that many gear to collect and having multiple quests seems pointless and mostly because of the one-way roads. The characters also lack any kind of personality so it's hard to feel connected with them at all.Unfortunately this game belongs in the bargain bin.[Rating: 69/100]

content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												Well I bought this game (like most games) on a %75 discount. I feel the game is well worth the money I played and I finished it in about a week. The game play is pretty good, as it follows the storyline for the books. But don't expect a LONG game (I completed Normal in 28 hours). You see, when you see the map, you see the layout of the entire Middle Earth. but you are only playing in about a few locations near and around Bree and the Shire and the Misty Mountain. Along with the game play, a couple of things to consider. Only you can equip and level yourself up. the AI does it automatically for your companions.The few annoying things are you can't walk through your companions, so if one of them is blocking the way, you have to wait for them to move or go around. This is actually annoying when you are in a fight with baddies all around you. You swing your sword and miss... Also, you have save points, which is good, but unfortunately, there is only one save slot for your game. You can't copy a slot, nor can you go back a few saves if you wanted to. But these are just technical woes, but it's still a fun game to play.There are 46 Achievements but there are a few that are secret, meaning it's not listed in your achievement list. Better off Googleing the rest to see what you need.I played the Ranger with a Two-Handed sword (great for the Barrow Down's level and easier to bust through.) Get lots of health potions and you should be good to go...I started on Normal, and when you finish your game, you restart from the beginning but you keep all your XP, Gold, and everything you bought. But, you are on the next difficulty level.There is one part of the game when you enter Carum Dum, it's heavy on the graphic at one stage and if you have a bad system to begin with, this will require patience to get through. But its a short travel.

												Starts out fun, but gets old pretty fast. The levels are very linear and are just hack-n-slash your way through. The RPG elements make it a bit enjoyable, but overall, it's pretty okay. There's some weird elements too that I don't think were thought out very well, such as slicing off heads with a hammer. I wish I could give it a neutral instead of thumbs up or down.6 / 10. Got old really quick.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Got this on sale for $5 and it's mostly excellent.======the bad======You are basically the d-list team fighting evil while all the cool stuff from Lord of the Rings is happening elsewhere.Story is totally forgettable and non-canon as far as I know.At the last location of the game, it's like QA completely ran out of time to validate anything. The framerate throughout the beginning of this section is choppy as hell, 2 specific rooms have absolutely bonkers graphics glitches, and I crashed multiple times during this section of the game. At one point, I had finally defeated the first phase of the last boss after 3 attempts - and the game crashed; that was a "ARE YOU F***ING KIDDING ME!?" moment. The first 90% of the game was pretty much bug-free during my multiple playthroughs minus a few rare game lockups during load screens. It's like the QA / development team just didn't have enough time to fix all the bugs in this game. It's freakin' great and smooth and nice like 90% of the time, but the remaining 10% are like no QA tester ever looked at it.UPDATE: I can't really tell you why, but a recent playthrough in 1080p resolution didn't have nearly the amount of issues on the last map - no idea why though!Solo with AI companions - there's not a way to easily see their equipment. You can quit, select a different character, manage their equipment, and repeat to set everyone's equipment the way you want - but that's pretty tedious. I never found it necessary to micro AI companion equipment - they upgrade themselves with random pickups just fine - but it seems bizarre that there's no such feature.======the good======combat, progression, loot, finding secrets - all of these systems are great and totally satisfying.It really feels good to build up to an eviscerating strike on an enemy and then knock their head clean off, chop off an arm, or knock them down and skewer them for the finisher.Getting a good hit streak and just going berserk on stuff is awesome, too.The skill trees and stat point systems really provide a variety of playstyles and builds for each character, and all of them feel useful.Active dodging and blocking, well done enemy tells, hit reactions, and misc animations - man combat is satisfying in this game.---------------------------------Basically if you can get this for super cheap on sale, I'd highly recommend you pick it up and play with 2 other friends.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												The combat is a chore of repeated clicking. I felt like missing a block or a dodge punished the player entirely too much, both in damage and the amount of time the character remains knocked down.It's an alright game overall, but it came to a point where it was simply unwinnable. I'm not sure if it comes down to luck or if you have to have 3 players playing at one time to coordinate attacks, but I couldn't manage it on my own.While defending a particular gate, trolls will barge in and just break it while you're wailing on them. There's nothing you can do to keep them from attacking the gate, since your attacks won't stagger large enemies. At that point, I gave up.

Posted: September 26, 2014
												Overall, this game was fun single player.  There is a multiplayer aspect to the game, which in my opinion, gives a game a much larger gamut of variety and fun.  Would there be more support for this product to resolve some game-breaking problems, I would revisit this review.  Unforunately, I must tell it how it is...The largest problems consisted of game saves sometimes  being overwritten (without consent or notifcation of any kind) when joining a friend's game and playing through the campaign as one of their three heroes.  Graphical errors due to lack of support on some common AMD graphics cards further complicated the ability to complete this game with people with these cards by kicking players/crashing.  No support is expected to continue for this game, so I must conclude the game is virtually broken upon download.

												More like... SNORE in the North, amirite?  Less of an arpg and more of a level based series of combat vignettes hack-n-slash.  And while the combat is 'beefy' and smashing things in the face is fun the problem is there's little supporting that to keep things interesting.  Talents, quests, and loot are generic.  The levels are purely linear and recycle the same enemies ad nauseam.  It seems the game was mostly designed with couch co-op in mind which explains its fairly shallow single player experience.  Try it if you got it as bundle fodder but don't bother purchasing individually.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												Whenever I see a classic franchise turned into a game, I jump at the chance to get it. However, this game has made me question that policy, as it was disappointing in more than one aspect.For one, the gameplay was painfully repetitive. You hack at enemies with staggering melee chains to deplete their tediously large amounts of health, and eventually score a "critical" slow-motion kill, with all such finishers being seen in the first five minutes. This would be all well and good if not for the waves upon waves of the same enemies in every battle, and reskins of the same enemies in every area. Virtually every enemy melee attack is slow enough that dodge-rolling out of them becomes literally half the game. Spells deal slightly above-average damage, yet they're incumbent upon leveling, are very few, have cooldowns, and can only be cast through the non-configurable and inconvenient number row.The game is apparently intended almost exclusively for co-op, as your ally NPCs' AIs are complete crap. They focus in on one enemy and proceed to totally ignore everything else happening around them; This makes stealth impossible, and leaves the large bulk of the fighting solely to you. One of the only ways to heal is waiting for your mage ally to cast a protective field that very slowly regenerates health - this can be annoying if there are many enemies with high-power attacks chasing you, plus the field can apparently be broken by a strong melee area-attack, which quite a few enemies in each battle possess.Additionally, although it may at first seem nice to have a semi-instant revive system, your allies are very stupid about using it: They will both run up to you regardless of how many enemies are in your vicinity, and proceed to get themselves mob-murdered, plus the revive will stop mid-way whenever they are hit by an area-attack, or by practically any projectile - making dying in a fight with a troll, a boss, or a few archers essentially irrecoverable. And even though your allies can remain in a near-death state infinitely, waddling about on their knees at random (making finding them at times annoying), you cannot, and game-over in a manner of seconds.The equip system is also laughably level-based. You can fight three trolls and scores of enemies to retrieve a legendary bow, and in the very next area, find a cracked shortbow in a barrel with 2x better stats. On account of this, wasting hard-earned gold on buying anything other than health potions is a wasted investment, and it's basically pointless to slot elf-stones (item enhancements) until the end-game, when you've finally stopped switching out your entire armor every area. Your inventory is also constantly getting bogged down with what the game deems 'unessential items', which are literally that, and have no secret or quest purpose whatsoever beyond getting in the way of useful equipment.The story is perhaps the only compelling thing about the game, but interacts badly with the mainline LOTR plot. For instance, when your party asks why you can't be part of the Fellowship, Elrond explains that the members must be stealthy and not necessarily powerful - when Aragorn, Legolas, and Gimli are basically the most badass warriors in the entire LOTR universe. The dialogue seems pretty forced as well, and can be difficult to follow unless you are versed in LOTR canon.Beating the game unlocks the next highest tier difficulty to play on, but the game has so little replay value that it's hardly worth it. War in the North lacks substance mostly because of its absence of variety and configurability, and I can't say I'd recommend it to any sincere LOTR fan.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												War in the North is a fairly boring action rpg.  The story of the game is that your party, that consists of a ranger, elf, and dwarf, is on a journey to stop another evil baddie other than Sauron.  This journey takes place as Frodo and the fellowship are on their way to destroy the ring.  Because of this setting, you can feel the B-side nature of it.  You do see some of the fellowship in Rivendell but the conversations boil down to, "Hey buddy, I'm doing this.  What are you doing?"  Oh yeah, they are talking eagles in this game.  TALKING EAGLES.Gameplay is a bit drab.  While I do enjoy the brawler genre, this game borders on Dynasty Warriors mindless and straight up boredom.  You have two main attacks, one standard and one strong.  You also have skills which are accessed through modifier triggers.  While useful, having those abilities limited by both a cooldown and power bar restricts you from using them all the time and only when it matters.  I had about 30 power potions left when I finished the game mainly due to me using them sparingly.  You have a block but it's useless.  It's hard to tell whether your character will actually block or take damage.  The only satisfying thing about the combat is that you get to decaptitate foes or sever their limbs for extra experience.Unless you are a LOTR nut, stay away.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2011
												The LOTR game we all wanted to see with all its blood and gore, War in the North delivers great storyline, awesome gameplay and marvelous landscapes. The world of J.R.R Tolkien is once again recreated in this game, inhabited with Men, Elves, Dwarves, Hobbits, Wizards Orcs and mighty Eagles. Story takes place right in the beginning of Jackson franchise, while the fellowship do their business, 3 new heroes travel to North with a task to stop right hand command of Sauron Agandaur. Game is mix of hack and slash and RPG elements like levelling your character and equip him with various weapons and armor to make him better. The strong point of game is 3 player coop, while you can enjoy the game alone you can do it better with 2 other friends. I would recommend this game only to LOTR fans or if you like fantasy go and grab it. But be warned If you want to play coop the better way will be to have 2 other friends with you, because playing with random people will break all the fun.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2013
												The Lord of the Rings: War in the North is an Action RPG developed by Snowblind Studios in 2011 and released PC, PS3 and Xbox360. (Yes, this game is an obvious console port.)The story is based on the events taking place in the northern regions of Middle-earth in the background of the main story of J. R. R. Tolkien's The Lord of the Rings, more specifically in Peter Jackson's The Lord of the Rings film trilogy universe. Players can choose one of three heroes who will journey to different locations to help aid in the War. Their actions help the Fellowship in a way that is not seen in the films or books.The graphics for this game while a little dated still looks quite nice with varied and sometimes quite beautiful environments. Music and sound are appropriately "Lord of the Rings'ish" and voice work is competently done.Combat is nice and fluid, and looks brutal with decapitations and abundance of blood splashing everywhere although it looks comical and more then a little strange when a blunt weapon like a staff can decapitate an enemy as well as a sword or axe. Co-op with 2 other friends can be quite enjoyable.With all that being said, this game is very buggy. In fact the bug was so bad, that I actually cannot finish the game due to a game stopping bug that i encountered at "Bargrisar". After killing him, the game just doesn't allow me to continue and I am simply stuck. This is only one of the many game stopping bugs as I have seen forum posts of how others are also stuck in similiar situations in later parts of the game, with no way to continue the game other then to replay and hope it doesn't happen again.Another annoying bug is that there is no way to turn off the ingame voice chat. It is horribly implemented, and is alot more trouble then it is worth. The worst thing about all of these is that the developers have already abandoned this game and there will not be any more patches produced to address all these problems.Overall Rating: 1 / 10I cannot honestly recommend this game to anyone as I myself was not able to complete the game due to the game stopping bug I encountered after about 9 hours into the game.This could have been a fantastic co-op game and had it not been plagued by all these technical issues, I could have given it a 7.0.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2011
												The LOTR game we all wanted to see with all its blood and gore, War in the North delivers great storyline, awesome gameplay and marvelous landscapes. The world of J.R.R Tolkien is once again recreated in this game, inhabited with Men, Elves, Dwarves, Hobbits, Wizards Orcs and mighty Eagles. Story takes place right in the beginning of Jackson franchise, while the fellowship do their business, 3 new heroes travel to North with a task to stop right hand command of Sauron Agandaur. Game is mix of hack and slash and RPG elements like levelling your character and equip him with various weapons and armor to make him better. The strong point of game is 3 player coop, while you can enjoy the game alone you can do it better with 2 other friends. I would recommend this game only to LOTR fans or if you like fantasy go and grab it. But be warned If you want to play coop the better way will be to have 2 other friends with you, because playing with random people will break all the fun.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												Lord of the Rings: War in the North is a third person hack 'n' slash game that allows you to slip in to one of three roles. That of a dwarven bruiser's, a dunedain ranger's or a Elvish Lorekeeper's.Their story begins in Bree, where Aragorn instructs them on a mission to venture to the north in order to secure safety of the ringbearer's journey towards Bree. Not only is the story played in War in the North very canon with Tolkien's universe, it also lets you experience several characters that are famous in the story.Radagast, Aragorn, Arwen, Elrond, Bilbo and many more are to be met throughout your journey.You will experience what it actually means to slowly become a very important part of a story as you venture to make your own story in the north while the ring goes east.The gameplay itself is crisp and you will rarely "slip" or not hit your target that you intended to hit. There is a levelling system that makes it all the more appealing and your armor upgrades in time with you as you find it as well.This game is best played co-operational with either one or two friends, a maximum of three players is allowed and each of them has their unique role.I can recommend this game to as good as every Tolkien lover out there. But also to those who have not yet experienced a story of Tolkien.With that in mind, I can only say, buy this game if you want to have a lot of fun.I estimate a 3 day (72 hour) playtime of the game, excluding challenges.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												This is the worst piece of garbage co-op game I have played in a very long time. I play with people who are on the other side of the world and whenever this piece of turd freezes for a few seconds, I get desync'd and get disconnected from the host. Half of the time after I get disconnected I cannot rejoin the host and he has to restart his session to allow me back in.This turd also has a bad habit of corrupting save files after desync issues. You can get permanently stuck in some boss fights if you reconnect after a desync. The boss won't be there PLUS you can't progress the story. We managed to fix it once by loading on top of the corrupted save. The second time it happened, the same trick did not work and now I am stuck with a corrupt save which in turn keeps crashing my game right after I click start to try and get to the main menu.!@#@ % !%!#(%$ @^*)# $@ !@#$EDIT 1: Finally finished the game. I had to delete corrupted saves both locally and from the cloud save folder before my crash on start issue disappeared. That was quite TEDIOUS.

												My first refund!This is nothing special, just another quick cash grab to capitalize on the success of the movies. It's half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ boring, and wasn't even worth the discounted price.The animations are terrible, there's absolutely no physics, the customization options are a joke (you can pick from 5 hairstyles, eye colors, face presets, and beards), your character is CONSTANTLY running around with their weapon drawn, even when in a city, combat is shallow and unsatisfying, gameplay, on the whole, is just unimaginative, repetitive and not fun at all. content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												Despite the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ graphics and the painfully linear gameplay, I thought the game had a nice plot and was extremely impressed by the lore. The gameplay mechanics are okay, though the AI's a tad bit over-powered at times. There is much desired in terms of combat tutorials. The voice acting was decent. Poor optimization as game crashes quite frequently, so much so you can get a steam achievement if there was one for game crashing. But, despite all the shortcomings, I seemed to like the game. However, 15 hours and 28 achievements later, my game suddenly goes Memento (anyone see the movie?) and my save game starts from "barrow-downs". Hours of grinding, 'gathering' and upgrading just [SAQUISHHH!!!... blub blub blub blub] down the toilet. I saw a couple of forum posts, which confirms that this issue does exist and the devs have shelved this a long time ago. Will I replay? Nah-uh, this is the end of the road for me.

content:
Posted: March 7
												From the look of it, i want to like the game.Good lore, actually pretty decent likenesses to the Films Well-known characters,except a few (copyright issues, or some geek wanting to refute PJ's choices?).And if you string the cut scenes and the few RPG moments, you have the making of a good start to a RPG...And thats all the good things there are to say about this game...You can play 3 different characters, but its basically just 1.And just 1 save...It crashes 2 out of 3 times (even in single player) on a "recommended" system...About the controls, the best thing you can say its based on a classic awsd FPS,but in combat there is no control whatsoever to which target you will hit,and even the minor opponents will kill you in 3 hits, while you have to hit each 3-5 times plus a finishing move... (and thats on Normal difficulty)Plusses and minusses?+ lore friendly, and fits in with PJ's vision of LOTR- EVERYTHING ELSEScore: 1 out of 10

content:
Posted: January 21
												Are you looking for a blast from the past? Being capable of magic, but not walking through grass (i.e. invisible walls)? Having AI companions stand in door openings, and needing to face a very specific way so you can interact with an object? And finally, having your computer freeze completely and needing to manually power off your PC, like in the Windows XP days? Then look no further, this game is just for you!I really wanted to like this game because of the LOTR setting, but in the second chapter the game began crashing after playing for a bit. I tried running in administrator mode and assigning fewer CPU cores, but to no avail. Rolling back to ancient drivers? No thanks. Combined with the quite generic combat, the game may not be worth the time investment for troubleshooting.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												*Hi, it seems like we have a licence for LOTR! Should we do something with it?-Sure! But what?*I don't know...- Nobody plays RTS anymore. Let's make an FPS!*That would be cool, but we can't make COD out of it, can we?-Yeah, that's probably true. ♥♥♥♥ it then. Let's make an RPG.*Right. But RPGs are complex, hard to make. It's a lot of work.-Meh, OK. Let's make a basic movement system. Some clicky combat. Some basic attributes and skills. And equipment here and there. Could it be any more simpler?*I don't think so. OK, we are gonna make an RPG then!I think it went something like this. It's absolutely uninspired. Unbelievably average in every way. Surprisingly boring. OK, maybe not surprisingly, I was out of big words, sorry.You have three boring characters to choose from and you can switch between them. From time to time they get an item which has some number a little bit higher then your current item. After clicking sufficient number of enemies to death you can put few points into attributes and choose from one of three skills and their passive upgrades.Add not too bad (but good either) graphics, average story and dull sound.It's not a bad game. But it definitely is not a good one. Why would you waste your money and more importantly your time with it if there are hundreds of better games. Just don't.

												This game is more fun than what I thought it would be. My first though was a low budget single player MMORPG, I were wrong. The game handles and looks nice, and it keeps to the LOTR lore, so it does not take a thing that never even got mentioned or existed in the LOTR lore. Grab this game, get two friends, and play. If you don't really care or have watched the movies and thought "Meh" buy it anyhow, it is so fun, I don't really care about the lore, I care more about slicing orcs heads off! :3

content:
Posted: February 18
												PROS+ Three classes.+ If alone, the other classes are played by the AI.+ Character modification+ Lore-Master can learn to dual wield. So, staff + one hand weapon. Best part of the game for that character.+ Standard attack (medium to fast speed) and critical attack (slow speed)+ Every class can attack melee and far distance.CONS- The characters do not sound like the movies characters voice-wise (Aragorn, Frodo, Gandalf etc.).- Items are WAY overpriced.- Playing as the Lore-Master is pretty damn hard considering that her job entails her not to get hit hard, which always happens regardless.- Lore-Master main staff magic is a joke.- I feel that the Lore-Master's mana is way too low, considering that it should be her main attack :/ .- Cannot modify names.- No real character modification, or at least only a minimal possibility.- No way to bring up a map to see what you should do.- There doesn't seem to be a way to go back to where you were once you use a portal. At least, my friend and I did not find such a way to do so.- It seems the game is only between 12-20 hours according to many people.

Maybe it's just because of the part of the game on in, I'm at the part where you have to explore the burrows and cave networks. For whatever reason this part is graphical intense, not sure if it's because of how many mobs are on the scream at one time, or if it has something to do with all the animations and special effects. I'm HOPING that once I clear this section of the game it'll stop crashing as much, but all I know is that it's very hard to play the game when it crashes every 20 minutes. I really can't say it's poorly optimized, I mean, the original game was on PS2 so it is an older game but as I said already it was running just fine at the very begining of the game.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												**TL;DR This game is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ version of Dragon Age: Origins, which came out a year earlier. If you want this kind of experience, then go play that as a dual wielder. War In The North is a brand-riding money grab that's repetitve, boring, and has LoTR as it's one and only thing that anyone could possibly like this game. Srsly go read the wiki for the story, this game is not worth it.***The one thing this game has going for it is the fact that it takes place in the LoTR universe. The aesthetics and the graphcs are mediocre, the voice acting is actually pretty good, but the game play is pretty bad.The controls are unresponsive and wonky, the level design is not obvious, the enemies are repetitive and boring... I got to the part after the stream of sappers and was just too bored to continue. Oh look, I axed another one. Oh wait, I'm the archer because I'm an idiot and they make you buy arrows instead of giving them to you. Let's be the mage..... aaaaand she's a healer.What the means is that this game is CLEARLY MEANT TO BE PLAYED AS THE DWARF. If I have to spend my money on arrows (because you do not find enough to not buy them), then my equipment is going to be lacking. I'll let the AI control that. If you're going to play a healer for NPCs then you're either too lazy to play and just want the story or you're too lazy to read the summary on Wiki. Either way, letting the computer shoot unlimited arrows and toss heals at you is really the only way it makes sense to play this game. I know this because the dwarf wa the last class I played and it was the only way I could even tolerate this game. I fought the troll as the Ranger... which basically meant I watched my teammates do Up-Downs like it's pre-season football.Which really lends insight into this game. Why even have those other classes if they're so much less effective than the dwarf? Really, the entire game just seems like a brand-riding money grab to me. Even the death animations on the enemies are repetitive... The game really holds no new interesting thingsdo I fly in the face of Mostly Positive reviews? I don't really know, to be honest. This game is really just a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Dragon's Age: Origins, which came out a YEAR EARLIER.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2013
												War in the North is an unexpected highlight. If you are a fan of the Lord of the Rings, enjoyed the setting in Skyrim and especially if you are not afraid of some repetitive but challenging Hack'n'Slay action, you might find this game entertaining. I bought it for 5 EUROS and I have to say these are besides of the one I payed for Left4Dead2 the best invested 5 Euros since a long for a game. I enjoy a lot the graphics, especially the great 3d vision support, the music and the unique Lord of the Rings atmosphere. The fighting system starts poor, but gets better while playing and let you really take part in its evolution. Overall, you should give the game a chance as I am sure it will entertain you much longer than some AAA titles for 10 times more of the price. Btw, it has also a great Coop-Modus with some minor glitches. At the moment there are still some players, so you should hurry up, if you want to enjoy this feature. Overall I give it for 8/10 as I am already addicted, even with way too many weird glitches the game sometimes has. But what counts in the end is not if a game is full with different feature, but if it can entertain for quite some time and there War in the North makes far more right than it messe up: 8/10.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Before you hit Buy (if you're one of the few who didn't get it as a Bundle), know all the drawbacks going in:-Clearly designed from the ground-up for console play.-Irritatingly clunky equipment system, featuring an annoying equipment degradation system that takes you out of the action pretty regularly for no reason.-Voice chat is set to ALWAYS ON NO MATTER WHAT, and multiplayer features generally integrate poorly (please wait for your friend to stop dicking around in his inventory before you can do anything!)-By the numbers plot, though certainly not the worst of the LOTR expanded universe games (still far better than The Third Age RPG).-Leveling trees are not balanced at all, with trap options aplenty.If you can withstand all that, there's an entertaining hack and slash game here. If you can't, well, the other games in the bundle were far better anyway.

number of helpful: 5 of 15 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 24
												I'll preface this by saying that my negative recommendation is conditional: if you strongly enjoy Peter Jackson's film version of The Lord of the Rings, and your computer doesn't use an ATI video card, and the game is on sale, then you should buy it.  It will be worth your while to play through it at least once.This game gets some things right.  The story and voice work are good.  The art design feels a bit over-wrought and generic at times, but for the most part it does a good job of maintaining the feel of the Jackson films.  It's also clear that the developers were careful to ensure that the game's events do not contradict Tolkien's work.  These aspects of the game are all much-appreciated.Where the game fails for me is the actual "game" part of the game.  War in the North feels as though it was developed by people who have a general idea of what a hack-and-slash game is, but don't understand any of the nuances required to make a GOOD hack-and-slash game.For one, dodge-rolling: does it have invulnerability-frames, or does it not?  I'm honestly not sure because it seemed like even odds whether it would allow me to actually evade an attack.For another, stun-locking: it often feels as though every hit sustained by the player causes you to be staggered.  Scoring hits on enemies, however, rarely ever interrupts their actions.  Some late-game enemies combine flurry attacks and staggering in such a way that you can't really fight back.Hitboxes and hurtboxes: this game has some of the sloppiest hitboxes and hurtboxes I've seen (essentially, invisible regions in and around character models which determine whether or not attacks connect).  Even when playing as the game host, I frequently found myself taking damage from hammer strikes and sword strokes that very visibly missed my character model by several feet.Lack of impact: this one isn't as severe as the above problems, but the combat lacks any sense of weight when attacks connect.  When fighting enemies that don't stagger you every other hit, the only indication you have that you've been hit is a sudden reduction of your health bar.  It took me a moment to realize why it felt this way, and I eventually realized that the game doesn't have hit-frames (I think that's what they're called).  Dragon's Dogma (a significantly better polished hack-and-slash experience) demonstrates this pretty well: when an attack connects in DD, it's often accompanied by your character's animation hanging for an extra frame or two at the instant of impact.  It gives the impression of your weapon colliding with the enemy (or the enemy's weapon colliding with you!).If the gameplay exhibited the same high production values as the art design and voice work, then giving this a thumbs-up would be a no-brainer.  Unfortunately, War in the North's gameplay ends up being the worst thing about the game.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												I would have not played much of this game without playing it cooperatively with a friend. Its not very good. Combat is stiff and floaty at the same time without having any depth and is only slightly better than MMO garbage. Not just that but you are near constantly in that combat and it feels quickly that you are just going through the motions to get to the next area to do the same things over and over. The RPG elements and UI are confusing at first but its not a huge issue but the UI is♥♥♥♥♥♥♥Also me and my friend had some trouble with in game VOIP. The game constantly has VOIP transmiting between the players and its low quality and laggy. You cannot turn this off in game. Some googling and we figured it out (something to do with setting line in or whatever as recording device, idk google it noob) but that should have never been an issue.This game is an RPG and it suffers from the RPG garbage. I dont want to waste time talking to people in a town and helping them find their sweetrolls or whatever waste of time you get from quest givers. I just want to run in and hack some brothers up. The amount of dialogue in situations is exacerbated by the fact the combat isn't very good. So its waste time talking to a bird that drones on and on so you can go back to jamming two or 3 buttons and going through the motions.Developers should have learned from the original games that were directly based on the movies. The ones that were released on PS2, and I expect PC and Xbox aswell (they share the same names as the movies, Return of the King, Two Towers). That was years ago but they are still miles ahead of this game and were very fun. They were less RPG and more action hack and slash and fun as hell in splitscreen or solo. Those were probably the best LOTR games I have played thus far, the RTS games were okay but not that great. They were solid games I suppose. But this one. Awe hell no.Unless you really like LOTR or the lore or whatever the gameplay probably won't keep you for long. Friendly AI is crap and unless you have 3 players you will have an AI with you. To summarize, its a crappy RPG hack and slash with poor gameplay and uninteresting combat, poor graphics, uninspiring sound, and crappy RPG elements. Its just crap.

												The Lord of the Rings is among the greatest fantasy epics ever told, and after the success of the movie franchise a bevy of tie-ins products, side stories, and other media was created to expand the universe. Snowblind’s newest action title is set in the land of Middle Earth but does not follow the paths of Frodo, Aragorn, or Gandalf; instead it tells an entirely new story. The Lord of the Rings: War in the North acts as a side car to the main storyline, telling of the heroic deeds of three brave warriors whose actions directly impacted the success of the Fellowship. Grab your axe, sharpen your swords, and get ready to kill some orcs.The human ranger Eradan, dwarven warrior Farin, and elven spellcaster Andriel receive a perilous mission from Aragorn while staying at the Inn of the Prancing Pony. Sauron is after the Ring of Power, and an unknown force is amassing an army in the northern reaches of Middle Earth. Fearing this resistance will spell doom for Frodo as he ventures into Mordor, Aragorn asks the three warriors to investigate the northern regions and act as a distraction to keep Sauron’s looming eye away from the Hobbits. Though the mission is assuredly a death wish, the Ring must be destroyed, and the three willingly accept. As their adventure progresses, Eradan, Farin, and Andriel encounter and recruit the Great Eagles, journey to the elven city Rivendell, and discover Sauron’s henchman Agandaur to be the culprit. The story runs parallel to the story from the books, so you’ll frequently hear updates on the Fellowship’s progress to Mount Doom, which is pretty cool. Though not as epic as the main storyline, War in the North does offer intriguing morsels of narrative that fans of Lord of the Rings will surely enjoy. Ever wonder why Frodo didn’t just fly on the back of an Eagle to get to Mount Doom? Well, you can find out why in this game. War in the North does a great job capturing the feel of the movies (not the books) in terms of atmosphere: you’ll feel like you’re in Middle Earth, but you won’t feel a lot of tension. Agandaur is indeed evil, but there’s never a feeling of looming destruction like there was in the source narrative. Interesting segments will pique your curiosity but all too often you’ll feel like War in the North’s story is entirely inferior to the Tolkien-authored classic.Snowblind Studios is no stranger to the action RPG genre, having created PS2 greats such as Baldur’s Gate: Dark Alliance and Champions of Norrath. War in the North plays similarly to these other titles. As you eviscerate countless orcs you’ll find better loot to equip and gain levels to grow stronger. Increasing in level allows you to advance further in a trio of skill trees which grant special powers such as firing multiple arrows at once, or healing spells restoring more life. The drive to find more loot and gain more levels is satisfying and acts as the main motive to keep playing. Seeing your character decked out in new armor and knowing a better helmet or sword could be around the corner can be addictive.Eradan is the most versatile of the three characters and can use a range of weapons and armors. Farin specializes in axes and hammers and is more of a tank class, while Andriel focuses on healing and support spells while using staves. Though there’s variety in the way each character handles, combat gets repetitive. Killing hordes of orcs is fun at first, but after the first ten waves of slaughter the game feels stale. The new abilities unlocked by leveling up only dampened the monotony for a short while. Even playing with two friends can feel boring at times, as you mindlessly mash the attack buttons, dodge roll from a troll’s club, and mash attack buttons again, occasionally calling for help or healing yourself.Some other gameplay weaknesses mar things further. If you fall in battle your allies can bring you back to your feet (sort of like Gears of War), but getting hit once while trying to revive an ally stops the process of healing altogether. This can make reviving others near impossible once they fall because you’ll be surrounded by enemies. The AI for your teammates is actually quite good, but the same can’t be said for enemies. Oftentimes they will just walk into your attacks, and only block attacks after getting hit a few times first. Enemies execute the same attack patterns throughout the game, so recognizing attacks becomes simple and dodging them is too easy. Also, the game has a handful of boss characters, like a massive troll, powerful sorcerers, and even a huge spider, but many of them implement the same attack strategy. Overall the gameplay is mixed: a good loot and leveling system are taken down heavily by bland, uninspired combat.Visually War in the North has some great looking game environments. The draw distances in certain locations (like the top of the Grey Mountains) are stunning, and the amount of detail that has gone into creating each environment is a big highlight. From the muddy and wet town of Bree to the great Dwarven city in the mountains, War in the North’s backgrounds is easy on the eyes. Characters look good as well but getting up close reveals some rough edges, particularly with hair. Beards and hairstyles move as if they’re one solid piece and don’t flow naturally. It’s a minor complaint (honestly, which game has ever gotten hair completely right?), but one you’ll assuredly notice. War in the North is also very brutal, with hacked-off limbs and blood flying everywhere. As you slice up foes your characters will be covered in blood, which is a nice touch. Snow sticks on your armor and clothes as you climb through the mountain stages, and it’s these fine touches that make the game’s visuals standout.War in the North can be played solo or with up to two other players taking control of your other party members. While playing solo you level up your entire team and can switch between them before each new mission, but playing with others requires each player to have their own save game and profile. What this means is if you’ve started a game and want a friend to join you in local split-screen co-op you’re out of luck, because that person will have to have a separate save game. This really cuts down on the co-op appeal as you can’t just pick up and play. Online multiplayer lets you join friends via Xbox Live, but you have to be close in level and story to join them, otherwise you won’t be able to save your content or progression. If you can get a group together though, playing with friends is easily the best option for the game. Having a human ally instead of a computer one is invaluable when a formidable gang of orcs, or worse yet a duo of trolls, show up . Unfortunately some bugs hamper the multiplayer experience, both offline and on. While playing splitscreen, I encountered enemies that stood still while we attacked them and freezing during load screens. While online the same issue with enemies arose, as well as enemies appearing from nowhere and considerable lag with some players. Strangely these problems only arise during multiplayer, as my experience through the game by myself went by flawlessly.The Lord of the Rings: War in the North is a game of ups and downs. The story is decent at times but fails to compare to the magnitude of the original books’ story. Leveling up and getting new gear is fun, but the combat becomes repetitive quickly. Multiplayer should be the definitive method of play, but requiring profiles for each player and a few gameplay bugs don’t help. I’d recommend War in the North for anyone who simply loves The Lord of the Rings, but if you’re searching for a co-op action title you might look elsewhere.Only On Sale

Product received for free
												A really fun and entertaining game; the AI is actually useful, the combat is smooth and flows from fight to fight, the storyline seems to be fairly well-written... I wouldn't know however because I can't play it for more than 2 minutes at a time due to constant crashes.This game would be an 8/20 at least, if it worked. It is fantastic, the menus are a little sticky and multiple clicks needed to wake the game up and selet items/upgrades and the levels last minutes at a time meaning large amounts of loading, however the game loads a lot behind the scenes, meaning you have an almost perpetual loading icon at the bottom middle of your screen.Still, none of this would be a deal breaker and I would totally recommend geting it because its positives hugely outweigh its negative qualities BUT... and this is a big but with one great big issue:Since Steam thinks it is okay to sell to you a broken, incompatible game that wont play due to constant crashes and people like me can't fix these issues because I am not tech savvy in the slightest, I cannot recommend it.It's games like this, released like this that are the reason I mostly play console games...

												I had some expectations about this game aside from the good reviews. I was expecting a game like  LOTR Return of the King Game (2003) which was great and had awesome visuals despite its old age. But this was made in 2011 I guess and from game mechanics to visuals everything is much worse. The combat is sooo clunky, it takes like 10 hit to kill one enemy. Animations are also so slow. Cutscenes and dialogues are unnecessarily long and boring. It feels like a work rather than a game. I just can't enjoy killing orc/goblin masses because they don't die and sword animations are awful. The environment and the story are somewhat uninteresting... In short the game that was made back in 2003 is much better. I am disappointed. I hope that the Shadow of Mordor is better, I will try it next.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2013
												Good game that really needs to be played in co-op mode to get the full fun factor.The game itself has a lot against it. The inventory management system is terrible. You cannot switch between the different characters as often as you should be able to. The game has quite a few bugs, which depending on your graphics card (up to date AMD's) can make the game unplayable on chapter 2 and 8 meaning you have to roll back your drivers to an old version. (12.6 if you needed to know)There's a limited number of different baddies to kill on each level. This game completely over uses the Troll sub boss.But...Once you get into a game with a friend or two you'll soon forgive all this for the sheer joy of beating the living daylights out of whatever it is that needs beating. Cutting an Orc's head off never gets old with the slow-mo kill cam. The loot is varied and interesting, you will constantly be after that next bit of gear to give you a slight edge.Replayability is good, once you've completed the game you can use the same character with the same stats / gear and play through on a harder difficulty, upgrading your gear once again. Even the static rewards get better on higher difficulties.The graphics are, in my opinion, superb. The voice acting is great. The story is fun in a Tolkein is probably turning in his grave way.If you want an online co-op hack and slash and dont have the time or inclination to throw yourself at Diablo 3 or Torchlight 2, then this is a must buy7/10

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												The word of Middle-Earth can be regarded as the archetypal high-fantasy setting. Thus, it lends itself very well to games of this type: hack-and-slash fests with some light RPG'ish elements (leveling up, learning skills and upgrading weapons). LotR:WitN goes beyond the known lore of Tolkien though: Snowblind Studio's have put a lot of work in a story that branches from the Ringbearer's one. Most of the time, this works quite nice: a lot of the scenes you'll visit are familiar (Barrow Dows, Mirkwood etc.) but are presented in a fresh way. The game actually offers quite a lot of background to the regular books, which is nice for those who haven't read 'The Silmarillion' etc. (me among them).As a game, LotR:WitN is quite pleasing: you select one of three characters and smash all sorts of foes to blubber. Each character has it's own strenghts and weaknesses and you can switch in between chapters. One mechanic that didn't work well for me was blocking: I finished the game without using it a single time (mostly playing as a dwarf). Still, I enjoyed it quite a lot for it's story and graphics. All in all I recommend this to those who like LotR and action-games, especially when you can get it at a sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												This is an excellent game that exceeded my expectations. It's the first LOTR game that actually presents battle sequences in a realistic fashion. The action is also intense and enjoyable, with limbs flying and heads rolling, sometimes on a slow motion camera. The replay value is also pretty high, since you can keep levelling up as you replay the story. The settings are amazing, and there is a very faithful and rich representation of Rivendell in the story. As far as nostalgia goes, this game hits home as well. You meet characters such as Aragorn, Gandalf, Elrond, and Bilbo along the way. This makes the overall experience much more enjoyable for fans. Bottom line, you should get this game... It's totally worth the money. 10/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
												More an action game with RPG elements than an action-RPG, this is nonetheless an enjoyable ride for fans of the LOTR movie trilogy. Gameplay is entirely centered around the action combat, which is relatively simple but satisfying. The skill tree provides a good sense of power progression and allows some customisation of each character. Aesthetically the game clearly follows the movies, but thanks to the story that intersects but doesn't otherwise follow the LOTR story, there are plenty of new locations to see and new events to play through. There are plenty of hat-tips to Tolkiens lore ( a few goof-ups too, but not too bad) and a decent amount of expositional dialogue. Unfortunately there is little depth to the characters in your party, so they will remain somewhat bland in spite of the 20-30 hours you will spend fighting at their sides.The single-save system is a bit of an annoyance, and so is the limited control and interaction with the AI controlled party members if you play this solo. Technically it was fairly solid otherwise, but the german voiceovers were sometimes assigned to the wrong scenes. An unfixed glitch (imho) is that you can't give shields or potions to your companions.Overall I'd recommend this game to people interested in a LOTR game, that do not mind to have a somewhat constrained visit to middle earth pesented through linear stories and levels and lots of action combat.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												This game is a good game overall, I enjoy playing it, and  we are on our second run through. The pros:Great story, great voice acting, very pretty, not too hard for someone who's not a serious gamer, yet challenging enough to keep the hard cores entertained. The cons: linear. very much so,it's fairly short at 17 hours (that's with doing EVERYTHING! all lore dialogue, and sidequests) and there are a few...ok several...major bugs that a non-beta game just should not have. This game, when it comes to bugs, makes me wonder if Bethesda put it out there. Most, are not a problem. Some, are downright infuriating. example: treasure reward gives choice, you choose, but oh look, it gave you something else in the box....  This has happened three times to me. Very annoying.   the rest, graphics, some inventory, some porting issues.  If you do not have a friend to play with, you will miss out on ALOT. We have not had the chance to play with three people yet, but having a bot to jump on the resurrections is nice, face it, humans are slow on uptake in the heat of battle sometimes.   I wish I could give a mixed reccomendation of this game, I highly reccomend playing it with a friend, but if you are alone, it's not nearly as fun.  7/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 10, 2013
												Good game that really needs to be played in co-op mode to get the full fun factor.The game itself has a lot against it. The inventory management system is terrible. You cannot switch between the different characters as often as you should be able to. The game has quite a few bugs, which depending on your graphics card (up to date AMD's) can make the game unplayable on chapter 2 and 8 meaning you have to roll back your drivers to an old version. (12.6 if you needed to know)There's a limited number of different baddies to kill on each level. This game completely over uses the Troll sub boss.But...Once you get into a game with a friend or two you'll soon forgive all this for the sheer joy of beating the living daylights out of whatever it is that needs beating. Cutting an Orc's head off never gets old with the slow-mo kill cam. The loot is varied and interesting, you will constantly be after that next bit of gear to give you a slight edge.Replayability is good, once you've completed the game you can use the same character with the same stats / gear and play through on a harder difficulty, upgrading your gear once again. Even the static rewards get better on higher difficulties.The graphics are, in my opinion, superb. The voice acting is great. The story is fun in a Tolkein is probably turning in his grave way.If you want an online co-op hack and slash and dont have the time or inclination to throw yourself at Diablo 3 or Torchlight 2, then this is a must buy7/10

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												This is a fantastic LAN game to play with up to two friends. The combat is fast and fun, but there are several issues with the game that make it fall short of what it could be.Buying and equipping items is confusing and tedious. There is no easy way to compare items against one another, so the player is stuck flipping back and forth between menus to determine which items are better.An even more troubling issue is the last stage, which is unbeatable. It's not hard, but the game has crashed in the same place on the last stage every time, despite any changes to computer, graphics settings or playstyle thrown at it. Some players have been able to beat the game, but many more are simply unable.That said, if it's cheap and you want to kill an afternoon, this is a fun way to do it — just plan on the story cutting short about thirty minutes from the ending.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												Pleasantly surprised by this one. Yes it's a corridor hanck 'n' slash game with RPG elements (you level up and can place points in a skill tree), but what makes this game worth playing is the co-op mode.Ignore the Bad PC Port tag, it runs perfectly with no game breaking bugs fine on mine and my partners rigs, one being an i7 920 and the other being an i7 3770. My partner's card is a GTX 570, mine being a GTX770. Both rigs run on Win7 64Bit.Graphically it beats vanilla Skyrim, and the level design is fairly good and varied, even though you're in a 'corridor'. Also, equipping new armour and weapons nearly always rewards you with a cool new look, as well as boosting your stats ! The voice acting is also good, and not being elitist about Tolkien's tales I actually enjoyed the (yes fairly unoriginal) story. Hell you even get to meet the main characters from the trilogy.If you and your partner, or a couple of mates want a good blast I'd recommend picking it up in a sale.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												This game is a ton of fun, expecially when you play co-op through the capaign with friends, but there is one MAJOR downside. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												If a slightly more than casual co-op hack 'n' slash set in Middle Earth sounds appealing, then you should buy LOTRTWITN.  (fun acronym, innit?)  If you want something deeper to play by yourself, then you will probably want to look elsewhere.War in the North is essentially Baldur's Gate: Dark Alliance set in Tolkien's universe. By that, I mean you and your AI/co-op partners will hack, combo, loot and sever your way through several chapters of ... who cares.  While the setpieces are faithfully drawn from Peter Jackson's LotR films, the story itself is not that important. Heroes will triumph in the face of seemingly insurmountable odds, and bad guys will deliver gutteral dialogue through the rugged steel spikes of their helmets. If nothing else can be said for the story, it at least gives the eagles an excuse for not simply flying Frodo to Mt. Doom to begin with. (not a specific spoiler, but yes -- there are eagles)Combat involves stringing combos together and landing stronger attacks when enemies are critical. In a way, that system reminds me of the original Witcher.  (tho very basic)  Leveling up gets you three attribute points and one to invest in skills.  Diabloesque ability trees allow you to play as you desire (to an extent), though melee combat remains relevant for every class. Further Diablo inspiration can be seen in the item "sets" you can combine for cumulative stat bonuses. All three classes have their own gameplay styles and the ability to discover hidden loot. The game is not a simple brawler: some areas and boss fights will require more than button-mashing and spamming skills. For tough foes that can knock you down, the dodge/roll ability is your friend.Presentation-wise, this game is behind the times. It runs on a souped-up version of a 2001 engine. While Snowblind has added some flourishes to remain relevant, it looks more like an early 360 era ('06) game than something released in 2011. The bland (but passable) visuals hold close enough to the film's art design. Just don't expect anything to write home about. We encountered a few frustrating glitches while playing, but they did not repeat. 360 controller support makes this a nice game to play from a couch, but the keyboard & mouse work fine for those used to already doing so.General sound design seems fine and supports my 5.1 system, but there seems to be an unresolved issue where the game has a permanently open mic in multiplayer. (so you hear quiet echoes if there's speaking in the room) The music ranges from fine to slightly distracting. I don't know whether it was a licensing issue or creative decision to forgo the musical scoring of the films, but it might have helped give the game a grander feel.Like many co-op titles, it's best played with friends to be experienced at its fullest potential.  If you have to fly solo, you may find this to be a disappointing experience. Either way, I'd say it's best purchased at sale price.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												It's great fun. If you're looking for serious depth, you really aren't going to find it here. But it's a fun romp through the Tolkien universe, with plenty of action and satisfying battles strewn liberally throughout the levels. There seems to always be something to do and somwhere to go, and while I can't comment on the length as I have yet to beat it, it does seem like one of those games where you get what you put into it. Play with friends if you can, though. The AI is okay, but doesn't open secret areas and is pretty useless in a fight except for picking you back up when you inevitably get skullcrushed by the swarm of goblins they let slip past them. Also, Dwarf. The Dwarf is hilarious to play. Little man, big beard, bigger axe, chopping off legs left and right; what's not to love? Lastly, on reports of glitchyness and general bugginess; I've had no problems whatsoever. No visual hiccups, no audio hiccups, nothing. Just smooth sailing. It runs smoothly at max settings on my machine, but your mileage may vary with this product. I've had a great experience, your experience may be less than great. At present, my personal recommendation would be to get this at retail price only if you have friends to group with. Otherwise, wait for a sale. It's built from the ground up as a co-op title, so you might as well play it as a co-op title.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												8/10. Recommended.Play as dwarf, ranger, or lore-master elf in the well-made LOTR world.Lotsa armor, lotsa weapons, lotsa loot everywhere.Each of the characters can find it's own hidden cache of great loot, each of the characters has different weapons to use and skills to use.Somewhat repetitive levels, (horn sounds and you can expect several waves of enemies in every level, beat __ waves to proceed), but very enjoyable finishing moves against every single enemy and also fights against trolls, where you really have to use rolling and your special abilities. You can customize your character's hair, eye and beard + color. But, it has one major down-side, anti-climax if you want.When you start last mission, Carn dúm, you've to walk through the fortress, which is gonna cause endless crashes and lags if you're using AMD GPU.Way to fix it? Downgrade your CCC to 12.6, or pull out your crossbow/bow/staff, aim down and walk through it, as I did. Once you go out from inner part of fortress to snowy part, it should be all good.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Great action game with some fun RPG elements.I loved the ability to play 3 different types of characters, basically hunter, mage or warrior. The characters are available for play only at the beginning of chapters or main areas before you start. AI for characters you are not playing seemed really good even though there were several times they got lost in an area or couldn’t jump down into an area. The pathing needs to be fixed on AI characters for sure.Story and voice overs were great, I love all the Lord of the Rings stories and this game does an excellent job getting you engrossed into the story and wanting to learn more about the characters. I have never been a super Tolkien Lore master so I can’t tell you if it is true to all the original Tolkien Stories. The game is more about a small group that helps with activities outside of the main storyline with Frodo and company.Combat with Keyboard and mouse was very responsive and easy to play. Skills are minimal but helpful during battles, especially boss fights. Items and equipment can be found almost everywhere with special sets available and that can be worn for bonuses during game play.There are NPC's in every story area for purchasing equipment and repairing equipment. Also there are lighted areas before main story battles that allow you to Buy and sell equipment, also gives you the option to travel to previous locations if needed for quest turn ins.Large map can be used for fast travel by just selecting area, also contains fighting challenges for group to fight waves of enemies.Only down side of the game other than the AI pathing issues is that there is no manual saving, the game saves automatically at new areas or story starts. When you complete a battle or area you find a glowing point that allows you to proceed to next area and it performs a save. Even though the game didn’t allow manual saves, it saved game enough times that I never had to redo a lot when my party was defeated in battle, since it typically saves just before the major battle or area change.Overall I would highly recommend this game, especially now that it is within budget price.

												Lord of the Rings: War in the North is a good game to play cooperative online. I had a lot of fun playing this with my brother. We played through the main game and loved it and it's not often that I can get a game to play coop with him. I thought the battle style was fun but somewhat repetative. content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												The 66/100 average of Metacritic is by no means doing justice for this game. The game being advertised as RPG might have fooled and♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off some people since it's basically a hack n slash game.There's only so few games out there for people who want to get the co-op experience and this game nails it and manages to be extremely fun to play through with the bros. The voice acting just adds to the fun as it's so hilariously bad. The combat system is just... well, it's a hack n slash so no further explanation really needed. It does its job. The only major flaw is really the requirement of exactly 3 players to be able to fully enjoy the game as the AI player really isn't that fun to play with.I wouldn't really recommend the game with the price tag of 20 euros, but if you can find this game on sale and lack a game to play with your friends, you should definitely give this game a try. It might be short, but it's fun while it lasts and has somewhat good replay value as you can play through it 3 times by swapping roles.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												Beautiful game with some great voice acting - a must have for any fan of the works of Tolkien or fan of the Jackson movies.  The combat might feel clunky or slow to those who are used to the smoother combat of other games where the goal is to be flashy, but you get a handle on it after a while and it becomes satisfying to really feel the chunk of your axe, staff, sword or mace in an orc skull. It's not that the combat system is bad - not at all. It's just different and geared to feeling a little more realistic. The combat is also brutal - you regularly sever limbs and dismember your enemies (but there's a setting to turn off the gore for your kids).  My only real complaints are that the sidequests give few hints on how to complete some of them, some aren't very obvious as to what the point is, and it can take a bit of running around to figure certain things out. Additionally, you will find it frustrating to be unable to switch characters on the fly - the game seems a bit wonky about when it chooses to let you switch ingame.  Otherwise though, solid LotR action game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												While Lord of the Rings: War in the North does not bring anything new to the genre, it is still quite well executed and be sure to provide you with a dozen or so hours of entertainment. Specially so if you are a LotR fan. The story follows the battles that took place in the North of Middle Earth while the Fellowship of the Ring marched on South towards the destruction of Sauron and I found it to be quite well integrated.I did not play the multiplayer version of the game so I cannot comment on that but I found that the singleplayer experience was solid and relatively bug-free. Besides some graphical glitches on some snow levels (which I cannot say were not due to my hardware) and some rare ragdoll quirks, the game looked and behaved quite nicely.You have 3 characters at your disposal and I imagine that a playthrough with each character gives you a different perspective of the story (albeit with the same levels) so that might give you some replayability value. You also have some challenge levels that might keep you busy for a little while longer. Equipment is varied and scales well (do not bother giving equipment to your party though, they'll equip themselves).Pros:+ Truthfull to the Tolkien lore.+ Stable and entertaining single player.+ Good graphics.+ Above average skill trees and gameplay.+ Good voice acting and overall sound ambiance.+ Excellent controller support.Cons:- Some graphical glitches on snow levels.- Very linear, you won't be able to explore a lot.- While you get some gameplay variety at certain keypoints of the game, the time in between is almost pure button and skill spamming.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												The 66/100 average of Metacritic is by no means doing justice for this game. The game being advertised as RPG might have fooled and♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off some people since it's basically a hack n slash game.There's only so few games out there for people who want to get the co-op experience and this game nails it and manages to be extremely fun to play through with the bros. The voice acting just adds to the fun as it's so hilariously bad. The combat system is just... well, it's a hack n slash so no further explanation really needed. It does its job. The only major flaw is really the requirement of exactly 3 players to be able to fully enjoy the game as the AI player really isn't that fun to play with.I wouldn't really recommend the game with the price tag of 20 euros, but if you can find this game on sale and lack a game to play with your friends, you should definitely give this game a try. It might be short, but it's fun while it lasts and has somewhat good replay value as you can play through it 3 times by swapping roles.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												If you are a fan of the Lord of the Rings, or you are looking for a fun co-op game to play with friends, look no further.Lord of the Rings: War in the North offers hours of fun especially as a multiplayer co-op game. The roles of the three characters you choose from are diverse and allow for each player to find their own rhythm and role in the gameplay. This is a typical third person action adventure RPG, offering the usual inventory micro management and looting.Don't expect the most polished game or top of the range graphics and mechanics, but if that doesn't bother you then this is a solid title. The controls are simple to pick up, and the gameplay is fun. I would recommend this to anyone looking for a game to play with a wife or girlfriend.
