content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												This game is really meant to be played Co-op. I'm not usually someone who goes for second playthroughs, but I did on this one. The campaign itself is not too long, so that helps. Leveling up really makes you feel more powerful. Two main complaints are that the Siege of Nordinbad is a little imbalanced with too many enemies that can kill you with one hit. Also, I played with two human players and one AI. The AI was constantly getting killed and if you don't revive them, you can lose. This totally messes with any strategy you might have. Lastly, if you have an ATI/AMD card, the beginning of the last chapter does a number on your framerate. It sounds like more complaints than praise, but it really is a fun game that's easy to get into and a lot of fun to play. Pick it up on sale, its a no-brainer.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 10, 2013
												For anyone who is a fan of The Lord of the Rings and action/RPG romps, LotR: War in the North is surprisingly fun.  The story takes place during the events of the books, but focuses around a different set of conflicts and heroes that were briefly touched upon in them.  Gameplay is what you'd expect out of an action RPG; hacking and slashing galore, unlockable and upgradable skills, plenty of loot to collect, and three different characters you can rotate playing with in between missions.  Length-wise, it's a good ~15 hour campaign that includes the option for online co-op and a New Game Plus mode for replayability.As far as issues go, there's nothing gamebreaking, however it does lack a lot of polish in some areas.  The audio is nothing special, and the graphics are often muddy.  The writing and voice acting isn't really up to par with proper RPGs either, but it serves its purpose.  Artificial intelligence, at least on the default difficulty, is pretty poor as well.  As for the controls, keys are remappable, but a gamepad is highly recommended.Though it may lack polish, as a total package, it's made up for by being just plain fun.  If you have a weekend to kill and you can nab it for a good price, War in the North is a worthy play.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												This game was most likely overlooked by everyone because of low publicity. However, what you will find inside is a fun Action-RPG in the vein of classic games like Baldur's Gate Dark Alliance. The combat is simple but meaty hack-slash-and-roll and you can play as a Ranger, Dwarf or an Elf. The story is original and runs simultaneously with the story from the books. You get to interact with a large number of characters from the books and it even the answers the age old question of "Why didn't the eagles just carry the ring to Mount Doom?" The boss fights are fun, if a little simple but rewards strategic attacking instead of mashing buttons.The main attraction of the game comes from playing online co-op with upto three people. Each character has abilities that compliment other characters. The A.I. is not bad by any means but you can't beat playing with actual people. After you finish the game, New game+ options open up which have chance to obtain more and more powerful weapons.7/10 game if played alone, 9/10 game if played with friends.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												This game is a good game overall, I enjoy playing it, and  we are on our second run through. The pros:Great story, great voice acting, very pretty, not too hard for someone who's not a serious gamer, yet challenging enough to keep the hard cores entertained. The cons: linear. very much so,it's fairly short at 17 hours (that's with doing EVERYTHING! all lore dialogue, and sidequests) and there are a few...ok several...major bugs that a non-beta game just should not have. This game, when it comes to bugs, makes me wonder if Bethesda put it out there. Most, are not a problem. Some, are downright infuriating. example: treasure reward gives choice, you choose, but oh look, it gave you something else in the box....  This has happened three times to me. Very annoying.   the rest, graphics, some inventory, some porting issues.  If you do not have a friend to play with, you will miss out on ALOT. We have not had the chance to play with three people yet, but having a bot to jump on the resurrections is nice, face it, humans are slow on uptake in the heat of battle sometimes.   I wish I could give a mixed reccomendation of this game, I highly reccomend playing it with a friend, but if you are alone, it's not nearly as fun.  7/10

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												So far it's been a pretty fun ARPG But the engine tries to mimic the unreal 3 enegines streaming capability and unfortunetly dosn't mimic it very well at all you may get sticky feeling streaming and it's bad at times my game crashed with black screen of death after 6hrs of continious play during this sticky streaming. One of them ctrl alt delete situations. While not a big deal really but annoying when you are in the heat of battle and having a good time and the game desides to break on you because it failed at streaming.  I enjoy the game regardless of this engine failure.  Little more cons to the game would have to be the character managment there is none other than the char you choose as your main when starting sp story there is options to give items to your ai buddies but soon as you goto a new zone you notice they some how managed to get them a new weapon & armor completly overwriting what you have gave them and no way of getting the item you gave them back so wasted loot. Another managment con would have to be way the game saves it dosn't seem to save the char changes done to other chars after you switch to them and then back to your main ai seems to be preset skill wise or something. char managment is 0/10 waste of time screwing with it worry about your main and screw the ai chars. Now with that said you can use the ai chars aswell not at anytime while playing certain check points offers the option otherwise you have to quit game and select the char. when you switch to this char you'll have to assign attribute points and skill points. I havn't been able get the settings to save but maybe due to how the auto save works more or less autosaves when the devs wanted it to which kinda sucks rpg games needs a manual save feature not just a check point here and there save. Else progress is esily lost.As for pros graphics are decent run well even on my 10 year old toaster all settings maxed and a smooth 60fps vsynced Some pretty cool weather effects when it's raining you can see water running down your armor and when you enter a building they are dry looking which adds some realism. Most of all you don't need a mod called real shelter like skyrim lmao I had throw that in there couldn't be helped....Combat is simple button spam with fun finishers I enjoy the decapitations and the blood splatters onto your armor and weapons. So far I'm still trying figure out who strider is as i never met him in the game yet a npc said my buddy strider was there lol some story elements have lost me entirly maybe related to other LOTR games which i will admit Ihave never played. content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												Rating: 5/10This game is a buggy mess that screams out the word "Budget". From the very second you start the game, you're taken 5 years back from the release date by virtue of dated visuals and shoddy animation. And the animation in particular takes life away from the characters in the game - Who should be great since this is an LOTR game and great characterization is the least you can expect from it. The gameplay is nothing great either, you get the bog standard hack n' slash action with some pretty basic shooting. However what really makes this game score low are the bugs and the glitches. WB (Isn't that a big surprise?) has not cared about addressing all the technical issues this game has, especially for gamers who use hardware by AMD. You will literally not finish the game unless you use outdated drivers. So if you're an AMD user, do not buy this game. And if you're not, I still wouldn't recommend it at full price. Buy it at a discount.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												With one playthrough under my belt I feel that I have a right to write a few words on this game. And, in all honesty, I enjoyed it greatly. It is very lore friendly, more so, than PJ's movies, it has amazing art style, the characters are vivid, even if not particularly deep, and it is nice that each has different, suitable to their race dialogue options. Story-wise the game is certainly passable, offering enough plot content to satify the RPG fans in most people, and surprisingly not single-minded, with detours and side stories which tie in to the main arc, but standing well on their own, too.As far as gameplay is concerned, it is good. Combat could have used more variation in available combos, because as is, it's just button mashing with occasional "strike when the arrow shines for a crit hit". I miss all the different combos from the old Return of the King games. Still, fighting hordes of enemies is fun, even more so, when you play with friends, as AI is wonky at best and in some sections you are definitely at a disadvantage (I look at you, mounted crossbow parts). There is a good variation, though, between characters. The dwarven champion is a heavy hitter, ranger is quick and slick DPS, loremaster is a support. All three work very well together and if you play with other humans, the slaughter you can do together is wonderful. Interestingly, each character has access to different kinds of secrets, with loremaster also being able to make potions for use of the team.All in all, I recommend the game to people enjoying the world created by JRR Tolkien and to people enjoying nice and simple hack'n'slash games. It is definitely worth buying at a discount, and a worthy item to consider buying without it, too.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												The game itself is very enjoyable and atmospheric, even if it is railroaded into making you follow only one path from start to finish. They do a decent job with the lore as well, though there are a few minor errors such as the party not knowing what 'beast' they saw- and then in the next scene outright calling it a Nazgul attack as if they knew anyway. As I said; minor detail.The main problem with this game are the bugs. If you can somehow play this game and not have it bug out on you, enjoy it. I can't finish this game because of this. The latest bug that keeps happening is my graphics gets all pixellated (like static-television bad), and then the screen freezes with whatever I last saw (attacking, running, whatever). I can hear my character is still doing things; I can hit Escape and can hear menu choices highlight, but I only see whatever the screen froze on initially. It never updates again; I have to ALT+F4 and start over, only for it to happen all over again...It has been out for awhile. To have these and many other bugs still (many others have similar or other issues, and I've changed graphical settings and compatibility modes/etc to no avail), I'm not impressed. For this reason I do not recommend this game. I will change my review if they resolve these issues.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												Bought this game due to Co-Op and it was pretty cheap. Best thing I've done. My wife was married to a game addict for over 20 years and this was the first game she tried with me. War in the North is a wonderful game for families, friends, etc. I haven't seen another game that was so easy to jump in, play together without any stress of level grinding, gear seeking etc. The game is simple to play, has all the aspects of RPG (gear, skills, stats, potions, etc), but it's made so simple for anyone to just pick up and go hack and slash.As other reviewers said, it's not the best out there, but it made my family have a great gaming night together, no other game brought us this close together. There are client crashes for sure (AMD and nVidia GPUs, Windows 7 and 10), the most annoying bug is the open mic in multiplayer. It was super annoying for us because we all sit together. Disabling microphone in Recording Devices in windows, took care of that. Other than that, we greatly enjoy the game and looking forward to a weekend when my family can play together again.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												I have ahicived all 4 difficulties on all 3 charachters, many long hours doing so, I can honestly say that War in the North is a wonderfull experieince. It certainly was shadowed by Skyrim's release in November, so it didn't get the recognition it deserves. Each combat method of Magic, Range, and Melee work expectionally well in various situations. The lack of feshed out charchter customization is made up with the sheer abundance of loot and rewards. You can certainly find a mirror (most likeley in resupply areas on the map like the rangers camp) to change your character's face and hair, but I think the sotry was meant to focus on the 3 protaganists rather tan the RPG element like skyrim or Dragon age. The over all story is quite well done, adressing what is going on in the North at the time when the fellowship is doing it's thing in the south (across all 3 books or movies) so you meet alot of the charachters such as Aragorn, Gandalf, and Frodo  and the gang along the way. Along with that, there are many beautifully done enviroments you play throuh, but you can feel boxed in at times, which is disspointing. It is not an 'open world RPG' it is like Dragon Age: Origins in a sense; you may go back to all the locations if you like, but once you start a new playthrough you cannot visit locations until you unlock them. The combat and skill trees are very fluid and well structured, but it can be repetitive at times. It's very satisfieing to see your enemies skull break open in slow motion. Their limbs also break off, ofcourse there is also tons of blood and gore, and settings to remove it. The combat style is based of of which charachter you choose, all of which have a range weapon. Magic for Elf (swords as well), axes and crossbows for Dwarf while the Human uses longsowrds, clasymores, and somewhat of a vanguard suit using sword/axe and shield. It is pretty mcuh what you'd expect them to use. Multiplayer works alright, but is best for friends. Multiplayer only works for 3 players with each player using one of the protaganists. In the game, there are 2 locations that use a wave-based setup. One in Ministirith, and the other in some undead elf area. Both areas are quite small and poorly executed. Overall I rate this game a solid 8.5/10  Interesting story (if you are familiar with the Trilogy Definetly worth a buy.

Posted: September 7, 2015
												So far it's been a pretty fun ARPG But the engine tries to mimic the unreal 3 enegines streaming capability and unfortunetly dosn't mimic it very well at all you may get sticky feeling streaming and it's bad at times my game crashed with black screen of death after 6hrs of continious play during this sticky streaming. One of them ctrl alt delete situations. While not a big deal really but annoying when you are in the heat of battle and having a good time and the game desides to break on you because it failed at streaming.  I enjoy the game regardless of this engine failure.  Little more cons to the game would have to be the character managment there is none other than the char you choose as your main when starting sp story there is options to give items to your ai buddies but soon as you goto a new zone you notice they some how managed to get them a new weapon & armor completly overwriting what you have gave them and no way of getting the item you gave them back so wasted loot. Another managment con would have to be way the game saves it dosn't seem to save the char changes done to other chars after you switch to them and then back to your main ai seems to be preset skill wise or something. char managment is 0/10 waste of time screwing with it worry about your main and screw the ai chars. Now with that said you can use the ai chars aswell not at anytime while playing certain check points offers the option otherwise you have to quit game and select the char. when you switch to this char you'll have to assign attribute points and skill points. I havn't been able get the settings to save but maybe due to how the auto save works more or less autosaves when the devs wanted it to which kinda sucks rpg games needs a manual save feature not just a check point here and there save. Else progress is esily lost.As for pros graphics are decent run well even on my 10 year old toaster all settings maxed and a smooth 60fps vsynced Some pretty cool weather effects when it's raining you can see water running down your armor and when you enter a building they are dry looking which adds some realism. Most of all you don't need a mod called real shelter like skyrim lmao I had throw that in there couldn't be helped....Combat is simple button spam with fun finishers I enjoy the decapitations and the blood splatters onto your armor and weapons. So far I'm still trying figure out who strider is as i never met him in the game yet a npc said my buddy strider was there lol some story elements have lost me entirly maybe related to other LOTR games which i will admit Ihave never played. "shrugs" Voice acting isn't cheesy sounds good so far.Not played co-op so i can't give a review of thatAnyways i'd say meta score is pretty accurate as I'd give a 6/10 I've played much better but I've also played far worse do i rec it sure it's a fun pass time has a few flaws but nothing I can't deal with. i don't recommend it for $20 not a $20 game $10 or less pick it up.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												I really enjoyed this game even if the world wide rating is not high. Its mostly easy and relaxing action game (combat system is similar to Prince of Persia) with rpg elements and good action battles.  You can choose between three characters (Ranger, Dwarf and Elf), learn and use lots of perks, improve your armor and weapons. You can buy and sell items of course.  You can use some basics commands to your other characters during the battle (attack/retreat) The game has very good feeling of Lord of rings world, you can meet the LOTR movie characters and the enemies are also copy of movie version. I really can recommend this game, but dont expect long and hardcore game with free and large world. The game also offers multiplayer cooperation against enemies. My rating is 7/10.+ graphics+ story+ Lord of the Rings atmosphere+ action combats+ you can choose between three different characters+ multiplayer cooperation+ AI of your mates is not bad and they can help you (heal etc)- gameplay could be longer- should be less corridor game- you cannot switch between characters during the battles and real time game, only if you load the game from main menu- only a few side quests- very, very often you discover new and new equipments- maybe too easy, but if you finish the game, there is unlock of harder difficult- final battle was quite dissapointing to me

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												War in the North was that one game that I had heard nothing but mediocre things about. "The AI is terrible," whined every reviewer, "and the story is complete garbage, not to mention the clunky gameplay." With words like these clouding my vision, my buddy and I decided to give it a whirl one day out of sheer boredom. Maybe it was my initially abysmal expectations, but I was thoroughly satisfied, and in some cases, completely blown away.Now, that's not to say that the reviewers were lying. The story is extremely silly, but that's not really the focus of the game. It only took us about an hour to realize that this is in no way a story-driven game. It's a pure hack-and-slash at it's finest, the likes of which I've never seen before. In this area, the game outshines just about every other RPG out there.This is one of the most fun action games there is... provided you have friends to play with, because the reviewers weren't kidding when they said the AI is absolutely awful. For instance, if you happen to get knocked down in combat, your the AI will focus 100% on making his way to save you. Great, right? Except for that massive troll about to wail on him with a giant hammer. We had very few kind words for our AI friend.The RPG elements are pretty simple, but again, that's because the focus is right where it should be: the combat. The difficulty spikes in satisfying ways, lulling you into complacency, then smacking you in the face with a horde of Uruk-hai.Beyond the standard gameplay, there are little touches here and there that make this game worthwhile. For one example, the in-game voice chat adds an echo effect to your voice when you enter a cave. Pretty neato, right? It's features like that, which, while being completely unnecessary to the core experience, add a sense of joy to the playing experience, and brought a smile to my face.In summary, if you have a friend or two to play with, and you're looking for a decent-length hack-and-slash with light RPG elements, this is the game for you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												This game is really meant to be played Co-op. I'm not usually someone who goes for second playthroughs, but I did on this one. The campaign itself is not too long, so that helps. Leveling up really makes you feel more powerful. Two main complaints are that the Siege of Nordinbad is a little imbalanced with too many enemies that can kill you with one hit. Also, I played with two human players and one AI. The AI was constantly getting killed and if you don't revive them, you can lose. This totally messes with any strategy you might have. Lastly, if you have an ATI/AMD card, the beginning of the last chapter does a number on your framerate. It sounds like more complaints than praise, but it really is a fun game that's easy to get into and a lot of fun to play. Pick it up on sale, its a no-brainer.

												I love this game so much, and I havent even played Multi-Player, even in single player this is a great experience. (I have low hours since i recently bought on pc, but I had it on my 360 for ages before hand and still enjoyed it immensely)Pros- -Graphics look amazing for a game thats been out as long as this.-Gameplay, some people say is a bit repetetive but I dont see that, there is a huge variety in enemies.-This game is heaven for looters, so much loot to find.-It offers character customisation, well this has been done before, it is a really nice touch to the game.-Feels like a genuine RPG experience, complete with questing, a great story, and of course; you start off in a tavern, what could be greater.-The soundtrack in this game is absolutely amazing, you will want to stay in a location for the music alone.Con- (literally only could think of 1)-Single Player A.I isnt the best, they arent absolutely stupid as they do level up by themselves and equip thier own equipment. But at times it feels like it was made with too much focus on human players all together.If you have the money buy this!

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												If you are a fan of the Lord of the Rings, or you are looking for a fun co-op game to play with friends, look no further.Lord of the Rings: War in the North offers hours of fun especially as a multiplayer co-op game. The roles of the three characters you choose from are diverse and allow for each player to find their own rhythm and role in the gameplay. This is a typical third person action adventure RPG, offering the usual inventory micro management and looting.Don't expect the most polished game or top of the range graphics and mechanics, but if that doesn't bother you then this is a solid title. The controls are simple to pick up, and the gameplay is fun. I would recommend this to anyone looking for a game to play with a wife or girlfriend.

												I love this game so much, and I havent even played Multi-Player, even in single player this is a great experience. (I have low hours since i recently bought on pc, but I had it on my 360 for ages before hand and still enjoyed it immensely)Pros- -Graphics look amazing for a game thats been out as long as this.-Gameplay, some people say is a bit repetetive but I dont see that, there is a huge variety in enemies.-This game is heaven for looters, so much loot to find.-It offers character customisation, well this has been done before, it is a really nice touch to the game.-Feels like a genuine RPG experience, complete with questing, a great story, and of course; you start off in a tavern, what could be greater.-The soundtrack in this game is absolutely amazing, you will want to stay in a location for the music alone.Con- (literally only could think of 1)-Single Player A.I isnt the best, they arent absolutely stupid as they do level up by themselves and equip thier own equipment. But at times it feels like it was made with too much focus on human players all together.If you have the money buy this!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												This game is really meant to be played Co-op. I'm not usually someone who goes for second playthroughs, but I did on this one. The campaign itself is not too long, so that helps. Leveling up really makes you feel more powerful. Two main complaints are that the Siege of Nordinbad is a little imbalanced with too many enemies that can kill you with one hit. Also, I played with two human players and one AI. The AI was constantly getting killed and if you don't revive them, you can lose. This totally messes with any strategy you might have. Lastly, if you have an ATI/AMD card, the beginning of the last chapter does a number on your framerate. It sounds like more complaints than praise, but it really is a fun game that's easy to get into and a lot of fun to play. Pick it up on sale, its a no-brainer.

Posted: September 7, 2015
												So far it's been a pretty fun ARPG But the engine tries to mimic the unreal 3 enegines streaming capability and unfortunetly dosn't mimic it very well at all you may get sticky feeling streaming and it's bad at times my game crashed with black screen of death after 6hrs of continious play during this sticky streaming. One of them ctrl alt delete situations. While not a big deal really but annoying when you are in the heat of battle and having a good time and the game desides to break on you because it failed at streaming.  I enjoy the game regardless of this engine failure.  Little more cons to the game would have to be the character managment there is none other than the char you choose as your main when starting sp story there is options to give items to your ai buddies but soon as you goto a new zone you notice they some how managed to get them a new weapon & armor completly overwriting what you have gave them and no way of getting the item you gave them back so wasted loot. Another managment con would have to be way the game saves it dosn't seem to save the char changes done to other chars after you switch to them and then back to your main ai seems to be preset skill wise or something. char managment is 0/10 waste of time screwing with it worry about your main and screw the ai chars. Now with that said you can use the ai chars aswell not at anytime while playing certain check points offers the option otherwise you have to quit game and select the char. when you switch to this char you'll have to assign attribute points and skill points. I havn't been able get the settings to save but maybe due to how the auto save works more or less autosaves when the devs wanted it to which kinda sucks rpg games needs a manual save feature not just a check point here and there save. Else progress is esily lost.As for pros graphics are decent run well even on my 10 year old toaster all settings maxed and a smooth 60fps vsynced Some pretty cool weather effects when it's raining you can see water running down your armor and when you enter a building they are dry looking which adds some realism. Most of all you don't need a mod called real shelter like skyrim lmao I had throw that in there couldn't be helped....Combat is simple button spam with fun finishers I enjoy the decapitations and the blood splatters onto your armor and weapons. So far I'm still trying figure out who strider is as i never met him in the game yet a npc said my buddy strider was there lol some story elements have lost me entirly maybe related to other LOTR games which i will admit Ihave never played. "shrugs" Voice acting isn't cheesy sounds good so far.Not played co-op so i can't give a review of thatAnyways i'd say meta score is pretty accurate as I'd give a 6/10 I've played much better but I've also played far worse do i rec it sure it's a fun pass time has a few flaws but nothing I can't deal with. i don't recommend it for $20 not a $20 game $10 or less pick it up.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												I'll keep it short.I thoroughly enjoyed it, as an avid Tolkien fan, it was nice to see some of the places in Middle Earth explored a little more, Such as Sarn Ford, Fornost etc. I've compiled into a list things I enjoyed and didn't enjoy about the game.Positives: The world looks pretty good, and has captured I feel how the various places you visit would be, based on the description from the book.The combat is decent enough, I played as the Ranger and enjoyed rolling underneath trolls or around Orcs and slashing at them whilst they were exposed.Side quests are a bonus, as in any game as they give you extra things to do, and increase playtime. There are also two 'Survival' type bonus missions.Whilst the levels are Linear, I did feel like I was exploring Middle Earth, which is obviously a good thing.Co-Op, in any adventure game is great, and this can be really good fun with a friend or two.Things I didn't enjoy:Not much to pick at here really, and a few of these things won't apply to you guys anyway.The game felt difficult towards the end, I know it's supposed to be Co-Op, but I found it nigh on impossible doing it on Singleplayer, as both the AI companions ran in a straight line to revive me, straight into the path of that Troll guarding my body.A few of the locations don't feel 'Tolkienesque' to me, such as the Barrow Downs with 'Zombie' like creatures, but this can be overlooked. I felt the shop system a waste of time, as I was constantly finding good enough Gear to be getting on with, and had no need at all to buy any gear except for early in the game, even then I now realise it wasn't nessecary as I often found something better than what I'd just bought moments later in a chest.Conclusion:This review isn't to be taken too serious, a lot of the issues can be overlooked depending on your expectations, but I enjoyed it, and it's a nice little romp through Middle-Earth as you take a different path from the usual main characters during The war of the Ring, And I reccomend this be it to play Solo or Co-op.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												RPG set in middle earth with 3 main characters, a Dwarf Champion of Erebor, a Elvish Lore-Master (mage), and a Ranger.Story:This game acts as a companion of sorts to the movies, when you begin the game, Aragorn is briefing the trio in The Prancing Pony in Bree, sending them on a mission after they report a Nazgul attack. He sends them to attack orcs at a ruined city to distract a mystery dark lord who is a servent directly to you-know-who. You basically meet every character that could have been in the movies, like one of the eagle's that gandalf constantly summons, or the twin brothers, sons of Elrond. Like I said, pretty much every part of this is a companion to the movies, because you're literally just working behind the scenes and making things easier for Frodo and Aragorn and the gang. In fact the first mission is distracting the "dark lord" so Frodo has enough time to get away. Gameplay: The combat is bloody, and entertaining. I especially like how some enemies sort of ragdoll after they die, making your attacks seem forceful and strong. It reminds me of how the combat looks in the movies when that happens, though sometimes the orcs go through these short death scenes where they sway on their feet for a few seconds before dropping dead and hitting them has no effect and it looks terrible when that happenes, because you're swinging a 100 pound axe at a guy and he's just going through a basic death motion. The gameplay can get hard, especially with bosses who can incipacitate 2 players at once. Playing as different people will alter your gameplay a bit, the elvish mage tends to stay back from the fighting a bit and focus more on blasts of power as her melee attacks are low damage, the ranger can play either frontline fighter or stay back archer as his bow let's him fire a steady stream of arrows and his sword cuts through orcs like butter. The dwarf fights with massive, powerful attacks and his main ability (rage) let's him deal out even more damage, making him effictive for clearing a room. His high damage crossbow is good for picking off archers or thinning out the numbers before you run in axe swinging. Graphics:There's not much to say here, the blood effects look nice but overall it's mediocre at the worst to good at the best, usually hovering around pretty good with a bit of meh. It obviously looks pretty dated now but don't let that stop you.TL;DR:An exiting, fun RPG with distinct characters, a good backstory that makes you feel like your acomplishing something, and a fun combat experience. The price of $20 won't break your bank either. I would reccomend heavily that you understand at least the full story of the movies, if not some extra lore of the series to play this game(Just watch the movies), though that's like a given with most LOTR games. 8/10Postive: + Good Gameplay+ Good Story+ Even better if you understand the lore+ FunNegative:- Okay graphics- Get's less fun if you don't at all understand the lore.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												A third person hack and slash ARPG smothered in Lord of the Rings lore. This is a journey that runs parallel to the fellowship's quest, although your fight is in the northern parts of Middle Earth. There's plenty of loot, weapons, a few optional quests, gem slotting, skill upgrades, and stat increases as you level up and fight your way to Agandaur, Sauron's right hand in the North. I'm a big fan of ARPGs and this one is definitely good. My enjoyment was mostly due to my love for the setting, however. Bioware style dialogue pulls you into the story as you run into the eagles, tons of orcs, wicked men, undead, trolls, a couple of wizards, and even a dragon. This game seems a bit underrated, its gameplay is solid even though the 3 classes do, more or less, play in a similar style. Still ... it was very fun the whole way through, I strongly recommend it, but most especially if you love LOTR. Played solo.

												Very fun game with RPG elements like loot, levelling, quests, skills, stat points, and other stuff. Story is ok, maybe about 10-15 hours to complete it, so it's not too short, especially if you take your time and explore the ares it puts you in; looking for loot and other secrets. Has a new game+ mode which is always nice for replay value. Has online 3 player co-op which looks fun. Combat is pretty sweet (I played as the Dwarf). It can get a little challenging at times, especially if youre relying on your companion's AI. The game throws multiple types of enemies at you, which are admittedly harder than some boss fights. Enjoyed playing it once, but not enough to play twice.7/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												To be honest this game's gameplay is pretty dumb. Eventually you'll end up just clicking your attack button walking through corridors with different textures occasionally using some of your special abilities. RPG elements are also very limited allowing you to choose skills from three small groups of abilities for each character. From these points you'd probably think this game is not worth your time but there is one big BUT. Even though the combat is dumb it's somehow entertaining and delivering killing blows to orcs has a satisfying feeling that drives you on. Also the story of a multiracial three men commando that has the task of crippling Sauron's forces in the north while Frodo and his pals march to Rivendell sucks you in even though it's simple and full of cliché. And finally the familiar places of Middlearth that look (at least for me) pretty good come alive in this game.So if you're a big fan of Lord of the Rings and you don't mind playing dumb yet entertaining hack and slash game get it:)

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Another singleplayer game that i completed, I must say, this one is very well made. The story was, well, it kinda went well with Tolkien's story, 3 people fighting in the north while the fellowship of the ring fighting down south. I really like the combat mechanics, its like Batman's combat mechanics (which i loved). The graphics are also amazing, beautiful landscapes, effects and what not. The looting system and inventory system is simple and nothing fancy but easy to use. You get to unlock skills by leveling up and spending skil points during gameplay, the good thing is you can play the whole story again with your old character but a new story difficulty, so you can continue progressing on your character and eventually get max skills and what not. But one downside about this game is that you basically just keep on fighting, like after you finished killing some orcs, some comes and you have to kill again, it kinda gets boring, but its fun to watch orc heads rolling around. I got this in the Humble bundle, which is a steal for this game, but if you are going to buy this game at full price, dont, it doesnt worth that much because the devs abandones this game and there are still some bugs and glitches here and there. But if you wanna fight for Frodo, go ahead :)

												This was the game that (for me) was going to be a fantastic masterpiece and a great keepsake for the honor Lord of The Rings trilogy deserve, but was sadly misused and wasted.LOTR: War in the North is based on the story of JRR Tolkien's books on Lord of the Rings, and the main focus on Ringskrømtene Nazgul and the Witch-king Agandaûr and places that Gundabad and Nordinbad. The protagonists in this story wood and consists of Farin, Eradan and Andriel who supposedly also did a great job during the journey to the ring bearer Frodo and his companions. The three protagonists are not looking in the party, but they are always at a distance from focusing on the war that has break out in the north. Farin, Eradan and Andriel his job is to stop the war, find Agandaûr and prevent war lost influence ring bearer in any way.A good ideaThe background story sounds like a good idea where you can get an incredible amount served and a game that really draws you in suspense. And yes of course it is, but here unfortunately all the possibilities that could have been abused and turned. It began as a rather exciting and gripping game that I really enjoyed every second of. But after a while it sort of just looser and looser. It almost seemed as if the game did not bother and continue any more. Suddenly I discovered that enemies became more and more the same only with stronger health and weaker attack, and eventually began almost everything and repeated several times and the effects were just worse and worse. Eventually, the game was full of bugs and colors that blink and flicker in a single chaos, and when this occurs I start and know that this just be another form of milking.Disgusting and Hermes Skyrim designOne of the most disappointing of this game is that it does not feel or look as if it is based on Lord of the Rings, but instead of a sags copy of Skyrim. It really gives the most impression that this is all about Tolkien's universe and not Skyrim's story. Many of the places you are under review the game looks like they should have been taken directly from Skyrim, and then only made on others just have the same style. I therefore feel that this is not a correct 100% finished game, but instead of a halfway done BETA and it is not exactly satisfying.When we come to control and camera is what most other games. Camera's okay that you can set according to how sensitive you want it on the input menu. But when we come to make it something that stands out a little, and it is in a negative way. If you are playing on PC so it is obviously best to play with a Xbox control, without it it works almost not to play this game. But unfortunately it is not like that fight well with it either, because I often annoy me that the character I play as doing things that he should not do. At various attacks lockup and special attacks erupt, and closes absolutely any kind of movement is therefore a must turn to. But what is strange is that all errors begin to occur when you are roughly halfway through the game.Boss and boss fights seem excessiveThen it hurts me to come with even a negative paragraphs. Again it goes pretty good to roughly the middle of the game, where I begin to feel that there is much of the same enemies as storms to you completely insane amounts. Many enemies also get completely sick of attacks that can take you out in an attack, and when it is supposed to get 10 to 15 like that at one time so I feel that this is just a way to get the player to spend more time in the game, and that it will take longer to get to the real aim. But I feel that all that kind of tasks which, for example, to protect a door for not being destroyed by 2 trolls are completely meaningless, for it does not matter because it is not possible to stop them from destroying the door of two strokes. Then, one dead and one must try again many times.SummaryAll in all I feel that this game could have been much more finished and more thoughtful, but since it is not feels like A 50% BETA! And there's nothing impressive result. I think that basically this game is pretty good, and considering the history, I think that this could become quite good if the developers just had focused more on gameplay. The graphics are old and ugly and a lot of places similar frightening much of Skyrim. The camera feels fine and is as it normally is in all such games. (Can be set according to how sensitive you have lost it on a separate input menu)It is certainly best to play this game with Xbox control if you play on your PC. But sometimes the attacks tend to unlock absolutely everything from motion and control, and will be repealed shot for 1 minute. The game starts well but just gets worse and worse as you get into the game and ends very tame. The game also struggling with little music and have rarely free respite, but in return very good voice acting. I annoys me constantly exaggerated bosses and enemies, and lots of bugs. Prone to crash.Pros:Good story.Okay camera.Good start.Decent durability.Very good voice acting.Cons:Awful controls.Weak end.Respite.Exaggerated matches.Much of the same enemies.Many Bugs.Few songs.Hermes design. (Looks like it should have been taken directly from Skyrim)The graphics are old and ugly.Gameplay: 5/10Graphics: 6/10Control: 5/10Durability: 7/10Camera: 10/10Sound: 9/10Music: 4/10History: 9/10Total: 6/10Difficulty: 8/10The game keeps the age limit.

												Don't let the Metacritic score scare you, if you are the kind of person that weighs a hearty experience over out-dated mechanics, then this game is a MUST. To be honest, I was incredibly surprised by what I've experienced so far with this game, I was expecting something that's just 'to pass the time' worthy, but I've encountered a genuinely enjoyable experience that I'm more than happy to keep coming back to. The combat is 8/10, which is pretty dang good. This isn't a game that lets you ignore mechanics and just hack away, even though some enemies have very easy to recognize/avoid attack pattern, it becomes a must when you reach mid-game and begin to feel just about as sesceptible to death as the warbands of orcs that you're hacking away at.Some of the dialogue can seem very iffy, however if you're interested in lotr lore, then you'll actually want to click away at all the chat options you're given with npc's.However the most important part.......... stabbed an orc in the chest, his leg came off as a result.11/10 lotr anatomy?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												This is a good 3rd person, linear RPG hack'n'slash akin to Darksiders, Batman Arkham Asylum and God Of War III. The main difference is that you have 3 heroes (Elf; caster/healer, Dwarf; tank, Ranger; critical hits & archer) that you can switch between before and after missions and that you can pass items to your non-active characters if you don't want them/can't use them due to class restrictions. The only thing that bugs me about this game is that you can't jump and very minor terrain assets act as improbable obstacles for your characters (i.e. a raised platform no less than a step high). I've only tried single-player, but it seems that if you could get a regular team going it would be just as entertaining and more challenging in multiplayer mode. ****

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												I'll keep it short.I thoroughly enjoyed it, as an avid Tolkien fan, it was nice to see some of the places in Middle Earth explored a little more, Such as Sarn Ford, Fornost etc. I've compiled into a list things I enjoyed and didn't enjoy about the game.Positives: The world looks pretty good, and has captured I feel how the various places you visit would be, based on the description from the book.The combat is decent enough, I played as the Ranger and enjoyed rolling underneath trolls or around Orcs and slashing at them whilst they were exposed.Side quests are a bonus, as in any game as they give you extra things to do, and increase playtime. There are also two 'Survival' type bonus missions.Whilst the levels are Linear, I did feel like I was exploring Middle Earth, which is obviously a good thing.Co-Op, in any adventure game is great, and this can be really good fun with a friend or two.Things I didn't enjoy:Not much to pick at here really, and a few of these things won't apply to you guys anyway.The game felt difficult towards the end, I know it's supposed to be Co-Op, but I found it nigh on impossible doing it on Singleplayer, as both the AI companions ran in a straight line to revive me, straight into the path of that Troll guarding my body.A few of the locations don't feel 'Tolkienesque' to me, such as the Barrow Downs with 'Zombie' like creatures, but this can be overlooked. I felt the shop system a waste of time, as I was constantly finding good enough Gear to be getting on with, and had no need at all to buy any gear except for early in the game, even then I now realise it wasn't nessecary as I often found something better than what I'd just bought moments later in a chest.Conclusion:This review isn't to be taken too serious, a lot of the issues can be overlooked depending on your expectations, but I enjoyed it, and it's a nice little romp through Middle-Earth as you take a different path from the usual main characters during The war of the Ring, And I reccomend this be it to play Solo or Co-op.

												I like games like this. It's simple, puts you in the action immediately, and doesn't go out of its way to make you grind or distract from the story. It's a very enthralling storyline and you get to make a few major choices by the end, to make it somewhat replayable. But what you're really looking for with a game like this is just to feel a part of the cinematic world: Everything you do is something you might see on screen. It's like playing a movie: gets you into the plotline right away, over quick & very satisfying. If you're like me and enjoy these one-time action RPGs, make sure to play through this one some saturday.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
												More an action game with RPG elements than an action-RPG, this is nonetheless an enjoyable ride for fans of the LOTR movie trilogy. Gameplay is entirely centered around the action combat, which is relatively simple but satisfying. The skill tree provides a good sense of power progression and allows some customisation of each character. Aesthetically the game clearly follows the movies, but thanks to the story that intersects but doesn't otherwise follow the LOTR story, there are plenty of new locations to see and new events to play through. There are plenty of hat-tips to Tolkiens lore ( a few goof-ups too, but not too bad) and a decent amount of expositional dialogue. Unfortunately there is little depth to the characters in your party, so they will remain somewhat bland in spite of the 20-30 hours you will spend fighting at their sides.The single-save system is a bit of an annoyance, and so is the limited control and interaction with the AI controlled party members if you play this solo. Technically it was fairly solid otherwise, but the german voiceovers were sometimes assigned to the wrong scenes. An unfixed glitch (imho) is that you can't give shields or potions to your companions.Overall I'd recommend this game to people interested in a LOTR game, that do not mind to have a somewhat constrained visit to middle earth pesented through linear stories and levels and lots of action combat.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												I have ahicived all 4 difficulties on all 3 charachters, many long hours doing so, I can honestly say that War in the North is a wonderfull experieince. It certainly was shadowed by Skyrim's release in November, so it didn't get the recognition it deserves. Each combat method of Magic, Range, and Melee work expectionally well in various situations. The lack of feshed out charchter customization is made up with the sheer abundance of loot and rewards. You can certainly find a mirror (most likeley in resupply areas on the map like the rangers camp) to change your character's face and hair, but I think the sotry was meant to focus on the 3 protaganists rather tan the RPG element like skyrim or Dragon age. The over all story is quite well done, adressing what is going on in the North at the time when the fellowship is doing it's thing in the south (across all 3 books or movies) so you meet alot of the charachters such as Aragorn, Gandalf, and Frodo  and the gang along the way. Along with that, there are many beautifully done enviroments you play throuh, but you can feel boxed in at times, which is disspointing. It is not an 'open world RPG' it is like Dragon Age: Origins in a sense; you may go back to all the locations if you like, but once you start a new playthrough you cannot visit locations until you unlock them. The combat and skill trees are very fluid and well structured, but it can be repetitive at times. It's very satisfieing to see your enemies skull break open in slow motion. Their limbs also break off, ofcourse there is also tons of blood and gore, and settings to remove it. The combat style is based of of which charachter you choose, all of which have a range weapon. Magic for Elf (swords as well), axes and crossbows for Dwarf while the Human uses longsowrds, clasymores, and somewhat of a vanguard suit using sword/axe and shield. It is pretty mcuh what you'd expect them to use. Multiplayer works alright, but is best for friends. Multiplayer only works for 3 players with each player using one of the protaganists. In the game, there are 2 locations that use a wave-based setup. One in Ministirith, and the other in some undead elf area. Both areas are quite small and poorly executed. Overall I rate this game a solid 8.5/10  Interesting story (if you are familiar with the Trilogy Definetly worth a buy.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 10, 2013
												For anyone who is a fan of The Lord of the Rings and action/RPG romps, LotR: War in the North is surprisingly fun.  The story takes place during the events of the books, but focuses around a different set of conflicts and heroes that were briefly touched upon in them.  Gameplay is what you'd expect out of an action RPG; hacking and slashing galore, unlockable and upgradable skills, plenty of loot to collect, and three different characters you can rotate playing with in between missions.  Length-wise, it's a good ~15 hour campaign that includes the option for online co-op and a New Game Plus mode for replayability.As far as issues go, there's nothing gamebreaking, however it does lack a lot of polish in some areas.  The audio is nothing special, and the graphics are often muddy.  The writing and voice acting isn't really up to par with proper RPGs either, but it serves its purpose.  Artificial intelligence, at least on the default difficulty, is pretty poor as well.  As for the controls, keys are remappable, but a gamepad is highly recommended.Though it may lack polish, as a total package, it's made up for by being just plain fun.  If you have a weekend to kill and you can nab it for a good price, War in the North is a worthy play.

Posted: November 15, 2013
												This game is phenomenally good and the multiplayer only makes it better. The story is good, the graphics are very solid, the voice acting is spectacular and I enjoyed every last instant of the combat.The game isn't perfect, it's got a few issues including a graphical bug during one of the mountain areas that causes the gamma to strobe severely (and I am surprised they haven't fixed that as I wouldn't want to get sued for causing a seizure), the multiplayer is quite solid but it can be a bit wonky as the default setting is for a public game, but most irritating is the fact that the steam in-game voice chat CAN NOT be turned off, resulting in hacky unsatisfactory workarounds to turn it off.Fix those, and add the ability to un-socket elfstones (since you upgrade gear so quickly, and there's no way to buy the blasted things) and you'd have a perfect game. As it stands definitely worth picking up!

												Rating: 8/10Extra Info: Kinda has a Dragon Age 1 feel to it, but with a faster pace to it.So I came into this game thinking that it would suck because it wasn't about the Fellowship, but it's actually pretty decent. Great way to pass time, pretty fun and it has some pretty good graphics as well. I recommend NOT playing on easy. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												I was able to enjoy "Lord of the Rings: War in the North" more thoroughly playing co-op. We were able to beat the game through all 4 difficulties and it was challenging enough not to become too boring. However once you encountered an area that you cannot progress through, you were stuck there repeating it until you either bested your foes or decided to quit altogether. It would have made more sense for one to be able to play through previous areas to gain more XP and/or be able to return to town to purchase more ammo, obtain repairs and buy gear, but this is not the case.Single player mode seemed to pose some problems with progression as the game got more difficult (sometimes too difficult). The AI that controls your friends is but in a word "tarded". You must hand them gear (without ever being able to check what they already have) because they aren't intelligent enough to equip themselves with upgrades. There are quite a few bugs that are fairly annoying as well. the dwarf is overpowered with a crossbow and can accomplish insane damage well beyond the abilities of the ranger. Since when are these hairy little guys able to best a ranger at archery?Also there were a few places where my partner in crime was unable to purchase from NPC vendors for whatever reason. Bugs are galore in the game and are less than subtle at times.If you are into LOTR lore, then you may learn some things in this game that perhaps you didn't know before. Rich in lore and details and graphics are nice. Game ran nicely on my both my intel quad core with intel graphics and even moreso on my AMD quad core APU (Radeon 65xx series).All in all we were able to thoroughly enjoy this game throughout, bugs and all. So I recommend it only if you get it at a decent discount or in a bundle as I did. I would never pay full price as it is full of bugs and there is no support since it has been abandoned.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												It's great fun. If you're looking for serious depth, you really aren't going to find it here. But it's a fun romp through the Tolkien universe, with plenty of action and satisfying battles strewn liberally throughout the levels. There seems to always be something to do and somwhere to go, and while I can't comment on the length as I have yet to beat it, it does seem like one of those games where you get what you put into it. Play with friends if you can, though. The AI is okay, but doesn't open secret areas and is pretty useless in a fight except for picking you back up when you inevitably get skullcrushed by the swarm of goblins they let slip past them. Also, Dwarf. The Dwarf is hilarious to play. Little man, big beard, bigger axe, chopping off legs left and right; what's not to love? Lastly, on reports of glitchyness and general bugginess; I've had no problems whatsoever. No visual hiccups, no audio hiccups, nothing. Just smooth sailing. It runs smoothly at max settings on my machine, but your mileage may vary with this product. I've had a great experience, your experience may be less than great. At present, my personal recommendation would be to get this at retail price only if you have friends to group with. Otherwise, wait for a sale. It's built from the ground up as a co-op title, so you might as well play it as a co-op title.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												This game was most likely overlooked by everyone because of low publicity. However, what you will find inside is a fun Action-RPG in the vein of classic games like Baldur's Gate Dark Alliance. The combat is simple but meaty hack-slash-and-roll and you can play as a Ranger, Dwarf or an Elf. The story is original and runs simultaneously with the story from the books. You get to interact with a large number of characters from the books and it even the answers the age old question of "Why didn't the eagles just carry the ring to Mount Doom?" The boss fights are fun, if a little simple but rewards strategic attacking instead of mashing buttons.The main attraction of the game comes from playing online co-op with upto three people. Each character has abilities that compliment other characters. The A.I. is not bad by any means but you can't beat playing with actual people. After you finish the game, New game+ options open up which have chance to obtain more and more powerful weapons.7/10 game if played alone, 9/10 game if played with friends.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												This was the game that (for me) was going to be a fantastic masterpiece and a great keepsake for the honor Lord of The Rings trilogy deserve, but was sadly misused and wasted.LOTR: War in the North is based on the story of JRR Tolkien's books on Lord of the Rings, and the main focus on Ringskrømtene Nazgul and the Witch-king Agandaûr and places that Gundabad and Nordinbad. The protagonists in this story wood and consists of Farin, Eradan and Andriel who supposedly also did a great job during the journey to the ring bearer Frodo and his companions. The three protagonists are not looking in the party, but they are always at a distance from focusing on the war that has break out in the north. Farin, Eradan and Andriel his job is to stop the war, find Agandaûr and prevent war lost influence ring bearer in any way.A good ideaThe background story sounds like a good idea where you can get an incredible amount served and a game that really draws you in suspense. And yes of course it is, but here unfortunately all the possibilities that could have been abused and turned. It began as a rather exciting and gripping game that I really enjoyed every second of. But after a while it sort of just looser and looser. It almost seemed as if the game did not bother and continue any more. Suddenly I discovered that enemies became more and more the same only with stronger health and weaker attack, and eventually began almost everything and repeated several times and the effects were just worse and worse. Eventually, the game was full of bugs and colors that blink and flicker in a single chaos, and when this occurs I start and know that this just be another form of milking.Disgusting and Hermes Skyrim designOne of the most disappointing of this game is that it does not feel or look as if it is based on Lord of the Rings, but instead of a sags copy of Skyrim. It really gives the most impression that this is all about Tolkien's universe and not Skyrim's story. Many of the places you are under review the game looks like they should have been taken directly from Skyrim, and then only made on others just have the same style. I therefore feel that this is not a correct 100% finished game, but instead of a halfway done BETA and it is not exactly satisfying.When we come to control and camera is what most other games. Camera's okay that you can set according to how sensitive you want it on the input menu. But when we come to make it something that stands out a little, and it is in a negative way. If you are playing on PC so it is obviously best to play with a Xbox control, without it it works almost not to play this game. But unfortunately it is not like that fight well with it either, because I often annoy me that the character I play as doing things that he should not do. At various attacks lockup and special attacks erupt, and closes absolutely any kind of movement is therefore a must turn to. But what is strange is that all errors begin to occur when you are roughly halfway through the game.Boss and boss fights seem excessiveThen it hurts me to come with even a negative paragraphs. Again it goes pretty good to roughly the middle of the game, where I begin to feel that there is much of the same enemies as storms to you completely insane amounts. Many enemies also get completely sick of attacks that can take you out in an attack, and when it is supposed to get 10 to 15 like that at one time so I feel that this is just a way to get the player to spend more time in the game, and that it will take longer to get to the real aim. But I feel that all that kind of tasks which, for example, to protect a door for not being destroyed by 2 trolls are completely meaningless, for it does not matter because it is not possible to stop them from destroying the door of two strokes. Then, one dead and one must try again many times.SummaryAll in all I feel that this game could have been much more finished and more thoughtful, but since it is not feels like A 50% BETA! And there's nothing impressive result. I think that basically this game is pretty good, and considering the history, I think that this could become quite good if the developers just had focused more on gameplay. The graphics are old and ugly and a lot of places similar frightening much of Skyrim. The camera feels fine and is as it normally is in all such games. (Can be set according to how sensitive you have lost it on a separate input menu)It is certainly best to play this game with Xbox control if you play on your PC. But sometimes the attacks tend to unlock absolutely everything from motion and control, and will be repealed shot for 1 minute. The game starts well but just gets worse and worse as you get into the game and ends very tame. The game also struggling with little music and have rarely free respite, but in return very good voice acting. I annoys me constantly exaggerated bosses and enemies, and lots of bugs. Prone to crash.Pros:Good story.Okay camera.Good start.Decent durability.Very good voice acting.Cons:Awful controls.Weak end.Respite.Exaggerated matches.Much of the same enemies.Many Bugs.Few songs.Hermes design. (Looks like it should have been taken directly from Skyrim)The graphics are old and ugly.Gameplay: 5/10Graphics: 6/10Control: 5/10Durability: 7/10Camera: 10/10Sound: 9/10Music: 4/10History: 9/10Total: 6/10Difficulty: 8/10The game keeps the age limit.

												Hugely overpriced. But even so are rather nice expansion to the original Lord of the Rings story. With exciting combat (decapitating heads e.t.c) and some nice customization (not just armour!) the game is quite fun, but has some major flaws.The enemies are very predictable, with simple button mashing knocking them down, but the developers were cheeky and throw much tougher enemies at you near the end causing you to think much more strategically. On the bright side, its an interesting story with epic loot and fun with friends. Worth adding to your collection IF its on sale.

It is fun and has a unique storyline.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												5/5 Stars. Playing LOTR: War in The North has had to have been one of the most enjoyable and classical video game experiences I've had in a long time. The Game almost takes me back to "The Third Age" on the Ps2 but i must say, the hack and slash action along with maturity of the gore really shines a new, realistic light on the world of Middle-Earth. The beautifully constructed and designed characters, movements and environments provide for a intense feel and submersion into the story. War in the North is something i wish i had purchased when it was released. The Game was simply beautiful and even though it was difficult to beat a boss at times; that's the way it should be. Thank you Snowblind, probably the best LOTR Experience i'I've had since BFME2.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												I was actually really suprised by this game. It has a full, so far interesting story with good to decent voice acting and nice cut scenes. I wouldn't call the graphics pretty, but they're not bad at all. The combat system reminds me of similar games I would play on the PS2 years ago (Lord of The Rings games, coincidentally). Each class can use both melee and ranged attacks. It includes a leveling system which allows you to put points into certain aspects, as well as a skill tree which offers some nice bonus upgrades (nothing new here, obviously, but it's still in). There are also items that you can find and buy to improve your character (again, nothing new, but it's nice to have).Most importantly though, I'm having fun playing it. It doesn't feel like a grind of clicking until things die. The only thing that would make it more fun for me is if I had some friends along. Should you buy it? At full price, I don't know. On sale though, I think It's worth it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												I would highly recommend this game, as any sane being of sentient nature should. For one, It's mother effing lord of the rings. It is an extremely great game to play through, whether single player or multiplayer. This game has an insane amount of replay value. You can play with two of your friends and become the trio of a Ranger, an elf, and a dwarf. You beat the game? Why not try it on the next difficulty and continuing with your level and abilities. Just wait til you get to heroic difficulty and above. The Uruk-Hai will have no problem wiping the floor with you. It is an awesome adventure, an epic telling of the war fought in the north while frodo and the fellowship carried out their own missions, and waged war in the southern lands. It has a great combat system, with some pretty epic and sprawling battles, a pretty good skill tree for each character, tons of equipment to well, equip. I would give it 9.5 out of 10 bacons.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Apart from the lack of a proper resolution settings there's nothing inherently WRONG with the game. The combat is smooth, the single player is definitely servicable, and the character interaction is pretty fun. However, there's so much about the game that left me wanting more, and not in a good way. The world is beyond linear and offers no sense of adventure or exploration, a total antithesis on Action RPG games or ARPGs in general. Had it at least had some modding support to allow user made maps to provide their own stories or adventures the replay value could skyrocket, but the campaign itself is too stale to really get a grip on you unless you're a huge fan of Tolkein or prefer story over gameplay in general.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Whether you're a fan of Lord of the Rings or not, If you're looking for an Action RPG then BUY Lord of the Rings: War in the North. This is a great game to play either Single Player or Co-Op and If you're a fan of Hack n Slash games with RPG elements then you'll like War in the North with it's really fun combat with brutal finishing moves. If you've played any of Snowblind Studios previous games then you'll know what to expect and feel right at home. Those who are looking for a deep storyline may be disappointed but for those who are looking for non-stop goblin slaying action will enjoy themselves.Pros:-Great Combat System-Beautiful visuals and Armor design-Interesting Characters-Co-op-Nice side story to the LOTR trilogy-Multiple Skill trees for different types of playstyles (i.e. Tank, Stealth, healer, etc)-Lots of enemies so there is never a dull moment.Cons:-Can be buggy-Camera can be disorienting at times. -AI teammates can be worthless-Short game

content:
Posted: January 6, 2012
												This game does Tolkein's Middle Earth right.  The storyline includes that of the Ringbearer, but unlike so many other Middle Earth-based games, it sacrifices and takes nothing away from it in the process.  The graphics are top-notch, the combat is fast-paced, and it's multiplayer.  The high quality writing combines with the superb voice acting to immerse you just about as deeply as anyone can be immersed into Tolkien's world.  There's very little more that I could ask for.

Posted: April 16, 2014
												I've always been in love with LOTR since the first time i laid eyes on it.  Ive played nearly 80% of all LOTR games and this one by far is one of my favorites.  This is a great game full of many fun features including unique weapons and armor for each character and iconic skill trees for each class.  Its a neat side story to the books, with a cool story.  The gameplay is smooth and the combat is realistic and addictive. Thisis a great game and an automatic plus for any fans of the LOTR universe that just want to learn and enjoy playing a piece of it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 10, 2013
												Good game that really needs to be played in co-op mode to get the full fun factor.The game itself has a lot against it. The inventory management system is terrible. You cannot switch between the different characters as often as you should be able to. The game has quite a few bugs, which depending on your graphics card (up to date AMD's) can make the game unplayable on chapter 2 and 8 meaning you have to roll back your drivers to an old version. (12.6 if you needed to know)There's a limited number of different baddies to kill on each level. This game completely over uses the Troll sub boss.But...Once you get into a game with a friend or two you'll soon forgive all this for the sheer joy of beating the living daylights out of whatever it is that needs beating. Cutting an Orc's head off never gets old with the slow-mo kill cam. The loot is varied and interesting, you will constantly be after that next bit of gear to give you a slight edge.Replayability is good, once you've completed the game you can use the same character with the same stats / gear and play through on a harder difficulty, upgrading your gear once again. Even the static rewards get better on higher difficulties.The graphics are, in my opinion, superb. The voice acting is great. The story is fun in a Tolkein is probably turning in his grave way.If you want an online co-op hack and slash and dont have the time or inclination to throw yourself at Diablo 3 or Torchlight 2, then this is a must buy7/10

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												My personal rating 7.5/10Being a massive middle earth fan i had to buy this game. Its a very solid RPG with some nice combat, but thats about it. It has your normal RPG elements levelling and getting gear, but it just doesnt feel like there is enough. There are only a few abilities for each of the 3 characters (different styles) so you get use to doing the same 2 or 3 all the time. Its a very enjoyable game, as you go through the game you come accross characters from the films/books which is a nice touch.But once you finish the game there isnt really much incentive to make you want to play again apart from doing it with all characters on a higher difficulty setting. Getting good gear is pretty easy and i didnt feel there was much varitation in the designs of the gear. There are a few side quests, but they are just there and feel like they are just added in for the sake of it. A few secret walls and thats about it.The game isnt really open world and you do the same line of quests for each character in the same order.Buy it cheap if you are a middle earth fan. Guaranteed atleast one enjoyable playthrough!!!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												If a slightly more than casual co-op hack 'n' slash set in Middle Earth sounds appealing, then you should buy LOTRTWITN.  (fun acronym, innit?)  If you want something deeper to play by yourself, then you will probably want to look elsewhere.War in the North is essentially Baldur's Gate: Dark Alliance set in Tolkien's universe. By that, I mean you and your AI/co-op partners will hack, combo, loot and sever your way through several chapters of ... who cares.  While the setpieces are faithfully drawn from Peter Jackson's LotR films, the story itself is not that important. Heroes will triumph in the face of seemingly insurmountable odds, and bad guys will deliver gutteral dialogue through the rugged steel spikes of their helmets. If nothing else can be said for the story, it at least gives the eagles an excuse for not simply flying Frodo to Mt. Doom to begin with. (not a specific spoiler, but yes -- there are eagles)Combat involves stringing combos together and landing stronger attacks when enemies are critical. In a way, that system reminds me of the original Witcher.  (tho very basic)  Leveling up gets you three attribute points and one to invest in skills.  Diabloesque ability trees allow you to play as you desire (to an extent), though melee combat remains relevant for every class. Further Diablo inspiration can be seen in the item "sets" you can combine for cumulative stat bonuses. All three classes have their own gameplay styles and the ability to discover hidden loot. The game is not a simple brawler: some areas and boss fights will require more than button-mashing and spamming skills. For tough foes that can knock you down, the dodge/roll ability is your friend.Presentation-wise, this game is behind the times. It runs on a souped-up version of a 2001 engine. While Snowblind has added some flourishes to remain relevant, it looks more like an early 360 era ('06) game than something released in 2011. The bland (but passable) visuals hold close enough to the film's art design. Just don't expect anything to write home about. We encountered a few frustrating glitches while playing, but they did not repeat. 360 controller support makes this a nice game to play from a couch, but the keyboard & mouse work fine for those used to already doing so.General sound design seems fine and supports my 5.1 system, but there seems to be an unresolved issue where the game has a permanently open mic in multiplayer. (so you hear quiet echoes if there's speaking in the room) The music ranges from fine to slightly distracting. I don't know whether it was a licensing issue or creative decision to forgo the musical scoring of the films, but it might have helped give the game a grander feel.Like many co-op titles, it's best played with friends to be experienced at its fullest potential.  If you have to fly solo, you may find this to be a disappointing experience. Either way, I'd say it's best purchased at sale price.
