number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												I read a lot of negative things about the Lord of the Rings-themed action RPG by Snowblind Studios, War in the North, prior to playing the “your first 30 minutes are free” demo on OnLive. These included the following: voice-acting was terrible; enemy variety was lacking; combat was generic and unsatisfying; there were numerous game-breaking bugs; and the story was not very interesting. What I discovered is that none of these things are true. In fact, I had much more fun playing WitN than Diablo. It exceeded my expectations in almost every way, and it was much better than the last action-RPG I played, Rise of the Argonauts, and that game was no slouch.I’m not sure I understand the hatred expressed toward this game, and I can really only account for it in two ways: 1) people who were playing WitN were expecting an old-school CRPG, which it was clear from pretty early in the development cycle that this was not going to be; or 2) the console versions have lots of issues. This is definitely one of the most underrated PC games of the year.The game is intended to be played as a co-op ARPG, but you can play solo as one of the three characters in your mini-fellowship and let the AI handle the duties of your compatriots. This works quite well except that, for good or ill, your NPC cohorts will not complete mission objectives like pulling levers to move to the next area or jumping on the odd mounted crossbow that you will find throughout the game to make it easier to take down waves of approaching enemies. One other quirk with the AI that makes life needlessly difficult on occasion is that it appears to be coded in such a way that if one of your group falls, the other two will prioritize reviving him/her over any other activity, even if the two of them are both surrounded by a swarm of melee enemies. Because reviving a downed ally takes about 5 seconds and is easily interrupted if the reviver takes too much damage, this can cause a lot of checkpoint reloads.Yes, you read that right: “checkpoint reloads.” I’ve more or less come to expect this phenomenon in multiplatform titles these days, but it still irks me that PC gamers with voluminous hard drives are forced to rely on single-save checkpoint systems like our console brethren. Fortunately, checkpoints are at least reasonably spaced so that you rarely have to replay long sections to get back to a point where you perished previously.The story follows a group of allies on a quest to defeat Agandaûr, a lieutenant of Sauron tasked with conquering the Northern territories of Middle-earth: Farin, a dwarven warrior from Erebor; Eradan, a Dunedain ranger oathbound to follow Aragorn; and Andriel, an elven lore-master of Rivendell. These three find themselves in Bree-town shortly after an encampment of rangers nearby is attacked by the Nazgûl. There they meet with Aragorn, who is awaiting the arrival of Mr. Underhill at the Prancing Pony; he charges them with the task of tracking down and destroying the Black Numenorean known as Agandaûr and suggests they start in the Fields of Fornost, which lie to the northwest. There begins a journey that will take them from the Barrow-downs to Rivendell to the Mirkwood and beyond. It’s a really interesting story and chock full of lore-references for the nerds among us.Despite what others may have said, the voices for each character are wonderful and the sound-alikes for the characters that appear in the films are quite good (with the sole exception of Aragorn, who just sounds wrong in some unfathomable way). Best of all is the fellowship’s frequent companion, the Great Eagle Beleram, whose voice just sounds like you would think an Eagle’s would, if they were to speak the King’s English. The rest of the sound design is great too, including some terrific incidental music.Graphically, the game is also well-done, although the character model faces are not quite up to the standards of the latest generation. Environments are varied and feel realistic. Most of the cut-scenes are in-engine and quite serviceable, but there are a few pre-rendered ones that are spectacular.The gameplay is typical for the genre: your group moves into an area, triggers a few waves of enemies, and then the mechanism to open the door/passage/gate to the next area is activated. The left mouse button is used for a standard attack, the right mouse button for a heavy attack, WASD keys for movement and the number keys (1-6) for health/power potions and special attacks. When enemies have taken a sufficient amount of damage, a yellow arrow will appear over their heads and you can perform a high-damage or killing-blow move; these frequently result in a limbs or heads being severed in a spray of black blood (to my recollection, even your human enemies don’t have blood of the more conventional dark red color). It’s a very visceral and satisfying system.Loot is obtained in several ways: enemies frequently drop coins and ranged-weapon ammunition (if you are playing as Farin or Eradan), loot piles and treasure chests are located in various places around the maps, and each character has a special treasure-finding ability (Farin can find veins of gold and on very rare occasions secret rooms in cave-like areas; Andriel can locate and open magically-warded secret doors; Eradan can follow tracks to ranger caches of money and weapons).Aside from the story mode, which can be played in online co-op if you can find other players (I had no luck recently when attempting to grab the one achievement that requires other humans), there are two challenge missions set in Lothlorien and Osgiliath. These throw waves of enemies at your group and can be a fun diversion for a while but ultimately get a bit tedious. There is also a new game plus mode, allowing you to restart the story with all of your levels and equipment intact with more difficult enemies. Actually there are two unlockable difficulty levels, Heroic and Legendary, but I probably won’t play through the game again; playing through any game more than once is a rare thing for me these days as I have such a massive backlog, but if you’re like me, you may have missed or were unable to complete a few sidequests on the first go-round, and it’s still just as enjoyable the second time through (with no real surprises to speak of, though).War in the North is not exactly perfect; there are a few bugs to contend with, although none of the ones I encountered could in any way be considered “game-breaking.” Andriel can unlock an ability to dual-wield a staff and sword, much the way Gandalf did in the films. Unfortunately, when you change areas, the game “forgets” that you have a secondary weapon equipped and empties that slot, so you have to go back to the inventory screen and manually reselect it. On one occasion in my second playthrough as Farin, Andriel completely disappeared in Mount Gundabad and did not return until after I got myself killed.These are basically nitpicks really, though. Yes, it’s not the most polished gaming experience ever, but, hey, good luck finding a bug-free AAA release these days. On the whole, it’s tremendous fun, and as I said before, easily among the best ARPG experiences you can find for the PC.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												Really a pretty decent hack and slash. Although the story is mostly forgettable, all around a decent experience. With every swing of my axe carrying a real heft and weight to it, combat feels very satisfying. I only have a few complaints. First, in my limited time playing as the mage, I found that she feels VASTLY underpowered compared to the other two characters. Second, with my Radeon 7970, I still get crashes when there are too many particle effects going on. Despite these problems and the aforementioned pitiful story, I would still recommend this game. 8.0/10.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												I haven't finished the game yet, however I could barely tear myself away to write a review. The leveling system is paced very well, and I've rarely felt that I was "grinding" exp. The combat is EXTREMELY representative of LOTR in the sense that you and your party can be put in 3 vs 30 fight, and even though you slay hordes of enemies the number of enemies present never seems to fall below that 30, and in some cases, will even go above. You can be thrown into combat with 3 enormous trolls, 20-30 orcs AND a mini-boss type enemy like an orc chieftain at a moments notice. Very combat heavy and story driven.

Posted: September 29, 2014
												As a fan of Lord of the Rings, I came into playing this game with high expectations. I was not disappointed! Not even a little. The game is a mix of RPG and third person slasher. It follows a new cast of adventurers as they quest on their own journey through middle earth.The single player is fun, though the "Companions" AI leaves much to be desired. It's definitely more enjoyable while played with friends in co-op mode, though I would avoid playing with Pick Up Groups, as is usually the case, that's often times a bad idea.Still, if you love tolkien, and hobbits and adventure, then you owe it to yourself to get this game.8/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 7, 2012
												This isn't a perfect game; it's not the best of ports (although it works), it's kinda corridor-ish at times and it's got friggin' always on online voicechat (something I just can't understand), but it's got lots of stuff going for it. Most of all, it feels like LotR and that's kinda important! You get launched into Middle-Earth and you stay there, even though very few original characters are to be seen. The combat is fierce and, well, cool and you know you're swinging a thirty kg sword - you feel the weight behind it! And of course, it's got three player co-op, which is the most important aspect to ANY game!This is kinda a must buy for LotR-fans who love to play cooperatively and that can momentarily forget that you have to use the somewhat horrible in game voicechat.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												Rating: 8/10Extra Info: Kinda has a Dragon Age 1 feel to it, but with a faster pace to it.So I came into this game thinking that it would suck because it wasn't about the Fellowship, but it's actually pretty decent. Great way to pass time, pretty fun and it has some pretty good graphics as well. I recommend NOT playing on easy. It started me off on Normal, but I got stuck in the Barrow-Downs with NO heath or power potions and no way to get through to the next store or get back to the last town so I thought this game was SUPER hard, it's not really. You just have to stock up on supplies. Easy is just WAY too easy, still fun though and I'm looking forward to my next playthrough on a harder difficulty. Oh just a friendly tip, DON'T give NPCs items... EVER. They will be lost forever, sell anything you aren't using or change the character and give THAT player the items. Never NPCs though. You've been warned. lol.

												I really, really recommend this game for all lovers of Lord of the Rings. During this game you find people from the original series (like Bilbo, Frodo, Gandalf... And even some of The Hobbit movie), make friendships with people from all over the north and discover things behind the film, as the characters are identical to the ones in the film. Though the only thing I would change was to have a mercenary mode in the end, which could discover all the places in the map (The Shire, Minas Tirith, Erebor...) and fix some bugs here and there. Still, the game is really recommend,   8.5 / 10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												I was actually really suprised by this game. It has a full, so far interesting story with good to decent voice acting and nice cut scenes. I wouldn't call the graphics pretty, but they're not bad at all. The combat system reminds me of similar games I would play on the PS2 years ago (Lord of The Rings games, coincidentally). Each class can use both melee and ranged attacks. It includes a leveling system which allows you to put points into certain aspects, as well as a skill tree which offers some nice bonus upgrades (nothing new here, obviously, but it's still in). There are also items that you can find and buy to improve your character (again, nothing new, but it's nice to have).Most importantly though, I'm having fun playing it. It doesn't feel like a grind of clicking until things die. The only thing that would make it more fun for me is if I had some friends along. Should you buy it? At full price, I don't know. On sale though, I think It's worth it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Great action game with some fun RPG elements.I loved the ability to play 3 different types of characters, basically hunter, mage or warrior. The characters are available for play only at the beginning of chapters or main areas before you start. AI for characters you are not playing seemed really good even though there were several times they got lost in an area or couldn’t jump down into an area. The pathing needs to be fixed on AI characters for sure.Story and voice overs were great, I love all the Lord of the Rings stories and this game does an excellent job getting you engrossed into the story and wanting to learn more about the characters. I have never been a super Tolkien Lore master so I can’t tell you if it is true to all the original Tolkien Stories. The game is more about a small group that helps with activities outside of the main storyline with Frodo and company.Combat with Keyboard and mouse was very responsive and easy to play. Skills are minimal but helpful during battles, especially boss fights. Items and equipment can be found almost everywhere with special sets available and that can be worn for bonuses during game play.There are NPC's in every story area for purchasing equipment and repairing equipment. Also there are lighted areas before main story battles that allow you to Buy and sell equipment, also gives you the option to travel to previous locations if needed for quest turn ins.Large map can be used for fast travel by just selecting area, also contains fighting challenges for group to fight waves of enemies.Only down side of the game other than the AI pathing issues is that there is no manual saving, the game saves automatically at new areas or story starts. When you complete a battle or area you find a glowing point that allows you to proceed to next area and it performs a save. Even though the game didn’t allow manual saves, it saved game enough times that I never had to redo a lot when my party was defeated in battle, since it typically saves just before the major battle or area change.Overall I would highly recommend this game, especially now that it is within budget price.
